[08/11/2024, 10:00:40] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: Article says minimal impact on sales. The interesting issue is how can the US enforce a ban on sales of high end chips. [10/11/2024, 06:44:44] Nick finegold: As the world starts to play GameStop with Crypto and realises, if everyone buys the same asset we all get rich , here is a guide to how far this rally might go . 

Historically, Bitcoin‚Äôs price has tended to rise significantly following a halving event, though this is not guaranteed. Each Bitcoin halving, which reduces the reward for mining new blocks by half (thus reducing the rate at which new Bitcoin is introduced), has often been followed by a substantial bull run. Here‚Äôs a general overview of past trends:

	1.	First Halving (2012): After the first halving in November 2012, Bitcoin‚Äôs price rose from around $12 to nearly $1,200 over the following year, marking a nearly 100x increase.

	2.	Second Halving (2016): After the second halving in July 2016, Bitcoin‚Äôs price rose from around $650 to almost $20,000 by December 2017, a roughly 30x increase.

	3.	Third Halving (2020): After the May 2020 halving, Bitcoin‚Äôs price climbed from about $8,700 to over $64,000 by April 2021, about a 7x increase.

BITCOIN just hit $1.7trillion. Just overtook Silver as 8th most valuable asset class.
( can you name the top 7!) 

Worth collecting a few thoughts here as we are clearly Entering the ‚ÄúRhino Zone‚Äù (euphoric and horny) stage now.
Raoul calls it the ‚Äúbanana zone‚Äù.

Retail will clearly do what they do best, buy the top and sell the bottom.( see Coinbase rankings as these are good proxys). 
I am told that many who went quiet in the middle of 2022 are now waking up and realising they've missed a good bit of the action, when it becomes a flurry I start to get a bit worried, but we are nowhere near there yet... I am also hearing v little supply on exchange! 
My BITCOIN Price Target for 2024 has consistently been $3trn, we just hit $1.7 trillion now. I think we see the next top could be around about $4.5trn. ( but honestly thats art not science). 
I have said constantly on Politics remember ‚ÄúPoetry vs Prose=campaigns vs policy reality‚Äù. 
It would be silly to expect complete plain sailing, but probably is good to ‚Äúbask in‚Äù the glory until a January inauguration 
(tx Jonah). 
One thing I think that's important about this cycle is the divergence between Bitcoin and the rest of crypto. 
Bitcoin is clearly digital Gold with large Sovereign, Pension and Institutional buyers now coming and consistent buyers, whatever the weather, so the domino effect there should mean it continues to remain strong over the long term. 
The Rest of crypto remains highly correlated with risk assets and monetary easing / QE / speculation / gambling since tied to VC inflows and retail bank accounts / sentiment. 
So I think more and more crypto can be understood in two buckets. One will be a more steady line up, the other will remain volatile year by year.
For now BITCOIN/ ETHE/ SOLANA/ MSTR / COINBASE/ DOGE/ SUI ( RaoulP) / RAYDIUM (Nutstuff).

[12/11/2024, 03:34:53] ~‚ÄØJB: Eur2,100/ mg

The price for Ytterbium-176, a stable isotope used primarily for producing Lutetium-177 in cancer treatments, varies widely based on availability and regional supply factors. The U.S. Department of Energy‚Äôs National Isotope Development Center (NIDC) periodically releases new batches, but specific pricing often requires a direct quote due to fluctuating production costs and market demand. For recent pricing, reports indicate it can range around 2,100 EUR per milligram in European markets; however, prices may vary internationally based on purity and isotopic form

Richemont had been trying to offload Yoox Net-A-Porter for a while (there is an activist in Richemont) and originally was going to sell it to Farfetch, but the latter imploded and got sold for pennies to Coupang. MYTE will take on YNAP but Richemont is also throwing in 500mm EUR (!) of cash for a 1/3 stake in the combined company. Mind you MYTE‚Äôs entire market cap prior to this transaction was ~300mm EUR (!!) so Richemont is giving away the platform and paying a massive premium to own the remainder. [13/11/2024, 08:06:23] Nick finegold: For those interested this is how MS get to $500 on Tesla 

Tesla breakdown of $500 PT for those that care . 

Key 2030 assumptions underpinning our current $500 bull case:

Auto: $90/share. 8mm units (28% unit CAGR vs. FY24 base) with 20% EBITDA margin. Our current base case auto assumption of 5.7mm units by 2030 implies a 21% unit CAGR.
Energy: $85/share. 400 GWh of ESS deployed (54% CAGR through FY30) with 22% EBITDA margin. Current base case is for 280 GWh ESS deployed by 2030.
Network Services: $146/share. Recurring software and service revenue. Includes used, parts & service, F&I, charging, FSD and other services. 25mm Tesla MAUs + 5.6mm Licensees, roughly $200/month ARPU with 53 to 55% EBITDA margins.
Mobility/Ride-Share: $118/share. 1mm units in mobility fleet by 2030, 60k miles/car, $1.75/mile, 25% EBITDA margin. We assume predominantly human supervised well beyond 2030.
3rd Party Battery/Powertrain: $61/share. 3.4mm licensee units (12% non-Tesla EV penetration), $50bn revenue, 25% EBITDA margin.
Humanoids: $0/share. Our current $500 bull case includes no explicit value of robotics/embodied AI beyond the automotive form factor. Among a wide range of assumptions, each 1% of FY24 US labor that could be replaced by Tesla Optimus could be worth approximately $100/share (NPV) to TSLA shares.
Combined total company FY30 revenue of approximately $550bn with EBITDA over $140bn.
Components of $500 Bull Case
Image
Source: Morgan Stanley Research.
Sensitivity analysis by business line: The following exhibit shows the impact on the TSLA share price (NPV/share) by flexing our FY30 assumption across units the units. For example, in autos every 1mm units of FY30 auto sales is worth approximately $10/share to Tesla. 100 GWh of ESS deployed is worth around $20/share. Please reach out to your Morgan Stanley salesperson for our sensitivity model (included in our earnings model) to help run custom scenarios.

[13/11/2024, 15:20:36] Nick finegold: Peanut the Squirrel (PNUT) is a meme-based cryptocurrency that emerged in early November 2024, inspired by a real-life pet squirrel named Peanut. Peanut gained popularity through social media, where his owner, Mark Longo, shared videos of the squirrel‚Äôs antics, amassing a significant following. The situation took a tragic turn when New York‚Äôs Department of Environmental Conservation confiscated and euthanized Peanut, citing concerns over unsafe housing conditions and potential rabies exposure. This action sparked widespread outrage online, with public figures like Elon Musk criticizing the authorities‚Äô decision. Ôøº

In response to the public outcry, developers launched the PNUT token on the Solana blockchain as a tribute to Peanut. The token quickly gained traction among traders and meme enthusiasts, leading to a surge in its value. Within days, PNUT‚Äôs market capitalization exceeded $100 million, with trading volumes reaching impressive levels. Ôøº

The rapid rise of PNUT highlights the influence of internet culture and social media on cryptocurrency markets. However, experts caution that meme-based tokens like PNUT are highly volatile and often lack intrinsic value, making them risky investments. Ôøº

As of November 13, 2024, PNUT continues to be actively traded, with its price experiencing significant fluctuations. Investors are advised to approach such meme coins with caution, given their speculative nature and the potential for rapid value changes. Ôøº

[22/11/2024, 13:53:42] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Nick here‚Äôs some food for thought‚Ä¶.

‚ÄúSatoshi discovered a method to transfer value without a trusted intermediary. But the brilliant idea was that
Satoshi found a method to store value without a trusted intermediary. Bitcoin is not just a little bit better than
Visa, but funding a replacement for storing value makes it a $450 trillion use case worth $10 trillion a year.
Bitcoin represents the transformation of our capital from financial and physical assets to digital assets. Bitcoin
is an asset without the financial risk of currency, stocks, and bonds or the physical risk of real estate or
property. This makes it digital capital (not currency). Digital capital has no tax, tenants, weather, corrosion,
regulator, etc. Digital capital is invisible, indestructible, immortal, teleportable, programmable, divisible, etc. It
is better than owning any building in New York, not even thinking about Moscow or any third-world country
(store of value) asset. This is the solution to global capital, and it is why all the capital in the world will flow into
the Bitcoin network. If you want to be wealthy forever, where would you put your money? Bitcoin is backed by
power. Bitcoin is the most powerful crypto network in the world, having 220 million holders. Bitcoin is
emerging as the dominant digital monetary network. Bitcoin is now the world's most recognised, widely held,
interesting, and compelling investment asset. Gold was the best idea in the 19th century‚Äì now it is dead
money. When people understand Bitcoin better, the 1-3% portfolio allocation will soon be more than 10-20%.
Bitcoin is a digital commodity, an asset without an issuer backed by digital power. Between 2024 and 2045, the
digital transformation will bring in $500 trillion of prosperity, including $280 trillion of Bitcoin, $350 trillion of
digital equity, $170 trillion of digital bonds, and $50 trillion of digital currency. Digital real estate and digital art
could each be $10 trillion. The Bitcoin Act of 2024: Trillions in 20th century physical and financial capital will
flow into the Bitcoin network, primarily benefiting the United States. It would strengthen the dollar and
protect the USD's status as the world‚Äôs reserve currency. The U.S. establishes, owns, and controls the world‚Äôs
reserve capital network. Any movement away from UST will flow into Bitcoin, assuring U.S. economic power.
Attract capital from around the world into the U.S., creating jobs, power, and prosperity. The financial impact
could be enormous as the U.S. can print money, take the Bitcoin bet, and, worse case, print cash for free, but
the 1 million Bitcoin Strategic Reserve proposal could lower the deficit from $54 trillion in 2035 to $32 trillion
by 2024 as the value of the U.S. Strategic Bitcoin reserve increases to $17 trillion of value. The historic
precedents for the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve are Manhattan in 1626, Louisiana in 1803, California in 1848, and
Alaska in 1867.
The idea is simple: determine where the value will be, buy it, and hold it forever. Bitcoin is the manifest
destiny of the Trump administration. It is the greatest deal of the 21st century that would be worth $3 trillion if
the U.S. holds its current Bitcoin, or $16 trillion if they implement the Bitcoin Strategic Reserve Act, which sees
the U.S. buying an additional 1 million Bitcoins over 5 years. If the U.S. does this, every other country has to
follow. The more aggressive, the more certain it could be.‚Äù

[25/11/2024, 16:43:17] ~‚ÄØPhilip Donald: on a rather different note‚Ä¶but quite possibly the most amazing thing I have read this year.    For the first time, says New Atlas, mosquitos have been used to deliver a malaria vaccine rather than the disease itself. Researchers at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine genetically modified the single-celled plasmodium falciparum parasite that hides in the salivary glands of female mosquitos and causes the deadly disease following a bite. After somehow finding volunteers to test the method ‚Äì getting bitten up to 50 times ‚Äì the pointy-headed parasitologists showed that a remarkable 90% of those inoculated in this way had developed immunity to the disease. The hope is that the technique will lead to widespread vaccination programmes without the need for refrigerated supply chains, sterilised needles and trained medics‚Ä¶.WOW!

[27/11/2024, 07:56:51] Nick finegold: Short attacks and Evolv 

Evolv US - Gun and knife crime - A core thematic pick which  we stayed with at the most difficult of times. 

Evolv US, uses touchless screens to search for guns knives and explosives , the stock fell 40% in a day because their financial accounts needed to be restated as a small amount of revenues ( $4-6m ) were booked early but were in no way fabricated. 

The CEO and FD have left the company , it was clumsy but running a public company can be complicated. .

Yesterday An FTC trade enquiry was resolved allowing a handful of schools using Evlv screens to cancel their contracts early if they are not happy with the product . This could impact 4% of ARR if EVERY contract were to be cancelled which we do not believe they all will be based on customer feedback. In addition there were no fines. 


Evlv has been subject to a short attack where the bears said their technology didn‚Äôt work despite 50 major sports franchises using their kit post rigorous trials 

Absolutely everything we have been told by the team at Stoic has turned out to be true and expect more good news going forward on new appointments that strengthen the companies governance and foundations further. 

These attacks can provide fantastic entry points and improve companies IF the core business is solid. 

These short attacks are a new dynamic in the market and can provide great entry points IF the core business is solid.

That‚Äôs what we concentrated on with Evlv US and that‚Äôs what needs to be concentrated on with asp isotopes , smci and a raft of other names that get attacked. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

Oxford Nanopore and UK Biobank to create world's largest epigenetic dataset targeting the causes of cancer, dementia, complex disease

27 Nov 2024

 The project will utilise Oxford Nanopore's technology to map the epigenome using 50,000 UK Biobank participant samples, to unlock crucial insights into disease mechanisms
The initiative builds upon a new strategic partnership between UK Biobank, Genomics England and NHS England to drive biomedical research forward and improve patient outcomes in the UK and beyond

Not a revenue changer for this year , but the company moves closer & closer to the NHS in diseases prevention and analysis .

[27/11/2024, 10:41:53] ~‚ÄØDipesh Patel: Now I'm no fuzzy panda and I'm not suggesting accounting fraud over the ¬£4.54 I paid for my chai tea latte last week (although it was daylight robbery), nor have I verified the Starbucks sites in Alaska, on the USS Harry Truman carrier, or the Robinson funeral home in South Carolina, but I am puzzled by the performance of the stock. What am I missing? Can anyone help? I appreciate we don't propose too many shorts through the club (rightly so), but SBUX feels to me like a Lulu or Nike waiting to happen after multi decade dominance. 
My inherited East African roots (no pun intended) have fueled some nerdy agricultural interests and also flagged over summer that coffee plants aren't flowering anywhere. For those not bored yet, pretty much all coffee is grown between the tropic of Cancer and the tropic of Capricorn in 3 regions and the critical months that have just passed can't have too much rain else the flowers for next year develop fungus. The rain has been terrible with no region unaffected. You can see that in the move in coffee pricing which is the most sensitive variable in every cup SBUX sells. For disclosure, I intend on shorting SBUX, I don't do any alpha capture systems as I have no alpha, and I am slightly nerdy about horticulture üòÖ. It's on 35x with downward earnings revisions. PS I'm not a coffee drinker!

[27/11/2024, 12:41:51] Nick finegold: On Aspi having watched the Paul Mann video . I have two simple observations 

1/ If the isotope business is in a state of readiness as it appears to be , investors will shortly require  a financial forecast on the mainstream business that should clearly underpin the valuation. The potential of being able to cool silicon trumps all other user cases and is fascinating . 

I have asked when forecasts will be forthcoming and the answer is that once these plants become operational there is sample testing and only post that exercise is it prudent to issue forecasts. More clarity on a timeline for when the company will provide investors with a forecast is very important. 

2/ If the nuclear tech is proprietary and not available to public scrutiny, ( which is entirely believable ) the key question then becomes have terra power seen it ? It is they not fuzzy panda that matter. 

It seems unlikely that any company would enter an MOU without some substantial DD in area such as nuclear . If they have seen it because they are part of the inner circle of nuclear energy providers , that makes the MOU very sustantive . 

Get clarity on those two issues and the rest is just noise . ‚Äé<This message was edited>
[27/11/2024, 13:16:59] Hope Finegold: ‚ÄéNick finegold added Hope Finegold
[27/11/2024, 13:58:48] TFG Personal: ‚ÄéNick finegold added ~‚ÄØKC Shetty and ‚Ä™+44¬†7932¬†034830‚Ä¨
[27/11/2024, 14:01:10] ~‚ÄØMatt H: Nick on the point of MOU‚Äôs my personal opinion is that you have nothing to lose by signing one as a buyer. If as a buyer you get the product then great it will help your business. If you don‚Äôt then nothing lost. There were loads of lithium miners that had MOU‚Äôs for offtake with OEM‚Äôs  & battery manufacturers etc. A lot of them never made it into production as the lithium/nickel/cobalt price fell out of bed. An MOU to me is nice to have but not a validation.
[27/11/2024, 14:07:20] Nick finegold: I agree , Matt that‚Äôs why I wrote what I wrote , it needs some form of external validation ideally from Terra power . I guess my point is that nuclear technology is not quite like signing a PPA for electricity or lithium it‚Äôs a touch more sensitive and nuanced  , I am not sure I would put my name in something that could lead to an investment . But your point is well taken and if that‚Äôs the angle of attack that (ie the MOU is not worth the paper that it‚Äôs written on ) then anything that makes it more substantive is good and where this needs to go ultimately. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[01/12/2024, 17:16:39] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: A bit of a hidden gem in the uranium space this morning 

https://on.ft.com/4eVAfKw
[01/12/2024, 17:17:33] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: I think it could be one of the most important pieces of news for uranium this year. 

We believe that the reason contracting volumes have been lower for u3o8 is because of the conversion bottleneck. 

I.e. there is no point in contracting u3o8 until you have conversion capacity.
[01/12/2024, 17:18:47] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Then a second article was released today following it which is well worth reading 

https://paulomacro.substack.com/p/uranium-and-a-key-upcoming-catalyst?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=posts-open-in-app&utm_medium=email&r=1hgame&triedRedirect=true

This article correctly notes that ‚ÄúA 6kt expansion at Metropolis opens up just over 20mmlbs of annual U3O8 demand. Since contracting tends to be multi-year, a capacity expansion would probably see contracting for say 3 years demand. In other words the expansion could touch off 50-70mm lbs of U3O8 contracting very quickly‚Äù.

Expansions in conversion capacity will have meaningful implications for u3o8 demand and is likely the reason for this years lack of volumes. Really interesting.

[02/12/2024, 09:11:00] Nick finegold: A quick word on Oxford Nanopore.

Two weeks ago after a great start in the portfolio the stock collapsed from ¬£1.60 to ¬£1.20 . I still have no idea why,  but with so much of the free float tied up with strategic allies, one redemption or distressed seller can disproportionately impact the price. 

I wrote in our club note that it was a good time to double up, given the recent NHS deals , focus on prevention opposed to cure and comparable valuations of some genomic testing businesses in the US (whose lanes were narrower)  but whose valuations were multiples of Nanopore had caught my eye. 

Since then the stock has rallied very aggressively.  

I just think that if US buyers begin to see what we see, this things could end the year well through ¬£2 and well through ¬£4 at the end of next year if they can scale these healthcare relationships. The companies products are see as a research tool not a mass market diagnostic testing tool and that really needs to change. 

It‚Äôs also worth mentioning that as Nanopore rises so does the NAV of IP Group that owns 11% as they continue to buyback their shares .

[03/12/2024, 12:01:54] Nick finegold: Recent reports of a 300t ‚Äúsupergiant gold‚Äù discovery in China has been hitting the headlines in recent days.

Digging deeper (if you will!) into this report, we understand that based on the amount of drilling that has taken place in the region, and the presence of artisanal gold working in the region and reports of as many as 40 gold veins intersected, there is probably some merit to what has been reported.

However, while a 300t discovery is large, it is hardly huge, and we doubt very much will have any impact on the global gold market. Even if the larger suggested 1000t resource were to be proved, and a larger mine developed, it seems unlikely to produce more than 30t ‚Äì approximately 1 million ounces ‚Äì per year. This would be an impressive mine, but small compared to global annual mine production of about 3,600tpy.

[05/12/2024, 10:17:57] ~‚ÄØGiles Fitzpatrick: Is there a simple explanation for this - assuming it‚Äôs correct? 

https://x.com/kobeissiletter/status/1864471249071595525?s=48&t=LR4xE8MKg3Nh16kdgyxEEQ
[05/12/2024, 10:19:25] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: Some plausible
[05/12/2024, 10:19:38] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: I'll highlight two
[05/12/2024, 10:22:39] ~‚ÄØGustavo M: Earnings surprises is the most obvious
[05/12/2024, 10:22:54] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: (1) companies report after close/pre open. Given on average they manage to surprise positively, this is reflected immediately in the opening price. So the open/prev close return captures most of the move
[05/12/2024, 10:26:32] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: (2) Patient/smart money vs impatient money. Impatient money rushes to trade at the open and pays the wrong price. Then spends the rest of the day earning nothing or even losing money. Patient money trades more intelligently and often later in the day so they capture the overnight moves.
[05/12/2024, 10:29:02] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: The conclusion is that short term (at the open) markets generally overreact.
[05/12/2024, 10:29:13] ~‚ÄØGiles Fitzpatrick: Thanks Zac.
[05/12/2024, 10:39:15] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: To clarify further, this doesn't mean all impatient money is dumb. There are many investor types, not just two, and some fast money (notably many algo HFT) is smart and profitable. But there is a significant group who "need" to trade at the open and the market knows how to make them pay. Being too impulsive doesn't pay.
[05/12/2024, 10:46:30] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: Another way to look at it is market makers (human or algo) are price setters and they are on average smart. Impatient money are price takers. The former know that the latter dominate the opening flows and not only set prices efficiently, they set them even further to make the latter pay.
[05/12/2024, 10:46:31] ~‚ÄØChris Huggins: Interesting Zak, thx. I am doing a bit of research into this myself for a systematic strategy. Are there any decent papers / broker notes you have seen that have some hard data on the ‚Äúimpatient money‚Äù theory?
[05/12/2024, 10:48:02] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: Hi Chris, will try to dig out, have seen some although often not actionable.
[05/12/2024, 10:49:09] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: You should speak to Gustavo too, he has experience in running systematic strategies.
[05/12/2024, 10:50:23] ~‚ÄØGustavo M: Happy to chat. Please text me privately. But no, haven‚Äôt seen any papers

[05/12/2024, 10:59:22] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: Yep, I see some of these are relatively low vol ETFs so if you rush to pay up at the open, you have definitely overpaid...

[12/12/2024, 14:45:09] ~‚ÄØTim: I met these guys many times, including in Denmark. The problem is they signed a lot of contracts 2018 to 2020 with very few inflation clauses and cost escalation pass through. After Putin's invasion of Ukraine the price of everything went up, especially steel, and Vestas have been stuck executing loss making business and working off these contracts. The end of this tunnel is supposed to be arriving soon but they keep guiding that EBIT margins will get back to 10%... then missing by a country mile. 

Then factor in the change in debt costs massively affecting the economics of a wind park and orders have slowed. 

Also; there have been some reworking of installed turbines on warranty at cost to Vestas, much less than Siemens Energy (Siemens Gamesa), but still a drag. 

Their maintenance revenue is +20% margins and growing in the mix, so that might support the shares at some point... 

But overall credibility is shot for the time being... 

A fall in debt costs would be quite helpful to their customers, but we are getting into second order inflation and the inflation echo. 

Overall... might be two years before things turn around for them.

[13/12/2024, 10:42:59] Nick finegold: Bitcoin just notched another win of sorts. BlackRock, the world‚Äôs biggest asset manager, says the cryptocurrency does have a place in multi-asset portfolios‚Äîto a point, anyway. According to a BlackRock Investment Institute paper released Thursday, giving Bitcoin a 1% to 2% weighting would produce a similar share of profile risk as the Magnificent Seven tech stocks in a standard 60/40 portfolio. That‚Äôs a ‚Äúreasonable range,‚Äù BlackRock proclaimed, as anything beyond 2% would sharply increase crypto‚Äôs share of overall portfolio risk. Bitcoin has been on a high since the election of Donald Trump‚Äîand his subsequent nomination of crypto fan Paul Atkins to be chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission‚Äîsoaring above $100,000. Although BlackRock‚Äôs memo provides a potential blueprint for investors ‚Äúwho are tolerant of Bitcoin‚Äôs risk,‚Äù they nevertheless should remain wary of scams amid the digital currency‚Äôs ongoing boom. Scammers have done exceedingly well for themselves in the past year (about $5.6 billion was lost to crypto fraud in the US last year, according to the FBI), in part because so many investors think crypto is a way to get rich quick‚Äîwhich of course makes them easy marks. ‚ÄîJordan Parker

[14/12/2024, 12:01:12] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Q: I did want to ask about that. Should we view the ASP deal as speculative ‚Äî meaning we're open to options that get us Haleu earlier than 2030 ‚Äî or do you really believe they can build capacity by then?

A: I think that'll be the fastest source. We've done due diligence there. They have the technical capabilities. They have a government lab there, Necsa [the Nuclear Energy Corp. of South Africa]. Necsa and the energy minister are both supportive of South Africa enriching uranium again, and importantly they have full IAEA protocols in place there because enrichment is a sensitive technology.

We're excited about that agreement for two reasons. One is it helped us solve this schedule issue on our first core for Natrium. But beyond that, Bill created the company to bring nuclear energy to places like Africa. So to be working in South Africa, and have our first activity in Africa with a very knowledgeable nuclear nation like South Africa, you can really see how South Africa is just our first step toward eventually deploying Natrium reactors in Africa.

There is probably no more credible source on the planet in the area of nuclear science than Terra power .

Centrus and Silex who are yet to scale Haleu trade at $1bn + valuations.  This statement suggests to me that Aspi has a shot at the same prize although commercialising and scaling HALEU is going to be hugely challenging and there are going to be several facilities being sponsored by the US Governmnent.

[18/12/2024, 23:41:52] Nick finegold: ASP Isotopes Inc. Sued for Securities Law Violations ‚Äì Investors Should Contact The Gross Law Firm Before February 3, 2025 to Discuss Your Rights ‚Äì ASPI
NEW YORK, Dec. 18, 2024 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The Gross Law Firm issues the following notice to shareholders of ASP Isotopes Inc. (NASDAQ: ASPI).
Shareholders who purchased shares of ASPI during the class period listed are encouraged to contact the firm regarding possible lead plaintiff appointment. Appointment as lead plaintiff is not required to partake in any recovery.
CONTACT US HERE:
https://securitiesclasslaw.com/securities/asp-isotopes-inc-loss-submission-form/?id=117025&from=3¬†
CLASS PERIOD: October 30, 2024 to November 26, 2024
ALLEGATIONS: The complaint alleges that during the class period, Defendants issued materially false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that: (1) the Company overstated the potential effectiveness of its enrichment technology; (2) the Company overstated the development potential of its high assay low-enriched uranium facility; (3) the Company overstated the Company‚Äôs nuclear fuels operating segment results; and (4) as a result of the foregoing, defendants‚Äô positive statements about the Company‚Äôs business, operations, and prospects were materially misleading and/or lacked a reasonable basis.
DEADLINE: February 3, 2025 Shareholders should not delay in registering for this class action. Register your information here: https://securitiesclasslaw.com/securities/asp-isotopes-inc-loss-submission-form/?id=117025&from=3¬†
NEXT STEPS FOR SHAREHOLDERS: Once you register as a shareholder who purchased shares of ASPI during the timeframe listed above, you will be enrolled in a portfolio monitoring software to provide you with status updates throughout the lifecycle of the case. The deadline to seek to be a lead plaintiff is February 3, 2025. There is no cost or obligation to you to participate in this case.
WHY GROSS LAW FIRM? The Gross Law Firm is a nationally recognized class action law firm, and our mission is to protect the rights of all investors who have suffered as a result of deceit, fraud, and illegal business practices. The Gross Law Firm is committed to ensuring that companies adhere to responsible business practices and engage in good corporate citizenship. The firm seeks recovery on behalf of investors who incurred losses when false and/or misleading statements or the omission of material information by a company lead to artificial inflation of the company's stock. Attorney advertising. Prior results do not guarantee similar outcomes.
CONTACT:
The Gross Law Firm
15 West 38th Street, 12th floor
New York, NY, 10018
Email: dg@securitiesclasslaw.com¬†
Phone: (646) 453-8903

[19/12/2024, 12:08:16] Nick finegold: Why UnitedHealth Group (UNH) is a Compelling Buy

Driving the news: UnitedHealth Group (UNH), a healthcare titan, faces short-term headwinds, including government scrutiny of PBMs and unexpected challenges like the atrocious murder of a divisional head. Yet, history shows these events often create buying opportunities for long-term investors in this compounder.

Why it matters:
	‚Ä¢	Massive market: The U.S. healthcare sector accounts for a staggering 19% of GDP and is growing.
	‚Ä¢	Demographic tailwinds: The U.S. population is aging rapidly, with those 65+ expected to grow from 58M in 2022 to 82M by 2050‚Äîa 47% increase.
	‚Ä¢	Cost pressures: Healthcare costs in the U.S. are often 50‚Äì200% higher than in other developed countries, driving the need for innovative cost-saving solutions.

By the numbers:
	‚Ä¢	Optum Health: Only serves 4.7M customers out of 340M U.S. residents, highlighting a vast runway for growth.
	‚Ä¢	Optum Insight: Operates with a 21% operating margin and a $35B backlog, or 1.6x 2024 revenues.
	‚Ä¢	Optum RX: Negotiated $85B in drug price savings for 2024, delivering over $2,000 in annual savings per customer.

The big picture: UNH‚Äôs integrated model, anchored by Optum, focuses on value-based care, improving outcomes, and reducing costs. Their investments in technology, home-based care, and data-driven insights position them as a leader in reshaping healthcare delivery.

Investor takeaway:
	‚Ä¢	Growth engine: UNH compounds EPS at 13‚Äì16% annually, yet trades at a modest 12.6x P/E (2027 estimates) with a free cash flow yield of 8.7%.
	‚Ä¢	Low expectations: Consensus estimates just 8% EPS growth for 2025 despite 10% revenue growth‚Äîleaving room for upside surprises.
	‚Ä¢	DCF value: Target price of $830 suggests significant upside from current levels.

Bottom line: With five growth pillars‚Äîvalue-based care, health benefits, tech, financial services, and pharmacy‚ÄîUnitedHealth Group is uniquely positioned to deliver sustainable, compounding returns. The recent weakness offers a rare opportunity to buy a proven compounder at a discount.

[19/12/2024, 14:06:23] Adam Clib: Nick is happy for me to post.

UnitedHealth Group has been mentioned above and appears to be well liked.
It has fallen from c.$600 to $500
Simple structure if you are interested in income / coupon:

Reverse Convertible on UnitedHealth Group
Issuer: Marex 
Currency: USD
Maturity: 24 month
Observation Frequency: semi annual
Barrier:  80%
Coupon 10.23%p.a


I am highlighting this coupon, because it has fallen so much in recent months.
You receive the coupon over the 24 months, semi annually.
At maturity (in 24 months) 100% of your capital is returned if the stock is not more than 20% down. Hence the 80% barrier.
At maturity : If UNH is below the 80% barrier  - the investor receives back the level of UNH ( E.g if its down 25% you receive back 75% of your capital) ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[19/12/2024, 19:49:57] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: https://sprott.com/insights/uranium-markets-impacted-by-market-signals-and-uncertainty/
[19/12/2024, 19:50:05] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: The spot market is dealing with an overhang of supply as some traders look to clear their positions before the year's end. Further pressuring the spot market are rampant rumors the Kazakh ANU physical uranium fund may be liquidating its 2+ million-pound inventory. While Russia‚Äôs retaliatory export ban on enriched uranium to the U.S. pushes utilities‚Äô focus to the nuclear fuel cycle's conversion and enrichment segments, we believe this attention will eventually cascade down to uranium oxide (U3O8). This year's muted term contracting activity, at 100.7 million pounds of U3O8e, was heavily skewed by Chinese contracts with Kazatomprom and increases the likelihood of future contracting, as deferred purchases will eventually need to be addressed. Delaying these purchases risks depleting existing stockpiles, which is an unsustainable scenario from a risk management perspective.

[20/12/2024, 08:26:19] Nick finegold: NIKE - The new CEO‚Äôs banter on the earnings call was excellent and very exciting to listen to , the numbers were a lot less exciting . 

This quarter, revenues were down 8% on a reported basis, and down 9% on a currency-neutral basis, reflecting ongoing headwinds from our franchise management actions. We continue to drive the biggest reductions to our classic footwear franchises on NIKE Direct, which was down 14% with NIKE Digital declining 21% and NIKE Stores declining 2%. Wholesale was down 4%. Gross margins declined 100 basis points to 43.6% on a reported basis, due to higher markdowns on NIKE Direct, wholesale discounts to liquidate inventory and channel mix headwinds, partially offset by lower product costs and strategic pricing actions. SG&A was down 3% on a reported basis. While we increased investment in areas such as sports marketing, this was more than offset by lower wage-related expenses and timing shifts in other demand creation expenses. Earnings per share was $0.78.

[24/12/2024, 08:13:04] Nick finegold: Yes I think LSEG will be a runner next year. If these products are a success they  will be integrated into MS office in time unleashing huge potential disruption and new subscriptions globally  . Ie if a super computer can do to financial services using back data , what Tesla would like to do to cars, autonomous driving and robots you may see a similar reaction in the share price of LSEG which is nicely underpinned by solid fundamentals and not really viewed as an ai stock yet . 

I have seen things beyond my wildest expectations in 2024 with the written word but have yet to see anything that has utterly amazed me in the numerous FS suites to which I subscribe. No doubt it‚Äôs coming and being built inside places like citadel and Bloomberg but 2024 has been about testing in FS and hallucinations in finance can be very expensive so it takes time . 

‚ÄúSearch‚Äù in financial services  is not a subject about which many have spoken . 

What I mean by that is i spend a huge amount of time trying to get from theme to stock and then screen those stocks. 

If one could search an idea for the optimal outcome in seconds it turns Financial Services on its head. 

Ie imagine saying to ChatGPT , give me the worlds purest  play on speeding up connectivity between  data centres and their users in a way that reduces costs , for the service provider and optimises the user experience . Please also screen within that group for the wall streets highest price target and rank accordingly with the cheapest valuations first . 

Also please screen for the management teams with the most successful exits and best track records of delivery over their careers . 

This is what has to be coming and LSEG has to be a front runner in that field. Easier for them to disrupt the space than Bloomberg with all its data locked inside the terminal for the time being . 

The edge risk of course is that someone does a better job with the backseat of data than laser and Microsoft , but they are unlikely to have that type of distribution .

[24/12/2024, 18:31:18] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: This was my favourite Christmas message so far ‚Ä¶
Thankyou Charles D‚Ä¶ 

Happy Christmas, everyone. 

A Norfolk friend writes a Christmas message to all his friends, and I thought I‚Äôd share it with you.   Happy Christmas 2024

Dear People-I-Know,

Having fun? Is life tip-top? Remember, I know you all, which is why you‚Äôre getting GLIM, because I don‚Äôt send it to people I don‚Äôt know. When I look around at you, my friends, I‚Äôd say you are a lucky lot. As am I.
Yes, of course we all have problems‚Äîthe wife, the kids, the job, the mortgage, the cost of hotels in St. Barths, the inability to get a good table at the Chiltern Firehouse, the au pair‚Äôs sexual incontinence, and the difficulty of getting an Uber on a rainy Saturday night. I don‚Äôt mean to belittle any of these things; they can be really annoying.
However, when I look around at you, my friends, I see some of the luckiest people in the world, living their best lives. None of you are short of food or housing, none have been involuntarily put in a uniform like your grandparents, and, best of all, you go where you want, take nice holidays, have access to life-saving medicine, and live in nice places.
When I tell my Martian buddy who drops in from time to time to check up on Planet Earth about you, he sighs and says, ‚ÄúWhat lucky bastards they must be.‚Äù I snort and wipe the tears of laughter from my face. ‚ÄúHow happy they must be!‚Äù he continues, completely oblivious to how awful the world is. They read the news, click on social media, and find themselves submerged in a tide of grievance, bitterness, and vice.
So here‚Äôs my advice: lighten up, look around you, and have a laugh. We should all do our best to make the world a bit happier, even if only a tiny bit. Whether it‚Äôs making a simple difference to climate change or the Ukraine war or a transgender attack or impeachment of Trump, something you do matters.
And yes, the same applies to you, the recipient of this GLIM. I know some of you have had a tough year, and I send you a virtual hug. I suspect the same will be true next year, so keep on smiling.

[30/12/2024, 11:30:26] ~‚ÄØTim: Morning Simon. I do think claim to be an expert on Norwegian shipping, but went to a conference in Oslo a few years ago. My take was most companies spend the cycle cash flow negative with maybe 2 years in 8 actually making money. These 2 years have to get them through the rest. Unfunded dividends most of the time hence the high yields.

When the market tightens they all press the capex button and add supply, sending the operators back underwater. 

Struck me as crazy but I guess there is some econometrics (a beautiful mind, Russell Crow, game theory) reasons behind this.

Like you was very interested in the yields at the time.

LNG space may be different so worth a look!

For those of you thinking about what is really exciting me‚Ä¶.

AI AGENTS: ( expect the likes of Raoul to be all over this in the next few weeks). 
As alot of the larger plays in Digital assets have consolidated, December has been an incredible month for Digital Alpha, but not in the places most are anywhere near. 
A good reason why is that the entire "AI agent" space is just $13bn USD today, in a total crypto market cap of $3.5trn, hence it is just 0.4% of the market
For historical context you have essentially had 5 significant ‚Äúmetas‚Äú in Digital assets / Crypto: Ethereum ICO rush of 2017, DeFi summer of 2020, NFT¬†bananza¬†of 2021, meme mania of 2024.¬†
AI agents will be the meta of 2025, and very few have portfolios prepared accordingly. AI Agents should account for 20%+ of all blockchain user transactions by the end of 2025. The¬†space is currently 0.4% of crypto market cap, I expect it to hit 4%+ in the next 12 months. Best risk/reward I have seen in the 8 years I have been looking at this stuff.¬†
The upcoming key use case for AI agents will be the low hanging¬†fruit applications in DeFi that make trading and investment allocations more seamless, we have already seen projects like ai16z, Vader, DAOS FUN, Photon, aixbt, Almanak, Wayfinder etc. capture significant mindshare. We are approaching an inflection point where crypto trading/fund management performed primarily by AI in a 24/7 playing field, will inevitably outperform human counterparts. This thesis has already been playing out in AI generated memecoins (GOAT, Fartcoin etc.)

The market is currently split into two key categories:¬†
1. The Infrastructure layer (Virtual/GAME, Eliza/ai16z, AI Rig Complex, Zerepy, Heurist etc.)¬†
2. The Agent layer (aixbt, Luna, VaderAI, Sekoia, Freysa, Duck AI etc.)

The Speed of deployment in this sector is key as most digital institutional managers are simply not able to trade the space yet (mandates have not been updated, ICs painfully slow and only a handful of assets listed on CEXs with significant liquidity/volume), the only key fund announcement so far is DWF devoting $20m to this space. [01/01/2025, 01:47:33] ~‚ÄØPaul Sisson: thx Nick as always for making the club a thriving community ‚Ä¶ & for anyone interested attach a short summary of my 2025 stock pick XVIVO .. HNY to you all ‚Ä¶                            What is Xvivo - Swedish Medtech Co, founded 1998, HQ Gothenburg & focussed on organ transplants. IPO‚Äôd 2012, #1 s‚Äôhldr Bure Equity (14%), Fourth AP 9%, Robur 8% & Capital 4%, Co has developed portable storage solutions for all 4 key organs (heart, lung, kidney & liver) that extend survival time when outside the body (Ex vivo).

Since 1st heart transplant in 1967 organs have been held in static cold storage (think coolers) with a survival time of ~4hrs. Xvivo has developed an oxygenated hypothermic (read cold) perfusion technology (aka HOPE) that uses a  nutrition & blood substitute solution to extend organ survival time to 6-12hrs - thats huge & clinical trails also point to reduced transplant risk. See photo below of Xvivo Heart Assist Transport module transporting a deceased 48yr olds heart from French West Indies to Paris on Air France flight in Jan 2024. Donor heart was successfully transplanted to 70 yr old after 12hrs of preservation.

Opportunity ? With just ~160,000 transplants/yr growing 5-7%/yr the World Health Org says this only meets 10% of total need & with just 30% of available donor hearts used for transplants the end result is 17 people in the US die every day waiting for an organ. Best guess is with improved technology the # of transplants can rise to 1m/yr. 

My view - Xvivo has a pioneering technology that will become a new standard of care & with demand for organs 10x higher than supply the demand for machine perfusion should grow significantly. Co has a history of continuous profitable growth, reported a breakout 2Q with Revenue +35%, margins +500bp to 24%, EBITDA 2x, EPS 3x & the stock jumped 25%. These are early days for a new technology that has a huge mkt opportunity & as Xvivo wins more EU & FDA approvals I see many more blowout Q‚Äôs

[01/01/2025, 08:20:13] ~‚ÄØYakov Schleider: Hi how does this compare to the transmedics solution
[01/01/2025, 08:26:39] ~‚ÄØYakov Schleider: Comparison from perplexity AI:
[01/01/2025, 08:26:41] ~‚ÄØYakov Schleider: Certainly! Here‚Äôs the information presented in a column format for easier reading:

### Comparison of XVIVO Perfusion Solutions and TransMedics Systems

**Technology Focus:**  
- **XVIVO Perfusion:** Ex vivo machine perfusion (EVMP) for extended organ preservation and reconditioning.  
- **TransMedics (e.g., OCS):** Portable normothermic perfusion systems for real-time organ viability assessment during transport.  

**Preservation Approach:**  
- **XVIVO Perfusion:** Offers hypothermic and normothermic perfusion options (e.g., Liver Assist, Heart Box).  
- **TransMedics:** Primarily normothermic perfusion, mimicking physiological conditions.  

**Applications:**  
- **XVIVO Perfusion:** Broad range: lungs, heart, liver, kidneys; focuses on reconditioning and marginal donor organ utilization.  
- **TransMedics:** Lungs, heart, liver; emphasizes live monitoring and immediate transplantation.  

**Portability:**  
- **XVIVO Perfusion:** Limited portability for some devices (e.g., Liver Assist).  
- **TransMedics:** Fully portable systems designed for transport.  

**Clinical Benefits:**  
- **XVIVO Perfusion:** Prolonged preservation times, reduced ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI), and expanded donor pool.  
- **TransMedics:** Real-time functional assessment and reduced cold ischemia time.  

**Organ Survival Times:**  
- **XVIVO Perfusion:** Up to 24 hours for livers (hypothermic), ~9 hours for hearts (HOPE).  
- **TransMedics:** Up to 24 hours for lungs (normothermic), ~12 hours for hearts.  

This format allows for a clearer comparison between XVIVO Perfusion and TransMedics systems across various features.

Sources
[01/01/2025, 11:13:02] ~‚ÄØYakov Schleider: Good luck to all!

Below is overview of my entry Implantica

Overview
Implantica is a Medical Technology producer responsible for developing Medical Implants. The Founder and Majority shareholder is Dr Peter Forsell. (Dr. Forsell was the Executive Chairman of Obtech Medical AG ......commercialized the SAGB, an adjustable gastric band to treat obesity that Dr. Forsell developed. The gastric band peaked at 42% market share of all obesity surgery. ) He sold this to johnson and johnson for eur 175 mn (Pre FDA approval) and invested 85 into implantica.
 
The main implant is called RefluxStop, which is used to treat chronic acid reflux. Acid Reflux (formally GERD or LPR) patients typically rely on medicine called PPIs but
1) this is not a prevention measure,
2) are expensive when used for years,
3) don't work for all patients,
4) affect gut health and
5) according to some don't prevent the GERD esophageal cancer risk. 
 
Here is an explanation of PPIs and their shortcomings:
https://youtu.be/cQMWmeChSXc?si=J8rlOmoW5gvjsBCq
 
 
RefluxStop is a two-hour keyhole surgery with few if any side effects. Patients are typically home on the same day. They can exercise within a week. The following interview is an example of how it has completely changed one man's life: 
https://youtu.be/2UAqtCOKnsU?si=zQD-9qPFeWLOiAmC
 
Here is an explanation of RefluxStop Surgery:
https://youtu.be/5l-k9_RehB8?si=Vc2mpANHgDMTjBsY
 
Here is the surgery (not for the squeamish) but it shows how easy it is for the surgeon. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jp8yjp3D3Og&t=5s
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Comparison with Peers
 
The only alternate treatment today is surgery which compresses the oesophagus (Like a LINX surgery) and have multiple complications associated including patients inability to swallow, burp or vomit afterwards...or lift heavy weights. Many people are also not eligible for these surgeries.

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Market Opportunity
 

Burden of gastroesophageal reflux disease in 204 countries and territories, 1990‚Äì2019: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of disease study 2019 | BMC Public Health | Full Text (biomedcentral.com)
  --about seventeen percent of the European population ‚Äì over 127 million people in Europe alone ‚Äì suffer from 17 GERD on a weekly basis.  
 
 
 
 
 

The bottomline here is that 10% of the population have acid reflux. We now have a cheaper and better solution reaching a critical mass in Europe. Three more countries have just begun using the treatment (Spain, Italy and Norway) AND THE NUMBER OF PROCEDURES HAS JUST CROSSED 1000.
 
Financials Overview
 
market Cap of $181 mn
Net Cash Rough $71mn giving an implied EV of $110mn.
 
The Adjusted gross margin on each surgery is 92-95% and sales are growing 50% YoY. The list price is EUR5900 per device.
 
Current cashburn is 6.5mn EUR per quarter.
 
 
 
Compelling Setup:
 
‚Ä¢ I estimate It would take an additional 1100 purchases (surgeries) per quarter to get to breakeven cashflow. I don't think this is a big ask at all and if the company could get to a 1.5% market share of acid reflux surgeries (circa 12000 surgeries per year) we could see this on a 25% fcf yield. Imagine if we get to 5%? 
 
‚Ä¢ Dr Forsell is a 47% shareholder. Nicole Pehrsson bought 42k shares of stock in January.
 
‚Ä¢ FDA submission is pending, they are approaching it in a modular submission and are waiting for feedback on stage 2 of 3.
 
‚Ä¢ CE approval in Europe already achieved and over 1000 surgeries now performed.
 
‚Ä¢ Recently Index inclusion announcement.
 
‚Ä¢ The main delay in the sales cycle is getting the Health Insurers to pay for the surgery which is slowly happening and NHS approval is pending. (decision expected in 2025 from NICE)
 
‚Ä¢ Please see here for the plethora of good news on the name:
‚Ä¢ Press Releases - Implantica
‚Ä¢ 'Revolutionary' device to stop acid reflux given to first patients in UK (ladbible.com)
‚Ä¢ Imperial College Healthcare first NHS Trust to offer innovative new procedure for severe acid reflux | Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust
 
‚Ä¢ Amazing review:
‚Ä¢ Dr. Leonardo Vincenti Opens Dedicated Clinic After he saw one of the national TV interviews, Dr. Leonardo Vincenti, Head of Surgery of the largest hospital specialized in gastroenterology in Italy, the ‚ÄùDe Bellis‚Äù in Castellana Grotte, and Center of excellence in Puglia region, decided to open an outpatient clinic dedicated to RefluxStop‚Ñ¢Ô∏è patients. This was to better manage the high number of requests coming in from local patients and those from neighboring regions. ‚ÄùUnlike traditional surgeries, RefluxStop‚Ñ¢Ô∏è has no side effects such as difficulty swallowing the food bolus, gas bloating, etc.‚Äù said Dr. Vincenti.
 
‚Ä¢ Tender awarded in March in Spain. Likely an additional 30 Surgeries this year. You only need 180 to print sequential 100% YoY growth and I believe that , given the recent media attention, we are likely only one or two quarters away from a significant upwards growth inflection.

There is NO sell side analyst coverage yet in the USA, the company has circa $40 mill in the bank and zero debt.

* NASDAQ listed LTBR is the world leader in new nuclear fuel development;
* Its role in the world‚Äôs existing reactors and in the transition to new reactors, big and small, will be fundamental;
* It addresses all anti-nuclear energy issues too:
    * The fuel operates at 300¬∞C (572¬∞F) rather than 1,300 ¬∞C (2,372¬∞F) which addresses safety concerns;
    * It is useable in the world's 420 existing reactors as well as new small and large reactors being developed;
    * Existing reactors can have their lives extended by 40 to 80 years, as has happened in USA;
    * The fuel can produce 30% more electricity so 30% more revenue, which addresses financial concerns; 
    * The spent fuel cannot be weaponised, which deals with the proliferation issue; and it can be reprocessed, which is hugely relevant for waste management; and
* Their partners in USA are the US Government via Idaho National Labs and independent studies by MIT have confirmed performance.

****Lightbridge technology is patented. An acquisition target for American entities such as Centrus Energy, Westinghouse, GE Hitachi ; and JV or licensing agreements for Orano, Urenco or Framatome.

[08/01/2025, 10:18:18] ~‚ÄØPhilip Donald: Meta‚Äôs Llama 3.1 last summer was trained for 8 weeks on half a billion dollars of Nvidia GPUs. But over the holidays Deepseek, a Chinese hedge fund that has been building its own models, woke everyone up. It released Deepseek 3, which it claims has comparable benchmark scores to GPT4o and Anthropic‚Äôs Claude 3.5 and to have achieved this with perhaps 10% of the training compute of Llama 3.1 (yes - I am simplifying this a great deal). 

There is plenty of skepticism about this, on a number of technical fronts, but it points to how open the field remains: there are no moats, the science is very fluid, we don‚Äôt have a solid sense of the theoretical limits we‚Äôre working within, and the economics could change, a lot.      https://github.com/deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3/blob/main/DeepSeek_V3.pdf

[08/01/2025, 10:23:45] ~‚ÄØPhilip Donald: Here is a list of some of the most useful Ai apps available to us today

General Assistance 
1) Perplexity: AI-powered search engine
2) Anthropic: General chatbot, great for projects
3) ChatGPT: Advanced Voice Mode lets you talk to AI

Get work done
1) Granola - Al notetaker that listens to your meetings
2) Wispr Flow - Al voice dictation speech into text
3) Gamma- make decks, docs, and websites
4) Adobe - summarize and chat with PDFs
5) Lindy - build Al agents to automate your workflows

Build an audience
1) Delphi - AI, text, voice, and video
2) HeyGen - AI Avatars to scale content production
3) Argil (YC S24) - Al avatars for social media videos
4) Overlap (YC S24) - long-form videos into shorts
5) Persona- Al agent builder for creators
6) Captions - Al avatars and video editing

Build a product
1) ùêÇùêÆùê´ùê¨ùê®ùê´ - Al code editor that knows your codebase
2) Replit - Al agents to make apps from natural language
3) ùêÄùêßùê≤ùêÇùê°ùêöùê≠- use any Al model in one place
4) Codeium - Al-powered autocomplete for your code

Get creative
1) ElevenLabs - realistic Al voices
2) Suno- create songs / music from text prompts
3) Midjourney- Al image generation
4) KLING AI - Al video generation
5) krea.ai - Al creative canvas to make images
6) Photoroom - Al image editor, great for product photos

Learn or grow
1) Rosebud - Interactive journal
2) Good Inside - Parenting co-pilot
3) Ada Health - Assessments of medical symptoms
4) Particle - AI news app

Have fun
1) Remix AI - social app for sharing Al images
2) ùêåùêûùê≠ùêö ùêàùê¶ùêöùê†ùê¢ùêßùêû - make Al images in Meta apps

[15/01/2025, 23:32:46] Nick finegold: Hindenberg research disbands . I wonder what will happen to Fuzzy Panda ? 

This is a great read from the founder .
[15/01/2025, 23:33:00] Nick finegold: A Personal Note From Our Founder
As I‚Äôve shared with family, friends and our team since late last year, I have made the decision to disband Hindenburg Research. The plan has been to wind up after we finished the pipeline of ideas we were working on. And as of the last Ponzi cases we just completed and are sharing with regulators, that day is today.

I write this from a place of joy. Building this has been a life‚Äôs dream.

I did not know at the outset if it would be possible to find a fulfilling path. This wasn‚Äôt an easy option, but I was na√Øve to the danger and felt drawn to it magnetically.

When I started this, I doubted I was capable. I didn‚Äôt have a traditional finance background. None of my relatives are in this field. I went to a state school. I‚Äôm not a slick salesperson. I don‚Äôt know any of the right clothes to wear. I can‚Äôt play golf. I‚Äôm not some superhuman that can function on 4 hours of sleep. In most of my jobs I was a good worker but mostly looked over. I had no money when I started‚Äîand after catching 3 lawsuits immediately out of the gate, I quickly had less than no money. I would have failed right at the starting line had it not been for the support of world-class whistleblower lawyer Bryan Wood, who took the cases on despite my lack of financial resources. I had a newborn child and was facing eviction at the time. I was terrified, but knew that if I stayed still I would crumble. The only option I had was to keep moving forward.

It is very easy to succumb to negative thoughts and believe what others think of you, especially when things feel low. But it is possible to shatter all of that. I was passionate about this and I let that carry me forward despite my fears and insecurities.

And then this slowly started to flourish.

One at a time, and without a clear plan, we built a team of 11 incredible people. I hired each of them not because we needed workers, but because when our paths crossed and I could see who they were, I realized it was madness not to bring them on.

They are all smart, focused, and fun to work with. Little to no ego. When you meet them, they are all very nice and polite. But when it comes to this field, they are ruthless assassins, capable of world-class work. Like me, our team didn‚Äôt come from traditional finance backgrounds. My first hire often describes himself as a former bartender. We all have a shared view of the world, a mostly calm exterior, and a similar burning underlying intensity. They are all family to me.

We have all worked extremely hard, with a focus on precision and letting the evidence dictate our words.

Sometimes this meant taking big swings and taking on fights that are much bigger than any of us as individuals. Fraud, corruption, and negativity often seem overwhelming. Early on, a sense of justice was usually elusive. When it happened, it was tremendously fulfilling. It kept us going when we needed it.

And boy did we have an impact, eventually‚Äîmore than I imagined was possible at the outset. Nearly 100 individuals have been charged civilly or criminally by regulators at least in part through our work, including billionaires and oligarchs. We shook some empires that we felt needed shaking.

Over time, people began to see what I hoped we could show‚Äîthat having an impact is possible, no matter who you are.

It has also been rather intense, and at times, all-encompassing. I often wake up from my dreams because I‚Äôve thought of a new investigative thread to pull on in my sleep, or an edit that clarifies a point I didn‚Äôt realize I was troubled by during the day. Or from the general pressure of it all. We are not fearless‚Äîwe just have faith in the truth and hope it leads us down the right path.

I‚Äôm grateful for all of it. We have days of bizarre, hilarious and ridiculous stories and we‚Äôve had a lot of fun amidst the pressure and challenges. It has been the adventure of a lifetime.

So, why disband now? There is not one specific thing‚Äîno particular threat, no health issue, and no big personal issue.

Someone once told me that at a certain point a successful career becomes a selfish act. Early on, I felt I needed to prove some things to myself. I have now finally found some comfort with myself, probably for the first time in my life. I probably could have had it all along had I let myself, but I needed to put myself through a bit of hell first. The intensity and focus has come at the cost of missing a lot of the rest of the world and the people I care about. I now view Hindenburg as a chapter in my life, not a central thing that defines me.

Beyond my own desire for relief, it also feels selfish to keep the knowledge we‚Äôve accumulated trapped within our small team. I have more than enough. In the past several years we‚Äôve been flooded with thousands of messages from many of you asking how we do what we do, or whether you can join the team. I read them all and I‚Äôve been trying to figure out how to respond in a way that can answer everyone‚Äîso over the next 6 months or so I plan to work on a series of materials and videos to open-source every aspect of our model and how we conduct our investigations.

My hope is that after we fully share our process, in a couple years I will get an unsolicited message from someone who reads this (maybe you), who embraces the same passion, learns the craft, and finds the confidence to shed some light on a subject that needs it, despite the obstacles in your way. That would make my day, even if I‚Äôm off trying to learn music or planting a garden or whatever I end up doing next.

For now, I will be focused on making sure everyone on our team lands where they want to be next. Some are going to start their own research firm, which I will strongly and publicly encourage, even as I will have no personal involvement. There are others on our team who are now free agents‚Äîso feel free to reach out to me if you have a need for anyone who is brilliant, focused, and easy to work with, as they all are.

It wasn‚Äôt always obvious to me, but I now view all of this as a love story. To my wife, you have been so patient with me. It has not been easy, to put it mildly, and I am forever grateful that you have sacrificed so much and pushed forward with me. And now, my dear, we get to enjoy it together for as long as this world will let us.

To my family and friends, I‚Äôm sorry for the times I have ignored you while I let my attention be drawn away. I can‚Äôt wait to have more time to share with you together.

Lastly, I want to express how grateful I am to our readers. Your messages of kindness and encouragement through the years have gone a long way to help give us the strength to continue. And it constantly reminds me that the world is filled with good. Thank you for all of it‚ÄîI couldn‚Äôt ask for more. It is all a blessing.

With unfathomable levels of gratitude,

Nate Anderson


(P.S. If you are chasing something you think you want or need, or are doubting whether you are enough, take a minute and give this a listen. It had a big impact on me at a pivotal time.)

[16/01/2025, 05:52:52] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: To name a few‚Ä¶.

Adani Group
Hindenburg‚Äôs most impactful report targeted the Adani Group in January 2023. The allegations of fraud and stock manipulation led to a staggering $150 billion rout in Adani Group stocks. This report shook the Indian conglomerate to its core and sparked widespread debate about corporate governance in India.
Nikola Corporation
In September 2020, Hindenburg published a scathing report on Nikola, an electric vehicle startup. The investigation revealed deceptive practices, including a staged video of a semi-truck rolling downhill to appear self-powered. This report led to significant consequences:
	‚Ä¢	The resignation of Nikola‚Äôs founder, Trevor Milton
	‚Ä¢	Criminal indictment of Milton for securities fraud
	‚Ä¢	Milton‚Äôs conviction on three counts of fraud and a four-year prison sentence
Icahn Enterprises
In 2023, Hindenburg targeted Carl Icahn‚Äôs publicly traded vehicle, Icahn Enterprises. The report accused the company of luring retail investors with unsustainable distributions while concealing the risks associated with Icahn‚Äôs personal margin loans.
Block Inc.
Hindenburg also targeted Block Inc., the financial technology company led by Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey.
Opko Health
In 2017, Hindenburg published a report on Opko Health, uncovering connections to criminal activities and product failures. This led to SEC charges against the company‚Äôs CEO and the company itself for fraud in 2018.
Ebix, Inc.
Hindenburg scrutinized Ebix, a fintech company, in 2022-2023. The report warned of inflated revenue numbers and massive debt load. By December 2023, Ebix filed for bankruptcy, confirming Hindenburg‚Äôs warnings about its financial instability.
Carvana
In its final report on January 2, 2025, Hindenburg accused auto retailer Carvana of accounting irregularities, calling it a ‚Äúfather-son accounting grift for the ages‚Äù.
These cases demonstrate Hindenburg Research‚Äôs significant impact on the financial markets, often leading to regulatory investigations, criminal charges, and substantial market value losses for the targeted companies.

Unlike their earthbound counterparts, space-based solar panels can harvest sunlight continuously, unaffected by seasons, weather or the day/night cycle. Given there is no atmosphere between them and the sun, they are also thought to be around 10 times more efficient at energy collection. The plan is for the array to transmit energy back to the planet‚Äôs surface using microwaves, in theory producing as much energy in a year as the ‚Äútotal quantity of oil that can be extracted from the Earth‚Äù.

Gold vs. Bitcoin Debate

1 Big Thing: Gold reserves vs. Bitcoin reserves
	‚Ä¢	A growing conversation is emerging around the idea of nations reallocating gold reserves to Bitcoin.
	‚Ä¢	Brian Armstrong suggested that countries should hold at least 11% of their gold reserves in Bitcoin, predicting that Bitcoin‚Äôs market cap could surpass gold within the next 5‚Äì10 years.

Why it matters:
	‚Ä¢	Trump has ordered the creation of a cryptocurrency working group, signaling a push for a national cryptocurrency reserve.
	‚Ä¢	With the U.S. already holding 200,000 BTC from seizures, some believe this could evolve into a strategic asset for the country.

The critics:
	‚Ä¢	Skeptics question the strategy, noting that foreign central banks prefer gold as it‚Äôs not U.S.-controlled.
	‚Ä¢	Concerns have been raised about the U.S. ‚Äútalking up‚Äù Bitcoin prices before building its reserves, possibly benefiting insiders.

Zoom in: Gold‚Äôs short-term outlook
	‚Ä¢	Gold positioning:
	‚Ä¢	Futures open interest is at a 2-year high, while speculator net longs are nearing 3-year highs.
	‚Ä¢	Gold‚Äôs RSI stands at 69, signaling it may be overbought.
	‚Ä¢	Seasonal factors: The start of the Chinese New Year may temporarily reduce gold buying demand.
	‚Ä¢	Bearish signals:
	‚Ä¢	A short-term pullback in gold prices is likely, with long bond yields potentially reversing downward.
	‚Ä¢	If the U.S. were to sell gold reserves to buy Bitcoin, prices could drop, but foreign central banks (CBs) would likely buy the dip.

Tactical takes on Bitcoin adoption
	‚Ä¢	Some believe a Bitcoin-as-legal-tender strategy could unlock broader adoption:
	‚Ä¢	Allowing BTC to be lent, borrowed, and held on corporate balance sheets (√† la gold‚Äôs integration).
	‚Ä¢	Ideas like BTC becoming CGT-free have been floated to encourage this transition.

But there‚Äôs skepticism:
	‚Ä¢	Could this push simply be a way to enrich existing Bitcoin holders, including Trump himself?
	‚Ä¢	Michael Saylor predicts Bitcoin could reach $13 million per coin, but some view the current hype as part of a political play.

A shifting dollar and gold‚Äôs old-world allure
	‚Ä¢	Currency moves:
	‚Ä¢	The dollar appears to have topped out and could enter a bear market.
	‚Ä¢	Undervalued currencies like CAD, NOK, JPY, and AUD are catching attention.
	‚Ä¢	The gold vs. crypto debate:
	‚Ä¢	Gold remains a favorite for many in Europe, India, and China, prized for its tangible value over ‚Äútech-fueled greed.‚Äù
	‚Ä¢	Yet, digital assets are pulling focus away from traditional markets.

What‚Äôs next?
	‚Ä¢	Gold247: A Gold Council initiative aims to digitize and modernize gold as a fungible 21st-century asset.
	‚Ä¢	For long-term investors, gold remains a hedge against monetary inflation and central bank-driven erosion of purchasing power.
	‚Ä¢	However, Bitcoin‚Äôs increasing adoption could signal a paradigm shift for reserves worldwide.

Worth noting:
	‚Ä¢	Classic cars, wine, and gold coins remain alternatives to Bitcoin, with gold still CGT-free in the U.K., unlike crypto.
	‚Ä¢	For those diversifying: Consider balance‚Äîgold for stability and Bitcoin for growth.

Stay tuned as these markets evolve, and the lines between traditional and digital assets blur.

[27/01/2025, 17:35:58] Nick finegold: If you use Bill Gates equation  on climate change it‚Äôs quite helpful vs Deepseek. 

PxSxExC=0


P= Population 
S= Services required by the population 
E-= Energy required by the services 
C= Carbon .  
You quickly realise , the Population is not going to zero 

Services required by the population only grows , and is not going zero 

E Energy required by the services is the first time there is good news. This number can and always has the potential to be
Meaningfully reduced.  What deepseek did from an energy perspective is not so different to what an energy saving light bulb does x 1bn homes x 50 bulbs in each home. People are working on ways to save energy in millions of different ways 

The only letter in his equation though that can get you to zero is Carbon.  Ie we still need to decarbonise the planet as California burns and millions die each year through particulate matter in cities z 

Hence nuclear ain‚Äôt going away , it‚Äôs just going to be an even bigger part of the energy mix than we thought that‚Äôs all and we will always live in a madly energy hungry world . 

Wait til we
Plug in 1bn robots and cars , start to desalinate water at scale . 

From a global energy standpoint not a lot has changed.

From what happens to the hypersacalers they will just save a ton more money and staff.

[27/01/2025, 19:05:01] ~‚ÄØPhilip Donald: I always enjoy reading Benedict Evans weekly insights translating silicon valley developments into language I can understand in the Thames Valley‚Ä¶‚Ä¶i have taken the liberty of reproducing this on Crypto‚Ä¶.which resonated with me. Even if I have some how do I stop it being taken from me with no recourse ?‚Ä¶.How do others do it without fear ?‚Ä¶.                    Cryptocurrencies are effectively bearer instruments, which means if you get hacked there‚Äôs no recourse, but a strong part of crypto ideology is that you control your own money. So, Ledger makes a hardware ‚Äòwallet‚Äô device to store your tokens in a secure, uncrackable offline format, with strong encryption, passwords, etc etc...

However, this week a criminal gang kidnapped the co-founder of Ledger itself, with his wife, and cut off his finger in an attempt to extract a ransom, before the French police rescued him. There‚Äôs long been a saying in cryptocurrency security circles that no amount of clever software is proof against someone hitting you with a wrench until you give them the password, but this made that very real. [29/01/2025, 00:36:02] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: FWIW I think (1) AI long game and a lot of capital will be allocated well, a lot of capital will be wasted. The race is to pick the winners. (2) Current narrative/pricing implies some winners are nearly given. (3) Some have monopoly (asml), others very big lead (nvda, tsmc), others apparent oligopoly (OpenAI, Anthropic, hyperscalers) (4) $6m is misleading but also not the point - if deepseek said they'd spent 6bn it would still challenge the current narrative (5) "they have GPUs they are not supposed to have" is a legalistic argument that ignores the reality that GPUs are a commodity, a previous one but a commodity - you can't smuggle an asml machine but GPUs move around the world with a little more difficulty than Russian oil. [31/01/2025, 15:30:43] Nick finegold: Very good run down from Jonny on why golds breaking new highs when it looks like it should pull back temporarily.
[31/01/2025, 15:30:47] Nick finegold: Dear All,

There are some interesting dynamics playing out in gold mkts now which have been gained some attention in the press. I felt it important enough to give you our perspective on it.

Much ado About Something.
 
Since the November Trump Victory, 400 Metric tons of physical gold has left London for the NY COMEX
This has resulted in a 70% increase of COMEX stockpile of gold (29.8M ounces)
Headlines ascribe this move to fear of tariff on gold imports
Headlines also ascribe this move to an arbitrage play between the UK gold spot price and the NY-based futures price (London is known for making the phys gold spot price; NY is known for the futures contracts)
The view at VON GREYERZ is that post Basel 3, banks and COMEX need more allocated/physical gold to comply with Basel Regs
Bullion Banks linked to COMEX are also openly allowed to artificially price fix (extended shorts) the gold price via daily (and massively levered) shorts against gold (short contracts are backed by 4% actual gold and 96% paper leverage)
Typically COMEX could play this short-game for decades because gold on the COMEX stayed on the COMEX as every futures contract was simply rolled over. 
BUT NOW THE GAME HAS CHANGED: Players on the COMEX are no longer rolling over their contracts, but asking for PHYSICAL DELIVERY of the gold (this is called ‚ÄúOpen Interest‚Äù and its up 750%)
WHY are they seeking physical delivery? Because they prefer real gold over UST‚Äôs for all the obvious reasons‚Ä¶
What does this mean for gold? Well, now the COMEX is worrying about if it will have enough gold to continue its perma-short on gold. Less artificial (but legal) gold shorting means a rising gold price
The UK, meanwhile, has less gold on its books now to lease/lend against gold, which means the premium for gold will go higher and the UK‚Äôs traditional role as gold-lease-lend player is weakening
In short, gold demand is rising and gold supply (in the banks, COMEX etc) is tightening‚Äîall good for gold.
And all boils down to less interest trust in sovereign debt and debased fiat‚Äîall part of our gold story at VON GREYERZ for years‚Ä¶

I hope this perspective is helpful and I remain at your disposition for any questions you may have.

Wishing you a fine weekend.

Best
Jonny
 
Jonny Haycock
Partner
 
VON GREYERZ AG
Bahnhofstrasse 43
CH-8001 Zurich

[01/02/2025, 11:03:57] ~‚ÄØAndrew Draycott: Indian budget today

Significant fiscal stimulus announced.


The Finance Minister certainly kept the biggest surprise for last‚Äîannouncing zero income tax for individuals earning up to INR 12,00,000 per year. This is a game-changer. To put it in perspective, here in the UK‚Äîwhere the cost of living is nearly five times higher on a PPP basis‚Äîthe tax-free allowance is roughly the same on an absolute basis at GBP 12k!

It seems the market and analysts haven‚Äôt fully absorbed the impact yet, as reflected in the erratic stock movements. But I see this as a masterstroke to fuel consumption, particularly discretionary spending. Imagine a young couple in a Tier 2 city earning a combined INR 24,00,000 (~USD28k) annually, with every rupee available for spending or saving. I would guess over 75% of salaried inviduals will be below this threshold and now pay nothing in taxes (legally).

[01/02/2025, 11:29:12] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: So, putting aside any response from the target countries, this is indeed inflationary but not in a way that a tighter Fed policy can control. Trying to think how this differs from e.g. a selective VAT rate (or whatever they call it) increase and seems equivalent to me. The response of the economy ranges between (a) no fall in unit consumption -> v inflationary (b) no increase in $ spending -> unit contraction. In reality somewhere in between so some inflation and some contraction, with the cash going to the Treasury. The contractionary effect of the price rises probably outweighs any Fed action. In any case, Fed is prob stuck... To be clear, I am not suggesting recession, just lower growth (and higher prices). Ofc we don't know what else follows, either by Can/Mex/CH, or by the US gov. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[01/02/2025, 12:42:21] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: Mexico I understand have so far signalled willingness to cooperate. But ofc if they are going to get hit anyway, response may change.
[01/02/2025, 13:12:57] ~‚ÄØTom Wiggin: Simpleton view :  if tariffs cause a spike in product price (to the consumer) for product derived from a single market (in this case CN and MX),  then that same product from another source does not necessarily increase in price until such time that demand causes it to.  So in this case, food and oil accessibility/availability from elsewhere will decide size of the inflationary effect.  Bad news for the producer suffering the tariff,  good news for the producer who doesn‚Äôt (who presumably was delivering a more expensive product in the 1st place).  Net net = price inflation for sure but not necessarily severe and not necessarily instant.
[01/02/2025, 13:16:38] ~‚ÄØTom Wiggin: I suspect Trump math says that the alternative producer is or could be good ole America - and therefore may see his policy as a perverse form of  potential growth stimulus.
[01/02/2025, 13:25:27] ~‚ÄØZac Bobolakis: Yes, agreed, outcome likely somewhere in-between. Substitution depends on availability and whether like for like. Eg Canadian crude v different to US/other crude so refineries in the US  who process Can oil will have issues. Onshoring obv growth positive but takes time. The intertemporal frictions and risks...
