[01/02/2025, 16:59:27] Nick finegold: I fed all of todays comments into chat GPT and asked it for its opinion on the impact of tariffs based on your comments but it could ingest millions of data points 

. I am sure it has occurred to you all that this technology can predict a more accurate vision of the economy and how to manage it ? Reducing the number of economists in the world . 

No industry is going to suffer more change than asset management . 

Here is its answer or all of yours neatly summarised . 

In my view, U.S. tariffs on key trade partners like Mexico and Canada will almost certainly result in short-term inflation. However, the longer-term consequences depend on several factors: the availability of alternative suppliers, the resilience of supply chains, and how long these tariffs remain in place.

Here‚Äôs how I see the key points:

1. Initial Inflation Spike
	‚Ä¢	With tariffs on 30% of U.S. imports, particularly food and oil, prices will increase. These sectors affect both consumers directly (groceries, fuel) and indirectly (transportation, manufacturing costs).
	‚Ä¢	Since food and energy prices are major components of headline inflation, the tariffs will drive inflation up temporarily.

2. Limited Ability to Substitute
	‚Ä¢	Mexico and Canada are key suppliers because of proximity and established supply chains. Alternatives‚Äîeither domestic or from other countries‚Äîare unlikely to fully meet demand quickly.
	‚Ä¢	For example, U.S. refineries optimized for Canadian crude may face higher costs adapting to other sources of oil. Similarly, perishable food products from other countries may face logistical challenges.

3. Fed Response
	‚Ä¢	I doubt the Federal Reserve will immediately raise rates. The Fed typically views tariff-driven inflation as a ‚Äúsupply shock,‚Äù which does not require monetary tightening unless it becomes entrenched.
	‚Ä¢	However, if tariffs persist for a year or longer, inflation expectations could shift upward. In that case, the Fed may face pressure to act, complicating any plans to cut rates to stimulate growth.

4. Economic Cooling Effect
	‚Ä¢	Tariffs act like a tax increase. As prices rise, consumers may reduce spending, especially on discretionary goods. Businesses facing higher input costs might cut investments or lay off workers.
	‚Ä¢	This demand reduction could partially offset inflationary pressures but at the cost of slower economic growth. I expect GDP growth to slow, though not necessarily enter a full recession unless other shocks occur (e.g., retaliatory tariffs).

5. Trump‚Äôs Strategy and Risk
	‚Ä¢	I agree with the speculation that Trump sees tariffs as a negotiating tactic. If Mexico and Canada comply quickly, he may lift tariffs, minimizing long-term damage.
	‚Ä¢	The risk is that this approach underestimates how long negotiations might take or how resistant these countries could be, particularly if domestic politics in Mexico or Canada prevent quick concessions. If tariffs last longer than expected, both inflation and supply chain disruptions will intensify.

6. Market Complacency
	‚Ä¢	Markets do seem under-prepared for the potential fallout. There may be assumptions that tariffs will be short-lived or that substitutes will emerge quickly. However, as seen with other trade conflicts (e.g., U.S.-China), disruptions can last longer and be more impactful than anticipated.
	‚Ä¢	Investors should be cautious, particularly in sectors reliant on trade with Mexico and Canada. Companies in these industries may face higher costs and earnings pressure.

Summary:
I believe the tariffs will cause a temporary but sharp inflation spike. If negotiations drag on, we could see both inflation and slower growth. The Fed might initially hold rates steady, but prolonged tariffs could force it into a difficult position. Markets and businesses should prepare for heightened uncertainty, as the complexities of global supply chains cannot be quickly untangled. This is a significant risk that should not be underestimated.

[05/02/2025, 15:08:10] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Still recommend ‚Äúart of the deal‚Äù. Unless you have read you cant begin to even comprehend‚Ä¶

UNDERSTANDING TRUMP: 
Trump sees all dealmaking as what you might call "distributive bargaining." Distributive bargaining always has a winner and a loser. It happens when there is a fixed quantity of something and two sides are fighting over how it gets distributed. Think of it as a pie and you're fighting over who gets how many pieces. 
The other type of bargaining is called ‚Äúintegrative bargaining‚Äù. In integrative bargaining the two sides don't have a complete conflict of interest, and it is possible to reach mutually beneficial agreements. Think of it, not a single pie to be divided by two hungry people, but as a baker and a caterer negotiating over how many pies will be baked at what prices, and the nature of their ongoing relationship after this one gig is over.
[05/02/2025, 15:09:41] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: https://www.reuters.com/world/us/wright-draws-enough-senate-votes-become-us-energy-secretary-2025-02-03/

that requires more than $100 billion a year in cap ex and buybacks, might be worth 12 or 14 times earnings. It
isnt worth 25x. Last year, Google spent $52 billion on capital investments. As you can see, that‚Äôs a major
portion of the money it made (more than 50%!) If you look at real ‚Äúcosts‚Äù of Google‚Äôs business they wouldn‚Äôt
have made $100 billion last year they would have lost $14 billion. (Expensing investments and costs associated
with Option dilution etc) Judging Google on an after-capital investments basis would leave you with a paltry
14% ROE, consider that vs Peers. Never forget: US accounting standards were originally developed for the the
Pennsylvania Railroad, where capital investments in new tracks, new stations, and new bridges (150 years
ago!) would in fact be used profitably for decades, pron not the case with Nvidia chips! If these tech upgrades
were treated as expenses, then Google‚Äôs business would look a lot different: Google would have made less
than half as much money last year ‚Äì only $48 billion on sales of $350 billion (rather than $100 billion), for a net
income margin of only 13%.
There's honestly no reason to pay 25x earnings for a business everyone is so universally bullish on, (how many
Sell ratings?!) funnelling 70% of cash flow into a capex blackhole. It wasn't long ago that META traded down to
9x earnings when it went through the same debacle with the metaverse. SAMSUNG is at 10X vs GOOGL @25 X.
(that said was THE buying point for META!) Now it may be stretching things a little, but to drill a lateral, ‚Äúairlines: we
can increase our production while spending all our earnings and our stocks will go up right?‚Äù interesting chart
(tx bbg and thankyou the Madeira Group!)

[09/02/2025, 12:06:09] Nick finegold: Ok it‚Äôs superbowl day and having named my fourth child Jet after the most losing  franchise in NFL history , my advice is do the opposite of whatever I suggest . 
It‚Äôs a tough one to call , my heart is with the Eagles . 

Super Bowl Rundown ‚Äì Investment Club Edition

Too Close to Call

This year‚Äôs Super Bowl is a razor-thin matchup. Let‚Äôs break it down by strengths and weaknesses for both teams.

The Eagles ‚Äì The All-Round Machine

The Eagles are a better-balanced team across almost every metric:
	‚Ä¢	Offensive Line: Dominant protection and run blocking.
	‚Ä¢	Wide Receivers: Outclassing the Chiefs‚Äô unit.
	‚Ä¢	Running Game: Headlined by Barkley, they‚Äôre far superior.
	‚Ä¢	Secondary: A solid unit capable of handling opposing passing attacks.

The Problem? The Chiefs still have three world-class factors in their favor:
	1.	Patrick Mahomes: Arguably the best quarterback in the game.
	2.	Andy Reid: A mastermind coach (and former Eagles coach), who‚Äôll be desperate to beat his old team.
	3.	Steve Spagnuolo: A defensive coordinator with a reputation for stepping up in big games.

Chiefs: Strengths and Weaknesses
	‚Ä¢	Chiefs have benefited from facing weaker opponents this year, often with injured offensive lines.
	‚Ä¢	Their defense might be overrated, having looked stronger than it really is against those weaker teams.
	‚Ä¢	Turnovers: Eagles are 20-2 in turnover ratio over the last six games. Will they keep that up?
	‚Ä¢	Mahomes Playoff Record: 8-0 as either an underdog or with a small (-3 or less) spread.

Other Key Trends:
	‚Ä¢	Chiefs have appeared in four recent Super Bowls and have never led at halftime‚Äîyet they‚Äôve won three of them.
	‚Ä¢	Eagles may control time of possession, which could keep Mahomes off the field for long stretches.

Betting Insights

I‚Äôll be keeping stakes lower than usual since‚Ä¶
Fact: My Super Bowl betting record is very poor.

However, here are some trends and opportunities to watch:
	‚Ä¢	Teams that scored 40+ points in the conference final: Just 3-7 in Super Bowls.
	‚Ä¢	Team scoring last: Has won the last 18 straight Super Bowls.

Best Value Bet

Halftime/Full-Time Bet:
	‚Ä¢	Eagles to lead at halftime, Chiefs to win full-time at 11-2 odds. This bet plays off the Chiefs‚Äô history of second-half comebacks and their slow starts in recent Super Bowls.

Let‚Äôs see how this wild matchup plays out! ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[12/02/2025, 11:32:13] ~‚ÄØMatt H: Barrick results out. They look poor.
[12/02/2025, 11:40:54] Nick finegold: For those interested . 

TORONTO, Feb. 12, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Barrick Gold Corporation (GOLD)(TSX:ABX) delivered a strong performance in Q4, increasing gold production by 15% and copper production by 33% over Q3 to meet its annual guidance for the year. Additionally, gold cost of sales1 and total cash costs2 for the quarter were reduced by 3% and 5%, respectively.

The results for the year, released today, report a 69% increase in net earnings to $2.14 billion, a 51% increase in adjusted net earnings3 to $2.21 billion and a 30% rise in attributable EBITDA4 to $5.19 billion for 2024 ‚Äî the highest in over a decade. Year-on-year operating cash flow increased 20% to $4.49 billion and free cash flow5 more than doubled to $1.32 billion, driven by the stronger earnings. A quarterly dividend of $0.10 per share was maintained, bringing the total annual dividend paid to shareholders to $696 million, and a further $498 million was returned in buying back shares.

[13/02/2025, 07:30:49] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Thx Ben I think it dovetails with this ‚Ä¶

‚ÄúOn other side of all this early-stage Digital Asset Tokenisation stuff CONSIDER THIS‚Ä¶

I/we believe a Venture Capital Apocalypse is coming...it might even be here already. (Tx carriednointerest)
The venture capital asset class is facing a watershed moment. Orphaned & Zombie VC software companies are
everywhere. 1) VCs invested in businesses at lofty valuations. 2) VC. backed software acquisitions are
plummeting. 3) Down rounds are sky rocketing
All of this results in VCs not distributing much to LPs. So, where do we go from here?
1) Many VCs will likely shut down. 2) I think the top VC funds will be fine. There will always be generational
businesses founded every year. Top VCs will get the pick of the litter. They will downsize AUM. 3) Overall LP
allocation to VC will likely go down. 4) There will be many 'orphaned' VC backed software companies that
don't have a path forward in the new environment.

[14/02/2025, 18:59:46] ~‚ÄØJB: TSMC Considers Operating US Intel Factories After Trump Request

Summary by Bloomberg AI
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. is considering taking a controlling stake in Intel Corp.'s factories at the request of Trump administration officials.
The intended result would have TSMC fully operating Intel's US semiconductor factories, addressing concerns about Intel's financial state.
The arrangement may involve major American chip designers taking equity stakes, along with support from the US government, to ensure the venture isn't solely owned by a foreign company.
By Mackenzie Hawkins and Ian King
02/14/2025 18:54:20 [BN]
(Bloomberg) -- Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. is considering taking a controlling stake in Intel Corp.‚Äôs factories at the request of Trump administration officials, a person familiar with the matter said, as the president looks to boost American manufacturing and maintain US leadership in critical technologies. 

Trump‚Äôs team raised the idea of a deal between the two companies in recent meetings with officials from the Taiwanese chipmaker, the person said, and TSMC was receptive. It‚Äôs unclear whether Intel is open to a transaction.

[19/02/2025, 17:50:14] Nick finegold: Thanks Mark. I think you would probably have to look at an unchanged term price rather than a spot market that‚Äôs terribly thin and almost incomprehensible but it‚Äôs a well made point .
[19/02/2025, 18:03:30] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: The disparity between spot and term is now become so great that it seems impossible we do not see a pick up in the carry trade. This disparity has to close and all the indications I can see are that term prices are only heading in one direction, so it will be spot that has to rise not term that has to fall.

In terms of upcoming catalysts, I think geopolitics will continue to provide meaningful support. A recoup between the US and Russia could be positive for two reasons:

1. It would free up some conversion capacity which will get utilities into the contracting market for U3O8 as there is now conversion capacity to sell into. There is no point in contracting U3O8 unless you can get it over to a conversion facility ASAP or else you just start to pay storage fees.

2. Potential for downblending of HEU could be a MASSIVE demand driver for U3O8. The megatons to megawatts program that you will be familiar with downblended HEU (90% enriched uranium) using A LOT of U3O8 (0.7% enriched uranium). Think about it like making Ribena. Downblending HEU (ribena concentrate) to LEU (drinkwable ribena) requires mixing HEU with U3O8 (water). Specififcally, megatons to megawatts required 150,000 tonnes over 2 decades of U3O8 to downblend HEU.

In January, 17m lbs was contracted in the term market so a very strong start to the year. In other words utilities are contracting, it‚Äôs just not being felt in spot prices at all. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[21/02/2025, 13:15:17] Nick finegold: Roche Reveals First Details of Its Nanopore-Based NGS Platform

Why it matters:

Roche has finally provided concrete details on its nanopore-based next-gen sequencing (NGS) platform, a move that could shake up the sequencing market. 

While it won‚Äôt commercially launch until 2026, the new platform could pose a challenge to Oxford NanoporeTechnologies (ONT)‚Äîthough ONT still holds key advantages in long-read sequencing.

The big picture:

Roche‚Äôs platform integrates:
	‚Ä¢	SBX chemistry from Stratos Genomics (acquired in 2020).
	‚Ä¢	Hardware from Genia (acquired in 2014).

Unlike ONT, Roche‚Äôs system lacks long-read sequencing capabilities‚Äîa critical feature that has set ONT apart. However, Roche‚Äôs use of nanopore technology could still impact sentiment toward ONT in the short term.

Between the lines:
	‚Ä¢	Roche‚Äôs system delivers Q20+ sequencing at >1,000 bp read lengths (simplex mode)‚Äîslightly longer than Illumina but far from ONT‚Äôs ultra-long reads.
	‚Ä¢	A duplex mode claims Q39 base accuracy with >99.3% raw read accuracy, making it a highly competitive offering.
	‚Ä¢	Real-time base calling and near-real-time mapping/alignment bring the system closer to ONT‚Äôs flexibility.
	‚Ä¢	Reusability: Roche hints at a ‚Äúcost-effective‚Äù reusable sensor, though pricing remains unknown.
	‚Ä¢	Future potential: The company suggests direct epigenetic modification detection could be integrated later, aligning with ONT‚Äôs roadmap.

The bottom line:

For now, ONT retains its long-read advantage, reinforcing its niche. Roche‚Äôs approach signals that short-read sequencing still dominates the market, and the company has yet to develop a long-read chemistry to compete directly with ONT.

What‚Äôs next:
	‚Ä¢	2024: Roche expands its early access program.
	‚Ä¢	2026: Initial research-use-only launch of the SBX platform.
	‚Ä¢	Clinical version to follow.
	‚Ä¢	Pricing remains a wild card‚Äîif Roche undercuts ONT and gets closer to Illumina‚Äôs pricing, the competition could intensify.


I will speak to the company but my best guess is that having Roche breathing down their neck forces Nanopore into the arms of someone much much bigger .

In another way it‚Äôs a validation of the magnitude of the opportunity but clearly the market has little interest in taking that view . 

Not launched this year , and ONT still clearly technologically superior , but at least it explains the recent price movement .

Key Takeaways:
	‚Ä¢	Strong Growth: Core revenue up 50% YoY, driven by 46% growth in core insurance revenue.
	‚Ä¢	EBITDA Expansion: Adj. EBITDA at ‚Çπ1.14bn, margins expanded ~200bps to 15%.
	‚Ä¢	Premium Growth Resilient: Core online premiums up 42% YoY, renewal premiums +41% YoY.
	‚Ä¢	Margin Concerns Temporary: EBITDA margins dipped ~200bps, mainly from operating leverage & underutilization of teams, but expected to improve.
	‚Ä¢	New Initiatives Impacting Margins: Contributed 87% YoY revenue growth, but weighed on margins; expected to normalize by FY26.
	‚Ä¢	Positive Outlook: Management reaffirmed ‚Çπ10bn PAT target for FY27, with incremental margin gains expected.

Investment View:
	‚Ä¢	Dominant Position, Large TAM, and High Growth Potential.
	‚Ä¢	Valuation: Trading at PE of 49x FY26 EPS, reaffirming BUY with ‚Çπ220 price target (+21% upside).

[28/02/2025, 11:32:21] Nick finegold: It‚Äôs not simple but you can buy them if you set up with interactive brokers and Saxo bank according to ChatGPT . 

As a UK citizen, buying Indian stocks involves a few steps due to local regulations and foreign investment restrictions. Here‚Äôs how you can invest in Indian equities from the UK:

1. Investing via Foreign Portfolio Investor (FPI) Route (For Institutional or HNW Investors)
	‚Ä¢	The FPI route allows foreign investors to trade Indian stocks directly on the NSE (National Stock Exchange) or BSE (Bombay Stock Exchange).
	‚Ä¢	However, this requires registration with SEBI (India‚Äôs financial regulator), which is typically for institutions or high-net-worth individuals.
	‚Ä¢	You must go through an SEBI-registered custodian or a Participatory Notes (P-Notes) issuer.

Not ideal for retail investors.

2. Investing via an International Broker with Indian Market Access

Some international brokers allow direct investment in Indian stocks. These include:
	‚Ä¢	Interactive Brokers ‚Äì Offers access to the NSE and BSE.
	‚Ä¢	Saxo Bank ‚Äì Allows investment in select Indian companies.
	‚Ä¢	Winvesta ‚Äì Provides fractional investing in some Indian stocks via ADRs (American Depository Receipts).

üí° Action: Check with these platforms if they support direct investments in Indian equities.

3. Investing via Indian Mutual Funds & ETFs (Easiest Way)
	‚Ä¢	UK brokers like Hargreaves Lansdown, AJ Bell, or Interactive Brokers offer access to Indian mutual funds and ETFs.
	‚Ä¢	Popular India-focused ETFs include:
	‚Ä¢	iShares MSCI India ETF (INDA)
	‚Ä¢	Lyxor MSCI India ETF
	‚Ä¢	WisdomTree India Earnings ETF (EPI)

üí° Pros: Simple, cost-effective, no need for an Indian trading account.

4. Investing via ADRs & GDRs (Indirect Exposure)
	‚Ä¢	Some Indian companies list ADRs (American Depositary Receipts) on U.S. exchanges or GDRs (Global Depositary Receipts) in Europe.
	‚Ä¢	Examples include:
	‚Ä¢	Infosys (INFY)
	‚Ä¢	HDFC Bank (HDB)
	‚Ä¢	Tata Motors (TTM)

üí° Trade these via UK brokers that offer U.S. or European stock access.

5. Opening an Indian Trading & Demat Account (For Direct Investing)

If you want full access to Indian stocks, you must:
	1.	Open an NRE/NRO Bank Account (for repatriable/non-repatriable investments).
	2.	Register for a PIS (Portfolio Investment Scheme) Account via an Indian bank (ICICI, HDFC, SBI).
	3.	Open a Demat & Trading Account with an Indian broker (Zerodha, ICICI Direct, Kotak Securities).
	4.	Convert GBP to INR and fund the account.

üí° Most complex route but allows direct stock ownership.

Final Thoughts ‚Äì What‚Äôs the Best Route?

‚úÖ Easiest: Buy India ETFs/mutual funds via UK brokers.
‚úÖ Best for stock picking: Use Interactive Brokers or look at ADRs/GDRs.
‚úÖ For direct Indian stock trading: Open an NRE/NRO account + Demat account with an Indian broker.

It‚Äôs hard situation because 50% of installed military hardware is Russian. But also worth noting india is <1% of global manufacturing whilst China is >25% so dumping is hard to allege. They are looking to lower tariffs in high end cars (concession to musk? Where previously they insisted that companies manufacture on shore to evade). The area that could be hit is services (they are 8% of services exports globally) and that could hurt IT services like infosys and Tata Consultancy

[03/03/2025, 11:03:38] ~‚ÄØJim: Developing rare earth projects in Ukraine in the foreseeable future is complete "fiction," with hurdles ranging from uncertainty over reserves to a lack of processing capacity outside of China, industry veterans say, with one expert describing U.S. President Donald Trump's plan to recoup war aid by exploiting the partially occupied country's natural resources as "absurd‚Äù‚Ä¶..

Experts are very skeptical, particularly about rare earth elements (REE), with doubts that Ukraine even has viable deposits to mine, as claims of reserves are based on exploration done during the Soviet era.

"There are no known rare earth deposits in the Ukraine, period," said John Mavrogenes, a professor of economic geology at the Australian National University, calling the claim "fiction" and the proposal "absurd."

"I assume that these people talking about it don't know the difference between a rare earth and any other critical mineral," he added. (Source: asia.nikkei.com)

The curated summary : it‚Äôs temporary , gold hasn‚Äôt been targeted by tarrifs and the market can cope .

More simply, I think that in the current macro environment, (with a weaker $ , an unpredictable stock market and interest rates likely to fall)  , global asset allocators who have been underweight for years must be starting to think about upping their weightings, in spite of  Golds great performance.

[14/03/2025, 15:14:22] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: A TALE OF 2 OXFORDS. (. Repeat of this from a few mths back)‚Ä¶
( I defer to Nick F & Curation on OXFORD NANOPORE ONT LN a  ‚ÄúBuy it before someone else does‚Äù story‚Ä¶) 

On OXFORD BIOMEDICA / OXB LN this is much less well known than OXFORD NANOPORE and is still 1/3rd size so much smaller and it trades on 1.3 X sales for 35% growth. 
OXB is the world leader in making ‚ÄúLentivector technology‚Äù and has never lost a customer - ever. Simply put, a type of vector (delivery mechanism) for the largest payloads in cell and gene therapy and the fastest growing type of vector in the world right now . This is essential for treating many types of cancer and single gene defect diseases such as Sickle cell disease and Cystic Fibrosis.
There are companies in this space trading at 5X with zero growth. 
OXB is just transitioning to profitability and they should make a small profit this year but a significant one next and then accelerate going forward. The restructuring of the business is also saving an est ¬£30 million a year from the bottom line! 
OXB LN is currently @2X sales growing at 35% CAGR. I think should be at 5-7X which is where CDMO co‚Äôs trade which equals a share price of ¬£7.50 vs ¬£2.88 today. 
Many may ask why so weak recently, well there has been a key huge seller that came about from a large Asset Management M&A and consequential funds restructuring. Thats now seemingly passed!

‚Äé[22/03/2025, 12:03:51] ~‚ÄØJacco Reijtenbagh: ‚Äéimage omitted
[22/03/2025, 12:15:31] Nick finegold: Gary Paulin in this group writes a wonderful newsletter and talks about this today .
[22/03/2025, 12:16:12] Nick finegold: This is what he wrote but it suggests that commodities will do well and if they do well copper is a big winner . 

Supercycle
 
 	
Now, as you know, commodity prices move in long, sweeping cycles of boom and bust, hence the term ‚Äòsupercycles‚Äô. The last one, after China entered the WTO, ended in 2012, since when the sector‚Äôs suffered from chronic underinvestment, capital constraint, nimbyism and ESG. We now have ‚Äònational security‚Äô trumping ESG and nimbyism. We have rearmament in Europe and Japan, reconstruction hopefully to come in Ukraine, and reshoring in the US. All are commodity-intensive endeavors.

So too is energy transition (the largest construction project on the planet), space activity (the largest outside the planet), AI capex and it seems even China ‚Äì the largest consumer of commodities ‚Äì is showing signs of recovery. More about her in a second...
 
 	
Scarcity
 
 	
But my favourite narrative remains that of Scarcity (with a little mean reversion thrown in for measure). You may remember last year we wrote of the mean-reversion potential of the transition from the ‚Äòethereal‚Äô world (that of ideas/IP) to the material world (things). It was a disaster of a call (for now, mea culpa). Our premise was that scarcity ‚Äì and therefore value ‚Äì for technology lies not solely in IP but in the supply chain, the ‚Äòmaterial world‚Äô, that underlies it.

As Ed Conway illustrated in his must read, Material World, this ‚Äòworld‚Äô is mission-critical to our tech-promised future, perhaps more now than ever. As we said at the time: ‚Äú...without sand, no silicon. No silicon no glass, no covid vaccines, no iPhone. No silver no solar. No salt, no sanitation, no drinking water. No copper, no electricity‚Äù. More pressing today: no titanium, (a coincidence that Ukraine holds a fifth of the world‚Äôs reserves?), no F35 fighter jets. No niobium, no missiles, no rockets, no winning the space race.

My question is: what does Trump see (in Ukraine, Greenland, Canada, Panama and DRC) that the market cannot? Answer: rare, yet critical materials. While governments clearly see value and prepared to pursue these rare minerals, I can still find exposures on single digit PEs with huge dividends in regions that are mostly ignored. I suspect Kiril Sokoloff‚Äôs observation still holds, that: ‚Äú...you could buy the top 100 miners, three years of copper production and all seaborne iron-ore with the market cap of Nvidia‚Äù.

America‚Äôs proposed Sovereign Wealth Fund should take note!
 
 	
China recovering? 
 
 	
As discussed already, don‚Äôt fight the command of a command economy. If China wants stocks up, she will probably get her way. It‚Äôs often as simple as that. And does she (want stocks up)? Yes. And property prices. Why? Because they represent system collateral. If your end game is to raise domestic consumption, then fixing the housing market will fix collateral, confidence and ultimately consumption. It may unlock the enormous savings potential, estimated to be c40% of GDP (with arguably post-Covid revenge spending still to come in China!).

If this sounds familiar, it was the playbook the US used to recover after the GFC. The most important signal to watch, therefore, is Chinese property data, which has stabilised, as has its market proxy, the SHProp Index. Should this now start to rally, I suspect it will inspire even greater confidence in the broader equity market. And commodities. Why? It‚Äôs their biggest market.
 
 	
Should old correlations hold again?
 
 	
Seeing as we are on the topic of mean reversion, a reminder of where things stood for gold (and silver) historically. Yes, gold has made new all-time highs, but should it get back to the market value of US official gold to 1989 levels relative to foreign-held USTs, it would need to at least double again. With regards to silver, the gold-to-silver ratio has averaged about 60x since the 1970s. It‚Äôs now at 90x, a historically high. What if old correlations hold? Got gold? Got commodities?

However there is substantial value in the mining equities and the next commodity bull will be augmented by additional demand for industrial metals and energy needed for re-building of Ukraine/ Datacentres required for AI/ Construction of the Yarlung Tsangpo Hydroelectric Project the world‚Äôs largest hydroelectric power plant / Rebuilding of houses, commercial buildings and infrastructure in California.....   so i am buying these big metals listed companies judiciously (As per our podcast with Sir Mick Davis) as economic weakness may well  come first..

[24/03/2025, 21:09:17] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Connecting ADOLESCENCE & DEPIN. 
The issues adressed in the Netflix sensation ‚ÄúAdolescence‚Äù may be synonymous with the greatest unspoken crisis of our time. 
I am not going to dwell on any reservations I may have had after 4hrs of wrist slittingly depressing viewing and I wanted to point out that a knowledge of the use of turpentine and its paint removing skills could have saved me half an hour of that! 
What however matters much more is that the most dangerous threats to the young no longer arrive in the form of visible enemies or machines of war. They come through screens silent, intimate, ever-present. There is a quiet war being waged on the attention, self-worth, and identity of young people, and society is losing it.
Childhood, once defined by imagination, boredom, and real-world risk, has been replaced by hyper-stimulation and emotional exposure. The treehouses, scraped knees, and slow days have given way to infinite scrolls and dopamine loops. Where connection once meant whispered secrets under a canopy of trees, it now means curated images and performance metrics. Childhood has been digitised‚Äîand with it, something essential has been lost.
Institutions meant to nurture young minds have largely turned a blind eye. The education system is preoccupied with optics new facilities, digital showcases, and parent-pleasing upgrades‚Äîwhile the real threat unfolds unchecked. The great handover has happened: children are now raised by algorithms, not adults. Parents, overwhelmed and outnumbered, often surrender early. Devices become pacifiers, lifelines, and unfortunately, gateways.
Bullying, once visible and subject to social correction, is now ambient. It hides in DMs, in group chats, in silence and exclusion. We‚Äôve moved from sticks and stones to likes swipes and shares but the bruises run deeper and the scars are harder to trace. What once stayed in the corridor now follows them home, sleeps beside them, wakes with them. The torment is programmable and worse, it‚Äôs now gamified.
But all is not lost. There are glimmers of resistance and one of the most promising comes from an unlikely place and somewhere Nutstuff and George at Sycamore Gap are laser-focussed: decentralised physical infrastructure networks, or DEPIN. These systems reward real-world participation. They are built not on attention extraction, but on contribution. They replace the empty currency of fake likes with real value earned through activity that benefits others, networks maintained, coverage provided, data stored, energy shared.
DEPIN models offer young people something the current system does not: purpose. A sense of building, belonging, and being part of something bigger than themselves. These systems don‚Äôt just consume attention they reward action. In a world designed to distract, this is a quiet revolution.
If adolescence today feels like freefall, perhaps the way out is not to retreat but to rebuild. Not to lecture young people but to give them better systems. Systems rooted in contribution, in reality, in resilience. We cannot stop the future from arriving but we can decide what kind of world it builds.

To anyone asking for an investable conclusion of the above, it is to add to or add a position in HELIUM/ HNT. ( you can Buy in REVOLUT). $550m Mkt Cap & 500k going to 1m mobile customers. The data offload to Helium from the Major telco‚Äôs is as good an example of how DEPIN works as any. ( There is another soon to launch token which excites even more!)
[24/03/2025, 21:15:37] Nick finegold: Here‚Äôs a cleaner, more digestible version of your message for your investment club‚Äîstill thoughtful, but simpler, more to the point, and easy to understand: courtesy of ChatGPT 

‚∏ª

Connecting Adolescence & DEPIN ‚Äì A Brief Investment Perspective

After watching the Netflix docuseries Adolescence, it‚Äôs clear we‚Äôre facing one of the biggest silent crises of our time: the mental and emotional decay of young people. The threat isn‚Äôt war or violence‚Äîit‚Äôs coming through their screens. Social media and digital culture are quietly attacking their attention, identity, and self-worth.

Childhood has been traded for dopamine loops and filtered feeds. Schools and institutions are slow to respond. Parents are overwhelmed. Algorithms are raising our kids now.

But there is hope‚Äîand interestingly, it‚Äôs coming from the world of decentralised physical infrastructure networks (DEPIN). Unlike the attention-hungry systems kids are trapped in, DEPIN models reward real-world contribution. Instead of chasing likes, users get value for providing services like wireless coverage, data storage, or energy sharing.

This isn‚Äôt just tech‚Äîit‚Äôs a new kind of system that offers young people purpose instead of performance. Something real, something that pays back for participation, not passivity.

The investable takeaway?
Take a position‚Äîor add to one‚Äîin Helium (HNT). It‚Äôs a DEPIN project with a growing user base (500k heading to 1 million mobile users), and big telecoms are already offloading data to its network. Market cap is ~$550M and you can buy it via Revolut.

Bottom line: If today‚Äôs systems are failing the next generation, let‚Äôs invest in building better ones.

[03/04/2025, 06:10:29] ~‚ÄØMatt H: Japan does not impose import tariffs on vehicles, including those from the United States. However, imported vehicles are subject to several taxes: Ôøº
	‚Ä¢	Consumption Tax: A 10% tax applied to the vehicle‚Äôs value.
	‚Ä¢	Excise Tax: This varies based on the vehicle‚Äôs engine size and horsepower. Ôøº
	‚Ä¢	Vehicle Tax: An annual tax determined by the engine size and power of the vehicle. Ôøº

Additionally, imported vehicles must comply with Japanese safety and emission standards, which may necessitate modifications and inspections. It‚Äôs advisable to consult with Japanese customs or a customs broker for detailed information on the import process and associated costs.  Ôøº

[03/04/2025, 08:51:50] Nick finegold: For Full disclosure I bought some Novo yesterday. 

Its 50% pull back seems to take on board tariffs , new competition, and price cuts . 

What it‚Äôs ignoring is that the market is big enough for everyone , and Lilly will be subjected to the same barriers as Wegovy in the rest of the world . Does anyone really care about 22% vs 25% weight loss ? They will care more about price is my guess and whether it agrees with you. 

 I also took a deep dive into the work at the foundation and it‚Äôs mind blowing what they are doing in drug discovery with no cost to Novo shareholders . Nvidia quantum etc . 

It‚Äôs back at 17x and given I listened to an expert say it would take 12 years to roll out these drugs through the NHS to everyone who needed them just in the UK , I think this is a production game now and no one is better positioned than them in that regard .

[09/04/2025, 18:51:55] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: So the market seems to be making its mind up.
Nutstuff is guessing we finally have the beginnings of an outline of what the tariff off ramp looks like to Trump. First all world leaders need to bow down kiss the ring of the king in the oval office - or in trumps words last night at a Republican dinner "kiss my ass". Then he wants zero tariffs and then he wants something a little extra from each country and it will be different or what he calls bespoke - from China he wants a sale of tik-tok to a US group (although why, who knows) and an end of artificial management of the yuan; back doors to US via korea mexico japan etc stops, from Europe he wants more US exports of natural gas (already the EU buys 45% of its supply from the US) and mitigation of the "lawfare"/regulation of US tech firms etc etc. He wants to show America he is the greatest deal maker and can do things that other american presidents never did; he wants to show that America can throw its weight around and bully and intimidate others into submission. Most countries will grit their teeth and do a deal but they will never forgive the humiliation and in many ways, and in some we cant even fathom, the US will one day pay the price for this. Some, like China, may hold out and may even get the better of Trump. There will be a list of good countries Trump wants to deal with first - like Japan, South Korea, Israel and the UK - and those countries like Vietnam with whom he must get a quick deal  in the face of the disintegrating supply chains of businesses like Apple,  Gap, Nike, Coca Cola and Intel etc. And we know that Japan, South Korea and Vietnam are all in frenzied meetings with their Washington counterparts right now trying desperately to get a quick deal done this week. Other countries who are not on Trumps list - think Africa especially South Africa - may not get a look in for some time and could even be left out in the cold. Whilst there is plenty of room for further f** up, own goals and global economic sabotage its not going to be a surprise to see a deal or two done in the coming days and certainly by the end of next week.

We set out 10 reasons why India ranks as our preferred regional overweight.


 1.  India is among the least sensitive to Trump‚Äôs tariff onslaught
 2.  India‚Äôs economy is more domestically driven than peers‚Äô
 3.  The equity market is five-sixths domestically owned

"Uncertainty and anxiety about the future of markets and the economy are dominating client conversations. We've seen periods like this before when there were large, structural shifts in policy and markets ‚Äì like the financial crisis, COVID, and surging inflation in 2022," CEO Larry Fink said in a statement. 
The benchmark S&P 500 index fell 4.6% in the first quarter of 2025, its worst start to a year since 2022. 
Total expenses in the quarter rose to $3.58 billion from $3.04 billion last year. 
However, assets under management at the New York firm rose to $11.58 trillion from $10.47 trillion last year, as investors poured into exchange traded funds and other low-risk products.

[14/04/2025, 14:54:31] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Someones listening on MP US.

Nutstuff on RARE-EARTHS & CHINA: Yes, It's almost comical it took this long; China had a giant red button labeled "Rare Earths" for over a decade, and everyone knew they'd eventually press it. China‚Äôs decision to halt rare earth exports to the U.S. is not just an economic move it‚Äôs a calibrated act of geostrategic disruption. Rare earths like dysprosium oxide may represent a minuscule portion of China‚Äôs export revenue, but they serve as critical arteries for U.S. industries: EVs, semiconductors, aerospace, and defense. And China knows full well that most U.S. firms operate without meaningful inventories sacrificing resilience for balance sheet optics. By targeting this vulnerability, Beijing exerts maximum strategic leverage at minimal domestic cost. Do we have a Plan B? Well its MP MATERIALS/  MP US!

Dalio sees the trap: raise rates and you bankrupt the state. Cut rates and you trash the currency. Keep pretending you can do both, and you lose the credibility needed to do either. 
The Fed isn‚Äôt the Fed anymore. It‚Äôs a janitor with a mop, chasing spills it caused. And inflation isn‚Äôt ‚Äútransitory‚Äù when your credibility is. The US dollar isn‚Äôt just a currency anymore. It‚Äôs a geopolitical cudgel. And the moment your money becomes a weapon, people start building escape hatches. Think BRICS. BTC Think gold. Think anything but Treasuries. 
This is the point where empires get downgraded. De-dollarisation is not a fantasy. It‚Äôs already here. Quiet, incremental, but accelerating. Countries are dumping Treasuries and hedging bets. The American Empire is being unwound by Excel sheets. 
If Ray Dalio says something ‚Äúmuch worse than a recession‚Äù is coming you better buy some f**** Bitcoin.

[18/04/2025, 08:46:01] Nick finegold: RARE EARTHS:

The Big Picture:
America‚Äôs tariff-heavy strategy in the rare earths trade war is backfiring‚Äîfast. With China tightening controls on critical exports, U.S. industry is staring down a supply crisis, and the White House is scrambling to course-correct.

‚∏ª

1. Tariffs Trigger Trade Turmoil
What happened: The U.S. slapped across-the-board tariffs on rare earths‚Äîexcluding magnets‚Äîbut forgot to check if it could actually replace Chinese supply. Spoiler: it can‚Äôt.
Why it matters: Nearly 7,500 tons of rare earth magnets imported from China in 2024 now face tariffs. There‚Äôs no short- or mid-term substitute.

‚ÄúMutually Assured Destruction isn‚Äôt just nuclear‚Äîit‚Äôs trade, too.‚Äù

‚∏ª

2. Defense Industry in a Bind
China‚Äôs move: Beijing has locked out U.S. defense contractors from access to dual-use rare earths, hitting critical components: samarium-cobalt magnets, dysprosium, terbium, and others.
Impact: U.S. defense supply chains are stalled. The eVAC project is the only domestic magnet hope‚Äîand it‚Äôs still China-reliant.
Bonus pain: Samarium just vanished from U.S. supply.

‚∏ª

3. Lanthanum: China‚Äôs Ace
Why it matters: 63% of U.S. rare earth imports from China are lanthanum, vital for gasoline production.
What if China halts exports? Pump prices could spike 30%‚Äîa political death sentence in an election year.

‚∏ª

4. MP Materials: A Case Study in Vulnerability
Despite U.S. support: MP Materials lost 73 cents per $1 of revenue in 2024. Its fate is tied to Chinese partner Shenghe.
Tariffs on bastnaesite ore (MP‚Äôs core product) = lights out.

‚∏ª

5. Reactionary Policy: White House in Whiplash Mode
New exec order: ‚ÄúNational Security & Economic Resilience through Section 232 Actions.‚Äù
The irony: Existing legislation already covers it. Critics call it performative and duplicative.

‚∏ª

6. Lobbyists Swarm, Projects Flounder
Snake oil season: Bad actors are exploiting the panic for handouts.
Data drought: Most U.S. rare earth startups (MP, Noveon, USA Rare Earth) publish no material performance data.

‚∏ª

7. Global Chessboard
	‚Ä¢	Saudi Arabia: Courting RE processing partners (incl. MP & Shenghe) despite unclear domestic resources.
	‚Ä¢	Australia: Mulling a critical minerals stockpile‚Äîpurpose and beneficiaries TBD.
	‚Ä¢	Kiribati: Talking deep-sea mining with China. The desperation is showing.

‚∏ª

Bottom Line:
The U.S. shot first and is now dealing with the recoil. Without realistic domestic alternatives, defense readiness, energy resilience, and trade leverage are under threat. China isn‚Äôt blinking.
[18/04/2025, 08:50:19] Nick finegold: ‚ÄéPOLL:
In attempting to gain supply chain security it‚Äôs possible these tariffs cut off the US from minerals critical to almost every aspect of defence and manufacturing.
‚ÄéOPTION: Do you like the rare earth space as a potential investment opportunity? (10 votes)
‚ÄéOPTION: Think it‚Äôs best avoided given the current turbulence? (10 votes)

Lumina Gold Announces Acquisition by CMOC for C$581 Million
Vancouver, British Columbia - Lumina Gold Corp. (TSXV: LUM) (OTCQB: LMGDF) (the ‚ÄúCompany‚Äù or ‚ÄúLumina‚Äù) and CMOC Singapore Pte. Ltd., a Singapore entity and a subsidiary of CMOC Group Limited (collectively ‚ÄúCMOC‚Äù), both of which are arm‚Äôs length to the Company, are pleased to announce that they have entered into an arrangement agreement (the ‚ÄúArrangement Agreement‚Äù), pursuant to which CMOC will acquire all of the issued and outstanding common shares of Lumina (the ‚ÄúLumina Shares‚Äù), in exchange for C$1.27 per Lumina Share (the ‚ÄúConsideration‚Äù) in an all-cash transaction by way of a plan of arrangement (the ‚ÄúTransaction‚Äù). The Consideration represents total equity value of approximately C$581 million on a fully diluted basis.

 

The Consideration represents a premium of approximately 71% to Lumina‚Äôs 20-day volume weighted average trading price (‚ÄúVWAP‚Äù), and a premium of approximately 41% to Lumina‚Äôs closing price as at April 17, 2025, on the TSX Venture Exchange (the ‚ÄúTSXV‚Äù). Further details of the Transaction are outlined below.

[22/04/2025, 19:37:51] ~‚ÄØChris Dale: Spain to meet Nato‚Äôs 2% defence spending target this year, says PM  https://on.ft.com/4iwoyvZ
[22/04/2025, 19:39:33] ~‚ÄØChris Dale: From JB (a Spanish broker we talk to)

Indra. Spain announced a Eur10.5bn YoY increase in defence spending in 2025, thus reaching 2% of GDP (Eur33bn). This implies a 55% YoY increase in Security and Defence spending, which is well ahead of our 15% growth forecast. Even if we exclude the part of the plan related to communications and dual-use technologies, which we are not sure were part of the 2024 budget, we would still be talking about a 25% YoY increase vs 2024 ‚Äì also comfortably  above our estimates. According to press reports, this increase will be funded without raising taxes or increasing public deficit, through: i) reallocation of Next Generation EU funds (including ‚Ç¨1.3bn for cybersecurity), ii) interest savings on government debt, and iii) unused budget allocations from 2023. 87% of the funds will be allocated domestically and thus Indra should be a major beneficiary. We are just not sure how can domestic companies increase their capacity that much to face this surge in orders, namely taking to account we are already close to the end of April. We should have more details over the next days on how this budget increase will be implemented but anyway we do see the news as positive for Indra. We just do not know how positive and my analyst will chase.

[22/04/2025, 21:47:54] ~‚ÄØMehdi: Tesla earnings takeaways: expectations were very low, but these are still bad numbers

TSLA (Tesla) reported grim Q1 results vs. expectations, including total revenue -9% Y/Y to $19.33B (vs. the Street $22B), EPS -40% to 27c (vs. the Street 47c), and free cash flow ($664MM vs. the Street $1.66B). Mgmt. says the sales decline was driven by lower vehicle deliveries, lower vehicle ASPs, and FX, offset in part by growth in the energy business (auto revenue slumped 20% Y/Y while energy generation/storage revenue jumped 67%). The company finished the quarter with 22 days of auto inventory, a sharp spike from 12 days in Q4 and up modestly from 19 in Q3 and 18 in Q2. The aggregate GAAP gross margin fell 103bp Y/Y and held flat Q/Q at 16.3% (the core auto GM excluding regulatory credits was only 12.5%). ‚ÄúUncertainty in the automotive and energy markets continues to increase as rapidly evolving trade policy adversely impacts the global supply chain and cost structure of Tesla and our peers. This dynamic, along with changing political sentiment, could have a meaningful impact on demand for our products in the near-term‚Äù. The timelines for Robotaxi and Optimus are unchanged (‚Äúwe remain on track for pilot launch of Robotaxi in Austin by June and builds of Optimus on our Fremont pilot production line in 2025, with wider deployment of bots doing useful work across our factories‚Äù). Tesla is still planning to commence production of a more affordable vehicle in H1:25, but there will be less cost savings associated with this product vs. prior expectations (‚Äúthese vehicles will utilize aspects of the next generation platform as well as aspects of our current platforms and will be produced on the same manufacturing lines as our current vehicle lineup. This approach will result in achieving less cost reduction than previously expected but enables us to prudently grow our vehicle volumes in a more capex efficient manner during uncertain times‚Äù). 

What bulls will say: expectations were already super low, so the Q1 numbers aren‚Äôt as bad as they look, and the timelines for critical products (Robotaxi, Optimus, and low-cost vehicle) are the same as before. It‚Äôs likely Musk‚Äôs days at DOGE are numbered, and his departure from that agency could help remove a major sales headwind.

What bears will say: while expectations may have been low, these are still ugly numbers, and there‚Äôs no reason to think things are about to get a lot better. Robotaxi is years behind Waymo, and the company downgraded its guidance for the expense savings associated with the new low-cost vehicle. Musk‚Äôs personal brand has been permanently tarnished by his political activities in the last several months, and exiting DOGE won‚Äôt change that. On top of all this, the stock remains very expensive.

[23/04/2025, 11:31:42] Nick finegold: *Vertiv's Q1 Results Bring Relief to Investors*

Vertiv Holdings Co (NYSE: VRT), a key player in data center infrastructure, reported strong Q1 results that should reassure investors. Here's a breakdown:

*Key Highlights*
- *Beating Expectations*: Vertiv's Q1 EPS ($0.64) and revenue ($2.03B) exceeded Street estimates ($0.61 and $1.94B, respectively).
- *Raising Guidance*: The company increased the midpoint of its full-year sales guidance by $250 million, demonstrating confidence in its growth trajectory.
- *Strong Demand*: Vertiv's B2B segment saw healthy growth, with a backlog jump of around 10% quarter-over-quarter, driven by accelerated AI deployments in the data center market.

*Tariff Impact*
- *Minimal Tariff Effect*: Vertiv expects to mitigate the impact of tariffs as the year progresses, thanks to its diverse manufacturing footprint and operational flexibility.
- *2026 Outlook*: The company aims to significantly reduce the effect of tariffs entering 2026, providing a positive outlook for future growth.

*Investor Takeaway*
- *Robust Demand Trends*: Vertiv's results and outlook point to continued strong demand for data center infrastructure, driven by AI deployments.
- *Relief for Investors*: Overall, the report should bring relief to investors, as Vertiv's performance and guidance suggest a solid growth trajectory despite potential tariff challenges.

[24/04/2025, 12:11:42] Adam Clib: üíäNovo Nordisk is a name mentioned on here quite a lot. üíä
And page 11 today in the FT .

I have no idea if its going up or down.
If you think it's going up, buy the equity. But if income is your driver and you are confident that further declines have a floor,  then you could look to play this through a Barrier Reverse Convertible and take the coupons.

Marex issued Fixed coupon on Novo Nordisk, and its not complicated.

You receive quarterly income over a 3 year investment in GBP.

If at maturity the stock is lower than a defined amount then you are open to a loss of capital, like you would if you owned a stock.
60% barrier means you have downside if the stock falls 40% or more.
65% barrier means you have downside if the stock falls 35% or more.
70% barrier means you have downside if the stock falls 30% or more.
75% barrier means you have downside if the stock falls 25% or more.


Guaranteed Coupon p.a. achieved
10.95% with a 60% barrier
11.31% with a 65% barrier
11.64% with a 70% barrier
11.93% with a 75% barrier

Please ping me if you would like  to chat further. üòä

Please ping me if you would like to know more.  Not so complicated.

If at maturity the stock is lower than a defined amount then you are open to a loss of capital, like you would if you owned a stock.
60% barrier means you have downside if the stock falls 40% or more.
65% barrier means you have downside if the stock falls 35% or more.
70% barrier means you have downside if the stock falls 30% or more.

16.90% with a 60% barrier
17.16% with a 65% barrier

17.57% with a 75% barrier

[24/04/2025, 14:15:34] ~‚ÄØSimon Brewer: Hi Simon,
I listened to the latest podcast in the gym this morning and thought it was excellent. Carson came across very well and it was nice to hear be able to discover the voice behind Muddy Waters. I particularly liked his comments on passive investing. I have always seen it as the ultimate momentum trade and dislike it as such but he made me think of it and the associated risks more deeply. When the piper is finally paid, passive investing will be one of the weapons of mass destruction. I thought it was one of your best interviews. Perceptive, concise and good questions and again you left your guest the space to answer properly. Well done.
My trip to the US exposed me to the full horror of what those living there have to endure on a daily basis and that is all Trump all of the time. The cable news networks are relentless, dramatising everything and as polarising as anything I have seen. There seems to be no middle ground. Being assailed by that every day and knowing it will go one for the next 4 years must be terrible!
The Dems are simply nowhere at the moment. The only ones drawing any crowds are Bernie Saunders and AOC and their progressive message won‚Äôt wash with most Americans. It is only by stepping back, understanding why Trump won and moving closer to the centre that they have a hope of winning in 2028 or even winning one or both houses  in the midterms. 
While most of the people we saw lean Democrat, I did have lunch with an old New York friend who is a Trump supporter. Most of the country applauds the success of Trump‚Äôs immigration policies which have slowed the flow of migrants to a trickle. Most are fully behind the efforts to cut the size of the Federal government and also support the attempt to revive the industrial heartland. It means that Trump‚Äôs base will absorb quite a bit of pain before they turn  against him. That said, it was not his base that got him into power. It was the swing voters. They are not happy about the tariffs, are uncomfortable about Trump‚Äôs treatment of Ukraine and are embarrassed about the way this administration has gone after former allies. They particularly dislike the treatment of Canada and also the policy chaos.
While the tariffs have some logic a rebirth of the industrial heartland of America is a pipe dream in my opinion. Apart from anything else the US does not have the labour force to do the work. Manufacturing processes require precise work and as a result random drug tests. Given the gales of cannabis we often found ourselves walking through in both New Orleans and New York I wonder how many people would pass the tests!
Policy in our entire working lives has favoured capital over labour. Trump was brought to power by labour. In fact the last 3 US elections were won by the blue collar workers. There is therefore significant political logic behind the tariffs or at least their goals. Trump will never win the approval or votes of most of those with capital and he knows it so I expect him to double down in supporting his base. His addiction to conflict and the limelight will mean we have many more headline statements from him to come. I just hope the markets learn to react a little more equably than they have done recently!
For me, the big risk to global markets has always been the size of government debt amassed by so many nations. With democracy ill equipped to elect politicians who will make hard choices, it will be left to the markets and the bond market in particular to exercise control. We have seen them do that over the last few weeks though the most recent softening of stance in the tariffs was also probably also encouraged by the visit to the White House of the CEO‚Äôs of Walmart, Home Depot and Target. These guys warned Trump imminent rises and the possibility empty shelves as the tariffs impact is felt. Given these are the most used retailers for the MAGA crowd it was probably quite persuasive!
I am comforted that there is at least an adult in the room even if it is Mr Market but less bullish than I was. I think the earnings outlook in Europe is not bad and the valuations this side of the Atlantic are far more attractive. The Ukraine war seems to be in its endgame, however distasteful that will be, and that should result in lower energy prices, higher defence spending and higher spending on  infrastructure. So, while I am not betting against the US, I am trimming my overweight position on strong days and putting more money in Europe.
Well done on your enthusiasm for gold. I am afraid I cannot get the comments Buffett made about gold in his 2011 annual letter out of my head so I have not been able to enjoy the ride.
Best
Tyrrell

[26/04/2025, 07:07:20] Nick finegold: Read this . Especially the last paragraph.

Rick Smith

Got it. Let me maybe take this one. So, yes, I mean, Dedrone has sold a lot of stuff in Ukraine, but the far bigger picture is what happened in Ukraine has put drones on everybody's road map. Every military in the world is thinking about how do you detect these small drones that traditional military systems are not designed to detect, how do you defend against them. We acquired the world leader in drone detection. We acquired the at least one of the world leaders in indoor tactical drones with Skydio. We've partnered with the leading US maker of long range autonomous AI driven drones, in the moment where, basically DJI is largely being made illegal in the United States. So we think we are in an amazing position for drones and robotics. It's an area we're investing heavily. We're currently either the leader or partnered with the leader in the key market segments. And when you think about things like patrolling borders, protecting stadiums, and, I mean, Ukraine has shown what anybody could do with a drone you can buy for less than $500 and everybody in the world is thinking about how to defend against those, and we think we are, if not the best positioned, among the best positioned, for helping our customers globally solve that problem. So from a human perspective, I certainly hope that all the violence we're seeing in the world, comes to an end, but in a way that is persistent and sort of long-term puts these issues to rest. And we look forward to playing a role in helping use technology to protect people from killer drones. We're not going to get into the lethal drone business ourselves, but we're going to absolutely be a leader in helping defend against those kinds of threats and then using drones to be able to go out, act more intelligently, save lives, and stop threats without using lethal force. And we think those opportunities have all gotten bigger, just given the quick evolution of the space that's been caused by what's been happening in the Middle East and in Ukraine.

Josh Isner

And, Rick, I might just add one more thing there, which is just, to the first part of your question, Jeremy, just to address any ambiguity. None of our forward-looking guidance assumes any incremental revenue from Ukraine.

[26/04/2025, 13:13:57] ~‚ÄØRich McDonald: ChatGPT interpretation of the specific venue choice:
 
Why would world leaders be placed under this image for peace talks, with simple chairs and no table.
	‚Ä¢	Symbolism of Humility: Sitting in simple chairs ‚Äî no table, no grandeur ‚Äî echoes the humility of Christ being baptized. It strips away ego, status, and pride. The two leaders are just men, human beings facing each other, not kings, not gods.
	‚Ä¢	A Moment of Rebirth: Just as baptism signifies the death of the old self and the birth of the new, their meeting could symbolize the end of hostility and the beginning of peace ‚Äî starting again, washed clean from the blood of war.
	‚Ä¢	Witnessed by the Divine: Above them, the painting shows heaven opening, the Holy Spirit descending like a dove. It frames their conversation as being not just between two politicians, but as being witnessed by a higher, moral force ‚Äî justice, truth, mercy ‚Äî asking them to rise above selfishness and war.
	‚Ä¢	The Absence of Material Barriers: No table between them means there‚Äôs no negotiation, no posturing ‚Äî only vulnerability and honest dialogue. Two men facing each other with nothing between them but the burden of people‚Äôs suffering and the hope for redemption.

‚∏ª

In short:
Placing two leaders under The Baptism of Christ in St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica would send the message:

‚ÄúHere, in the holiest place, under the symbol of new life, humility, and forgiveness, you are called to set aside your pride and create peace.‚Äù

[28/04/2025, 12:57:08] Nick finegold: This cyber attack in Portugal is quite serious .
[28/04/2025, 12:57:29] Nick finegold: Brussels (CNN) ‚Äî In an unprecedented wave of cyber assaults, critical infrastructure across Europe was targeted early Monday in what officials are calling one of the largest coordinated cyberattacks in history. European Union cybersecurity agencies have pointed to Russian state-backed groups as the primary suspects behind the widespread disruptions.

Power grids, financial institutions, airports, and healthcare systems across more than 15 countries were affected. Several major European banks reported temporary outages, and airports in Frankfurt, Paris, and Madrid experienced system failures that caused extensive flight delays. Emergency services in parts of Germany and Poland were forced to revert to analog communications after losing digital capabilities.

"This is a direct attack on European sovereignty," said European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen at a press briefing. "We will respond with unity, strength, and resilience."

The Kremlin has officially denied involvement, dismissing the accusations as "baseless and provocative."

At the same time, NATO forces reported unusual naval movements in the North Atlantic. According to U.S. European Command (EUCOM), at least six Russian naval vessels, including two destroyers and a submarine, were detected maneuvering near critical undersea cable routes between Europe and North America. Additional allied naval assets have been deployed in response to what a senior Pentagon official described as "a significant and deliberate show of force."

"This pattern of behavior is deeply concerning," said Admiral James Thornton, commander of NATO's Allied Maritime Command. "We are closely monitoring all maritime traffic and are prepared to safeguard transatlantic security."

If it goes down you are 1:1 in terms of downside
 
Version 1:
Gearing: x1.15 , so if its up 20% at maturity you get  23% return with no cap

Version 2

The max redemption = 100% + 1.5*33.333% = 150%

[29/04/2025, 14:51:47] Adam Clib: üíäNovo Nordisk is a name mentioned on here quite a lot. üíä



If you think it's going up, buy the equity. But if income is your driver and you are "confident that further declines have a floor",  then you could look to play this through a Barrier Reverse Convertible and take the coupons.

Marex issued Fixed coupon on Novo Nordisk. 

You receive quarterly income over a 3 year investment in GBP.

If at maturity the stock is lower than a defined amount then you are open to a loss of capital, like you would if you owned a stock.
60% barrier means you have downside if the stock falls 40% or more.
65% barrier means you have downside if the stock falls 35% or more.
70% barrier means you have downside if the stock falls 30% or more.
75% barrier means you have downside if the stock falls 25% or more.


Guaranteed Coupon p.a. achieved
9.92% with a 60% barrier
10.31% with a 65% barrier
10.67% with a 70% barrier
10.98% with a 75% barrier

[29/04/2025, 14:53:27] Nick finegold: GM suspends call by 48 hours awaiting an announcement from Trump on auto tariffs ? 

In line result. 1Q results featured in line Adj. EBIT and modestly lower FCF conversion. Margins still strong by historic standards. China JV profit near break-even.
Withdrawn guidance. This is not at all a surprise given the uncertainty of tariff policies that could impact many billions of $ of Adj. EBIT depending on outcome and implementation. GM imports roughly 1mm units into the US from CN, MEX and Asia.
Suspended open market repo. Makes total sense to us given the fluidity of the situation which could entail OEMs such as GM consuming cash in many tariff and consumer scenarios.
Delayed conference call, President Trump in Detroit. While removing the guidance and suspending the buyback is not a shock, the delay in the conference call timing - if only by 48 hours - has grabbed investor attention. The delay seems to coincide with a Trump rally in the Detroit area after reports of U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick saying that President Trump is moving towards softening auto tariffs. While not confirmed, the President's visit to Macomb County (marking Trump's first 100 days in office) could present a unique opportunity for Trump to meet directly with the automakers, including GM. GM says the extra time should help offer a greater basis of information by which to address the forward outlook and market questions and that the management team is in direct communication with POTUS.

Feel free to go speakers corner if you want to express your opinion on any subject , feel free to become a paid up member of whatever political group takes your fancy , campaign on doorsteps , and donate , but spare this group . 

Please understand I deeply respect everyone‚Äôs opinion,  especially  if the commentary is  relevant to sectors and industries we care about deeply . but I am not running a debating society.  I am running an investment club that‚Äôs designed to make people money . 

Political opinions are welcome  if  linked to actionable outcomes in this group . 

Please give us your ideas on stocks and shares. Please give us opinions on how articles impact markets , but leave the rest of it at home , 

I know it‚Äôs a balance and having fun is very important to me , but today there was way too much noise , which spoils the user experience for the vast majority of members of this group so take it offline and discuss it all you like , 

Thank you .

[30/04/2025, 08:19:17] Nick finegold: From the World Gold Council. 

Interesting to note Jewellery demand falling heavily as the price rises . I am thinking about Pandora which is a good company but might be struggling in this environment. 

Key Highlights
Inflows into global gold ETFs rocketed in Q1: demand of 226t was the strongest for three years. Investors across the globe bought gold as a refuge against the threat of trade wars, continued geopolitical strife and equity market turmoil. 
‚Ää
Global central banks bought 244t of gold in Q1. The pace of buying slowed, but remained well within the elevated quarterly range seen over the last three years.  
‚Ää
Investment in gold bars and coins remained elevated at 325t. Gold‚Äôs price momentum attracted investor interest, which was cemented by the political and economic volatility roiling global markets.
‚Ää
Gold jewellery consumption dropped 21% y/y as record prices impacted affordability. While tonnage demand was lower in virtually every market, the value measure of demand increased in every country except China. 
‚Ää
Total gold supply was 1% higher y/y  as mine production inched up to a Q1 record of 856t. This was offset by a 1% decline in recycling as consumers held onto their gold hoping for higher prices. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[02/05/2025, 10:28:30] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: On a theme of new National champions and finding a non US name when before the default was US‚Ä¶

A NEW POSITION THIS WEEK: AVIO. IM is an Eur500m co and 30% owned by Leonardo (a Nutstuff Portfolio name). Avio is a key beneficiary of the European Rearmament, both in its Space division and its Defence Division.  Furthermore, the company is fundamentally cheap, with a strong backlog and in an important, strategic position.  This article frames the background of this call: https://www.wsj.com/finance/europe-defense-us-military-industrial-complex-61ea9654
In Defence etc just imagine if the US could immobilise Lockheed Martin fighter jets using a ‚ÄúKill Switch‚Äù. Just imagine Denmark using Lockheed Martin fighter jets to defend Greenland and all the US has to do is press a button and they drop like flies. It serves as the prime contractor for the Vega rocket family and a key supplier for Ariane 6. Avio‚Äôs core expertise lies in developing and manufacturing solid rocket motors, which are used in both the Vega and Ariane boosters. A Fun fact: The Company originates from Fiat as early as 1908, and at some point it was owned by Private Equity and General Electric! European Defence Peers such as Leonardo trade on 12x fwd EBITDA but bellwether Rheinmetall trades as high as 19x EBITDA. The nearest US Peer in Space is Rocket Labs, which trades on 10x fwd SALES (it‚Äôs still EBITDA negative), though it‚Äôs a far more integrated player and its growth is not only launch-related.
‚Äé[02/05/2025, 11:21:58] ~‚ÄØGR: ‚Äéimage omitted
[02/05/2025, 11:23:00] ~‚ÄØGR: US Exceptionalism Cannot Be Killed Off By Trump

The most bullish argument in favour of the US has been made by the unlikeliest of people: Nouriel Roubini. His latest column on Project Syndicate goes completely against trend and argues US tailwinds are more than sufficient to overcome the tariff shock. He said even if Mickey Mouse were president, the US would still approach 4% growth. He said "America is the world leader in 10 of the 12 industries that will define the future, with China leading in only electric vehicles and other green tech". Tariffs don't change that, he said, and in fact the hyperscalers are doubling down on investment. Meanwhile, Roubini noted while former Italian PM‚Äôs Draghi and Letta have both written blue prints for European growth, European governments have largely ignored their recommendations. As for the threat from Trump, Roubini noted the president has lost in every game of chicken he's played. He backed down on reciprocal tariffs the moment the markets objected; he's had to request a meeting with China on tariffs; Trump blinked first in his argument with Fed Chair Powell.

[03/05/2025, 00:11:58] Nick finegold: US lawmakers urge SEC to delist Alibaba and Chinese companies  https://on.ft.com/3GDKTu7
[03/05/2025, 05:57:25] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Chris Wood addressed this..

ChrisW: The base case here remains that the US has no leverage over China on the tariff issue. Beijing has made it crystal clear that it will not cut tariffs unless the US makes the first move since it is the Trump administration which initiated this trade war. The plan of the Trump administration is obviously to seek to isolate China by agreeing trade deals with more friendly countries, such as Japan and India. If this pressure means Japan and India may be able to negotiate better deals with the US than might otherwise have been the case, they are unlikely to agree terms that threaten their trading relationship with China. Remember that China specifically warned last week that it will retaliate against any country that negotiates trade deals with America ‚Äúat the expense of China‚Äôs interests‚Äù. In this respect, it is a reality that for many countries China is now a more important trade partner than the US. All of the above is why the Donald still badly needs an off-ramp before his tariff agenda inflicts too much unnecessary damage on the American economy, evidence of which is likely to show up in data in the next few weeks. Chris repeats the point that Trump should revert to a universal 10% tariff for everybody and then drop the rest of the agenda. From a stock market standpoint, the lack of evidence of accelerating stimulus deprives the China equity story of a near-term catalyst. Still Chris is comfortable with China equities both from a valuation standpoint, in a context where consumer sentiment appears to be stabilising at worst, and from a diversification standpoint since China is significantly uncorrelated to Wall Street-correlated global equities.  If the biggest potential positive catalyst for China equities, and indeed US equities, is a total Trump U-turn on tariffs, the biggest risk is a threatened Washington delisting of US-listed Chinese ADRs. Chris views this as extremely unlikely but clearly nothing is impossible.  Any such delisting action would be a massive buying opportunity for the rest of the world including European investors who, in his view, will not follow the US in the context of the current Trump administration.
[03/05/2025, 06:04:50] ~‚ÄØAndrew Draycott: I read that piece, and imho he is wrong on India putting any precedent to China over the US in trading relations. The FM was unequivocally hawkish China dumping via third party countries like Vietnam and Bangladesh and was seeking to impose tariff barriers to prevent it. India sees the bilateral agreement with the US as a generational opportunity to take manufacturing share from 1% to something like their services share at 8%, and will bend over backwards to give the US what they want in order to achieve it. Chinese fdi into India has consistently been banned, and byd recently tried to invest $10bn into Hyderabad and were stopped. Tik tock and Chinese tech is also banned. There is zero leverage for China over India, and I don‚Äôt really understand where Chris perceives it to lie.

[05/05/2025, 16:56:20] ~‚ÄØMatt H: Gold prices surged to record highs in the first quarter of 2025, as macroeconomic and geopolitical forces reshaped investor sentiment. The metal‚Äôs traditional role as a safe haven has been reinforced amid growing unease over U.S. trade policies, which have strained U.S. relations with the world and eroded confidence in the dollar and U.S. Treasuries.
Fueling the rally further is sustained demand from China‚Äôs central bank, which has steadily increased its gold reserves in a bid to diversify away from dollar-denominated assets. This strategic shift highlights a broader realignment in global asset allocation, particularly among emerging market economies.
Adding further momentum is a forthcoming change in U.S. banking regulation. From July 2025, gold will be reclassified as a Tier 1 capital asset under Basel III rules ‚Äî aligning U.S. standards with global norms. Because gold will now be a Tier 1 capital asset, banks can operate with far less capital than when gold was classified as Tier 3. Under the new regulations, allocated (physical) gold will have zero risk weighting. This could significantly impact the gold market, driving up prices and contributing to the overall demand for gold.

[08/05/2025, 17:04:27] ~‚ÄØAndrew Draycott: We hosted a call with Col. (Retd.) Ajai Shukla to take stock of the evolving India/Pakistan conflict.
The situation is tense, but not out of control. De-escalation remains on the table‚Äîif both sides can find and take a mutually acceptable off-ramp. History shows this can happen with our without international mediation. Cross-border attacks‚Äîexplosions, drones, and power outages‚Äîhave caused suffering and loss on both sides, including reports of India losing a fighter jet. But a full-scale war between two nuclear-armed nations (sorry to bore you with the clich√©) is not possible‚Äîand if it does break out, conventional military strength (where India is far far superior) becomes irrelevant. That‚Äôs exactly why the U.S. has never gone to war with North Korea.

 
Executive Summary and the De-escalation Path?
Operation Ongoing: Operation Sindoor is still active, with reports of continued strikes. It won‚Äôt be considered over until there‚Äôs a formal announcement‚Äîand Pakistan agrees. In today‚Äôs social media era, there‚Äôs a political narrative at play, a military execution underway, and a diplomatic route being quietly explored.
No Full-Scale War (Yet): While there have been cross-border actions, both sides seem to be carefully balancing force with diplomacy. India appears to have a tactical advantage, but neither side is pushing toward full-blown conflict.
Backchannels Are Open: Dialogue is likely happening behind the scenes‚Äîthrough official channels or via third countries. For two nuclear-armed nations, these quiet lines of communication are critical.
Off-Ramp Available: A face-saving off-ramp exists if both sides can claim a win and step back. We‚Äôve seen this before‚Äîlike in 2019 when an Indian pilot was returned, helping end the standoff in a day. A similar move could defuse the current tension.
The Rafale??: Col. Shukla believes at least one fighter jet may have been lost. India hasn‚Äôt acknowledged it‚Äîprobably to avoid giving Pakistan a narrative win. But interestingly, confirming it could serve as a circuit breaker for de-escalation.

Pakistan‚Äôs Political Landscape

Strategic Backdrop: The widening gap between India and Pakistan in economic, technological, and social spheres is fueling insecurity in Islamabad. Ironically, this imbalance may drive more hostility, not less‚Äîrooted in envy and pride. Pakistan is likely to stick with its reactive stance. India, meanwhile, must find a way to bypass the ‚ÄúPakistan drag‚Äù and push ahead‚Äî"with or without us" remains a relevant doctrine. The current tit-for-tat strikes across borders serve no long-term strategic purpose.
Military Leadership: Former Army Chief Gen. Qamar Bajwa had a broader strategic outlook and questioned the utility of symbolic wins like "moral dominance." His successor, Gen. Munir, is seen as the opposite‚Äîreactive, grievance-driven, and lacking strategic depth. His intelligence chief (DGISI) is cut from the same cloth.
The Sharif Brothers: Neither Nawaz nor Shahbaz is in the military‚Äôs favor. Nawaz often clashed with the generals despite initially being their chosen candidate. Shahbaz maintained a transactional relationship with the army‚Äîlargely to protect business interests‚Äîbut doesn‚Äôt enjoy full trust either.
International Response

Global Mood: Since the Pahalgam incident, India has moved swiftly to engage key global players. Western democracies seem fatigued with Pakistan and more aligned with India‚Äôs strategic outlook. Pakistan‚Äôs overdependence on China and its historical flirtation with political Islam are now global liabilities. Islamabad is increasingly isolated, relying mainly on China, Turkey, and a lukewarm Saudi Arabia.
Russia‚Äôs Role: Russia‚Äôs balancing act is becoming harder as China asserts dominance in Asia. The traditional India-Russia comfort zone is being reshaped into a tense China-Russia-India triangle. Putin‚Äôs tilt depends on how much he needs Beijing‚Äôs backing against the West. India is trying to reassure Russia that growing U.S. ties aren‚Äôt at Moscow‚Äôs expense, but that‚Äôs a tough sell. For now, Russia‚Äîlike the U.S.‚Äîhas stayed neutral, calling only for de-escalation. It‚Äôs a tricky space for Indian diplomacy.
Indian Defence Performance

How has Indian equipment fared: There‚Äôs been little direct hardware-to-hardware clash, especially with Chinese systems. Most of India‚Äôs strike capability‚Äîtanks, APCs, S-400s, submarines‚Äîstill comes from Russia. But India shines where it‚Äôs built for itself: indigenous missiles like the Agni series and domestically built warships (frigates, destroyers, corvettes) reflect real capability. Where India has relied on imports, it‚Äôs sacrificed tech control and slowed down true self-reliance.
