[09/05/2025, 13:43:39] Nick finegold: What does disease modification mean in plain English . 

Courtesy of ChatGPT

It strike me that below is the Meira GTX story in a nutshell. 

It is  a genetic disease modification platform ! 

Disease modification means you‚Äôre not just treating the symptoms ‚Äî you‚Äôre actually slowing down or changing the course of the disease itself. In their case using genetics. 

In plain English:
Most Parkinson‚Äôs drugs are like painkillers ‚Äî they make you feel better, but the disease keeps getting worse in the background.
A disease-modifying treatment aims to stop or delay the damage from happening in the first place. It‚Äôs closer to a fix than a patch. ‚Äé<This message was edited>
[09/05/2025, 13:45:21] Nick finegold: In other words MeiraGTx is attempting to cure not treat the symptoms of disease. 

They have already helped blind children see again and now MIGHT have a cure for Parkinson‚Äôs . Hence the FDA‚Äôs heightened interest .

[12/05/2025, 07:42:00] ~‚ÄØMatt H: Pan American Silver Announces Agreement to Acquire MAG Silver Corp.

All amounts expressed in U.S. dollars unless otherwise indicated.

Adds Strategic Interest in Tier-One Juanicipio Silver Mine and Significantly Strengthens its Silver Portfolio

Vancouver, British Columbia, May 11, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Pan American Silver Corp. (NYSE: PAAS) (TSX: PAAS) ("Pan American") and MAG Silver Corp. (NYSEAM:MAG) (TSX:MAG) ("MAG") are pleased to announce that they have entered into a definitive agreement whereby Pan American will acquire all of the issued and outstanding common shares of MAG pursuant to a plan of arrangement (the "Transaction"). MAG is a tier-one primary silver mining company through its 44% joint venture interest in the large-scale, high-grade Juanicipio mine, operated by Fresnillo plc ("Fresnillo"), who holds the remaining 56% interest in the Juanicipio joint venture.

Under the terms of the Transaction, MAG shareholders will receive total consideration of approximately $2.1 billion representing $20.54 per MAG share, based on the closing price of Pan American‚Äôs common shares on the New York Stock Exchange ("NYSE") on May 9, 2025. Consideration will be comprised of a mix of cash totaling $500 million and 0.755 Pan American shares per MAG share, subject to proration as detailed below. The consideration represents premiums of approximately 21% and 27%, respectively, on a prorated basis to the closing price and the 20-day volume weighted average price ("VWAP") of MAG‚Äôs common shares on the NYSE American ("NYSEAM") ending May 9, 2025. Following completion of the Transaction, existing MAG shareholders will own approximately 14% of Pan American shares on a fully diluted basis, benefiting from participation in a larger, diversified, and growth-oriented silver and gold producer.

[14/05/2025, 18:21:44] ~‚ÄØSSCOOK: Anyone looking for an idea in the periphery banking space should put Bank of Cyprus on their radar. Stock has run up like the rest of Southern  European banks but still trades at a decent discount to other Euro periphery banks and is still on ~6x PE even after the big run. By the numbers BOCH has one of best balance sheets in terms of capital (CET1 20%) and deposit funding  franchises (LDR 50%)and its capital mgt yield (dps/buyback) is 11%. Their restructuring  story is on par with other euro banks (better asset quality and cost efficiency) but not sure how many investors know this or care? Cyprus country macro is in good shape & much better than the other peripheries and much of the wider eurozone (better gdp growth, 65% govt debt/gdp, fiscal surplus etc.). Relative to when I last looked at this stock 10 years ago‚Ä¶both the Russians and the Cypriot government are gone. The company moved its listing back to Athens from London last fall which should help as everyone loves the Greek banks‚Ä¶at least for now. Loan growth is starting to pick up and they are transparent about what lower ECB rates means for them. This is clearly the market neglect story of the peripheries and the only pure play way to get exposure to Cyprus. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[17/05/2025, 16:24:03] ~‚ÄØRich McDonald: Does Moody‚Äôs US downgrade matter?

What a one-notch cut means for the market, the banks, and the White House

On Friday, Moody‚Äôs pulled the trigger and stripped the US‚Äôs of its last top rating ‚Äî downgrading it one notch from Aaa to Aa1.


But does it matter?

We looked into the implications of a downgrade a couple of months ago, back when Moody‚Äôs still seemed determined to ignore the sixty-foot flashing neon signage writing on the wall.

From a stock market perspective, who knows? We have no clue whether, or how much, it will matter when trading opens on Monday. Sure, S&P‚Äôs US sovereign downgrade in August 2011 prompted the worst single day fall in US stock prices since the (admittedly then recent) global financial crisis. But the market quickly recovered. This may have been people freaked out about what the downgrade might mean to the financial plumbing.

So, does the downgrade matter to financial plumbers this time? From a mechanical perspective, the answer is almost certainly ‚Äúnot at all‚Äù.

Banks‚Äô risk-weighted capital asset calculations look unlikely to be impacted by the rating change. This is because regulators don‚Äôt tend to differentiate between Aaa and Aa1 when setting capital risk-weights. For example, this is how the BIS sets out its standardised approach for credit risk as it applies to individual claims to calculate their risk-weighted assets in relation to sovereigns:


Moody‚Äôs could‚Äôve done a three-notch downgrade ‚Äî from Aaa all the way to Aa3 ‚Äî and nothing would‚Äôve changed on this front.

How about collateral management? A note from Barclays on Friday night looked at the implications:

For collateral purposes, a downgrade to Aa1 is also unlikely to have an effect. For instance, DTCC and CME refer to the asset class as US Treasuries and the haircut is a function of the maturity and security type (TIPS/FRNs) but not the ratings. At LCH, a downgrade to Aa1 is unlikely to lead to a change. For instance, USTs and Gilts have similar haircuts, even as the latter are rated lower.

Furthermore, they reckon that the move won‚Äôt trigger moves at the short end of the curve because:

Legislation since the financial crisis has reduced the use of explicit ratings guidelines in investment mandates.

So, they don‚Äôt expect waves of asset sales from the circa $4.5tn in Treasury and Treasury repo in money funds.

Moving away from financial markets, the downgrade may well matter to Moody‚Äôs themselves. If S&P Global Ratings‚Äô experience in 2011 is anything to go by, the firm will be in for a rough ride. Following S&P‚Äôs downgrade more than a decade ago, US Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner threw a bit of a public wobbly, and filmmaker Michael Moore called on Obama to arrest the firm‚Äôs CEO. As we wrote in March:

Someone hired a plane to fly past their rating agency‚Äôs offices dragging a banner proclaiming that they should all be fired, and a bunch of local governments terminated their business with the firm.

Meanwhile, and apparently unrelatedly, the Justice Department launched an investigation into S&P. Within a few weeks, CEO Deven Sharma had left the company. When things moved from being just an investigation to an actual $5bn federal lawsuit for allegedly misleading banks about the credibility of its ratings before the 2008 financial crisis, S&P called this direct retaliation for its downgrade.

Following the downgrade, Moritz Kraemer ‚Äî formerly Global Chief Rating Officer of Sovereign Ratings at S&P Global Ratings ‚Äî wrote on LinkedIn that the danger of retribution was real:

In the US, the rating agencies are regulated and licensed by the SEC (Securities and Exchange Commission). As things stand in America today, we must wonder, whether the SEC can act independently from the wishes of the White House. Remember that the previous SEC chairman, Gary Gensler, resigned on inauguration day, making way for a Trump acolyte. Will Trump be so enraged by the downgrade of the US (which he surely will take personal) that he will demand his pound of flesh and impose revenge on Moody‚Äôs.

We‚Äôve already seen the White House dismiss the analysis, and lash out at Mark Zandi, Moody‚Äôs chief economist. Steven Cheung, assistant to the President, tweeted: ‚ÄúNobody takes his ‚Äòanalysis‚Äô seriously. He has been proven wrong time and time again.‚Äù

As reported in MainFT, Zandi was not an author of this report and works for Moody‚Äôs Analytics, a separate part of the company that is not part of its ratings business.

More generally, while a one-notch downgrade from Aaa may not have huge market implications it is still important.

Fiscally, Moody‚Äôs has long projected near-basket-case metrics for the United States. In reaffirming the Aaa rating back in March it wrote that the country‚Äôs Aaa rating leaned instead on the country‚Äôs ‚Äúextraordinary economic strength and the unique and central roles of the dollar and Treasury bond market in global finance‚Äù.

And in its previous rating report reaffirming the Aaa rating back in November 2023, Moody‚Äôs wrote:

A weakening of institutions and governance strength, such as through deterioration in monetary and macroeconomic policy effectiveness or the quality of legislative and judicial institutions, could also strain the rating.

The world has moved on since 2023, and Moody‚Äôs is marking-to-market.

[19/05/2025, 13:42:26] ~‚ÄØKatie Jackson: Cory explained that the industry would welcome a reversal with open arms, especially considering that Germany has been a poster child of the anti-nuclear movement.

After the Ukraine war began, there were early hints that Germany might consider restarting its reactors. However, one major barrier is that utilities had already sold their nuclear fuel inventory, making a restart logistically difficult. Orano (a French nuclear fuel cycle company) offered to help supply fuel if needed, showing industry support.

However, momentum slowed when utilities pointed out they had already spent significant funds on decommissioning. If they were to reverse that decision, they‚Äôd want to be made financially whole ‚Äî and restarting would also require substantial new investment. This has likely discouraged further consideration of a reversal.

Cory concluded that while Europe overall is ahead of the U.S. in nuclear labor and supply chain readiness, recommissioning in Germany remains a difficult political and economic sell at this point. That said, if Germany did reverse course, the industry would absolutely support it.
[19/05/2025, 14:12:50] ~‚ÄØKatie Jackson: A negative turn in Swiss short-end yields is typically a forward-looking signal of economic weakness, monetary easing, or rising global risk aversion ‚Äî and is often watched as a canary in the coal mine for broader macro shifts.

Switzerland has historically had very low or even negative interest rates, making its short-term yields highly sensitive to global monetary trends. Changes in Swiss short-end yields often reflect anticipated moves by other major central banks (like the ECB or Fed), acting as an early signal of global rate shifts. ü§ì ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[19/05/2025, 21:33:04] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Big News from South Africa: TerraPower and ASP Isotopes Strike Groundbreaking HALEU Deal

We're excited to share major developments out of South Africa as TerraPower and ASP Isotopes (ASPI) enter into definitive agreements to reshape the future of advanced nuclear fuel production.

Key Highlights:

* Strategic Loan Agreement - TerraPower will provide a term loan to partially fund the construction of a first-of-its-kind HALEU (High-Assay Low-Enriched Uranium) enrichment facility in South Africa. ASPI is currently in discussions with financial institutions for the remaining non-dilutive financing, protecting current shareholder value.

* Long-Term Supply Agreement - A 10-year contract has been signed for 150 metric tonnes of HALEU, with deliveries set to begin in 2028 and continue through 2037. The new enrichment facility, located at Pelindaba, is designed to produce up to 15 MTU annually, with production slated to begin in 2027, pending regulatory approvals.

* Future U.S. Expansion Potential - TerraPower and ASPI will also explore collaboration opportunities to establish domestic uranium enrichment capabilities in the United States, tapping into ASPI‚Äôs innovative technologies in a new geography.

This landmark partnership is a major step forward for the global HALEU supply chain‚Äîand a strong signal of commercial momentum for ASPI.

[20/05/2025, 14:56:17] ~‚ÄØJB: The US govt. classifies helium as a critical material for many industries including semis, medical, space and nuclear.
 
The helium market is circa $16bn today and is likely to double from here given the structural growth in demand.
Up until now there have been very few liquid ways to play helium in the equity market, it is less than 5-10% of Linde‚Äôs business despite having the highest growth, margins and ROIC.
Linde, Air Products and Air Liquide trade on average multiples of 25x 2025 PE and 15x EV/EBITDA
 
ASPI has been tracking Renergen for over 3 years and is buying it today at a fraction of its underlying value, in fact less than 10cents in the dollar to the Sproule independent NPV of $2.3bn.
Since the NPV was calculated in 2021, helium prices are up over 150%.
 
There are significant revenue and cost synergies which APSI can utilise in buying this business.
 
ASPI has signed a term sheet with a large institutional investor for $30m to provide the cash to get this project to $8m of ebitda for 2026, making it very accretive from next year.
The DFC (US govt) and other lenders are providing $750m of low-rate debt to complete phase 2 of the project and help the newco produce over $300m of EBITDA by 2030.
 
Last night ASPI announced a definitive agreement with Terra Power for 15mtu of HALEU pa for 10 years. 
The QLE spin off will take place in the 2H of 2025.
 

The webinar will be well worth listening to.

https://ir.aspisotopes.com/news-events/press-releases/detail/62/asp-isotopes-inc-to-host-investor-webcast-ontuesday-may

Deal announcement

https://ir.aspisotopes.com/news-events/press-releases/detail/63/asp-isotopes-inc-announces-an-agreement-relating-to-the

 

Transaction Summary
Buyer: ASP Isotopes (ASPI)
Target: Renergen (via acquisition of its equity and assumption of debt)
Total Consideration:
$107.3m equity value shares at $7.52/share (closing price May 19th)
14,270,000 shares = 19% of shares outstanding
Renergen market cap = $60.5m (closing price May 19th)
Renergen assumed debt of $54.5m
Renergen EV = $115m
Total bid with ASPI assuming all debt = $161.8m
Valuation Context:
40% premium to the Enterprise Value of the business
<10% of the latest $2.3bn independently evaluated NPV ‚Äì which is only 9% of the total estimated gas in place
~70% discount to the $530m implied valuation in a December 2023 transaction with a South African Private Equity Fund
<10% of the latest $2.3bn independently evaluated NPV ‚Äì which is only 9% of the total estimated gas in place
Renergen shares are down -85% from their peak in March, 2022
Funding Structure:
Phase 1C completion (~$30m) to be funded from ASPI's $61.9m balance sheet cash as of December 31st, 2024
Phase 1C would generate >$25m in annual revenues and ~$8.5m in EBITDA
Phase 2 funding de-risked:
$500m low-interest loan from the US DFC at a very attractive interest rate
$250m loan from Standard Bank of South Africa
 
Timing:
Phase 1C completion targeted for 2Q 2026
Full Phase 2 commercial ramp-up by 2030
Strategic Highlights
1. Entry into the Global Helium Market via a High-Grade Asset
Renergen owns a vast helium field, among the highest-grade globally, ranging from 2-12%, with the average of 3.4% being >10x global average.
Helium is a non-substitutable input across critical sectors: semiconductors, MRI scanners, energy (nuclear and solar), and rocketry.
ASPI enters a market forecast to grow at 8.3% CAGR to $32bn by 2032.
Helium prices have appreciated by over 20% CAGR over the last decade and have suffered four global shortages since 2006.
2. Underpriced Strategic Asset with Proven Government Backing
ASPI acquires the asset at <10% of its NPV and well below comparable private equity valuations.
The US DFC‚Äôs $500m loan commitment and a recent South African court win further de-risk the opportunity and enhance upside.
The DFC loan rate is 5.25% versus the current South African government borrowing rate of 11.5% reflects the critical nature of the asset and associated risks.
Renergen‚Äôs relationship with the US Government could provide ASPI a geopolitical and commercial edge.
3. Value Creation Through Cost Synergies and Energy Advantage
Renergen‚Äôs access to ultra-cheap gas/LNG (~$0.35/mcf) allows ASPI to reduce isotope production costs by up to 94%.
Shared infrastructure, personnel, and operations create significant cost and revenue synergies.
ASPI will apply its proven cost discipline and project execution to enhance asset performance.
Operational Outlook
Phase 1C
Completion cost: $30m
Funding: ASP Isotopes Balance Sheet Cash
EBITDA upon completion: $8.5m annually
Multiple: ~16.5x 2026E EBITDA
Phase 2
Target EBITDA:
$300m in 2030
EV/EBIDTA 0.54x 2030E
Market and Customer Synergies
Semiconductors & AI ‚Äì 24% of total helium demand growing at >11% CAGR for the next 5 years
Renergen‚Äôs helium is essential for chip etching and cooling.
ASPI‚Äôs isotopes (e.g., Si-28) are critical to quantum computing.
Combined entity becomes a strategic, dual-source supplier to major US and global semiconductor firms.
Medical ‚Äì 25% of helium demand
Renergen: helium for MRI machines.  The MRI market is approx. $7.5bn growing at 6.5% CAGR driven by ageing population, a growing middle class and the growth in sport and fitness.
ASPI: isotopes (Yb-176, C-14) for diagnostics
Creates full-chain medical imaging and nuclear medicine offering.
Nuclear Power ‚Äì 10% of helium demand
Helium is used as coolant in HTGRs/SMRs.
ASPI also supplies enriched nuclear fuel.
Combined offering increases relevance to next-gen nuclear developers.
Aerospace ‚Äì 18% of helium demand
NASA‚Äôs Artemis program requires 3.2mcf per SLS launch.
Each Space X Starship and Falcon-9 Heavy launch is estimated to consume around 14-18% of global daily helium production ‚Äì 106 Falcon-9 launches in 2024
Geographic and Strategic Expansion
Austin, Texas HQ provides ASPI direct access to the US semiconductor corridor.
Johannesburg office strengthens presence in Africa, supports operational scale-up.
South African listing offers local investors immediate exposure to ASPI via Renergen stock.
Additional Benefits
Enhances ASPI‚Äôs profile as a critical materials company, increasing appeal to institutional investors.
Expanded R&D capabilities and global customer footprint.
Management has a track record of on-the-ground oversight and successful project delivery in South Africa.
Timing is optimal: share price low, recent court case win, Phase 1 progress, and strategic financing secured.
Conclusion
ASPI‚Äôs acquisition of Renergen offers a compelling combination of undervalued strategic assets, secure funding, and synergistic product and customer overlap.
It is a rare chance to enter a growing, non-substitutable market at a steep discount with meaningful upside in scale, margin, and relevance.
The acquisition firmly positions ASPI as a diversified, indispensable player in next-generation industrial, medical, and energy systems.
The significant growth potential of QLE (HALEU), PET Labs (Medical), and an Industrial Gases business that now includes helium, means ASPI is going to be a much bigger company which significantly widens its investor universe.
Paul Mann, the CEO of ASP Isotopes, remains focused on building a company with recurring revenues, high and sustainable margins and ROIC.

[22/05/2025, 11:14:15] ~‚ÄØAndrew Cawker: The summary last few paragraphs:- 

‚ÄúThe Bank of Japan‚Äôs colossus of a balance sheet represents one of the biggest threats to financial stability in Japan and around the world. A rise in yields represents a far from trivial loss to the BOJ‚Äôs $4 trillion of JGBs, accounting for almost 80% of its balance sheet.
No problem, you might say, for a central bank with potentially limitless capital. But the market is not stupid: that loss will eventually be patched over with freshly printed, inflation-stoking money, leading to more JGB selling. In extremis, the BOJ ends up owning the whole JGB market, and the yen becomes the primary mechanism of adjustment.
As domestic investors lose money and financial risks rise, the likelihood is that some of Japan‚Äôs huge net creditor position with the rest of the world is repatriated, leading to asset declines worldwide, especially in the US and Europe.
The majority of investors and consumers in Japan have never had to contend with inflation much above 1% for most of their adult lives. But belatedly or not, when they move to preserve their purchasing power the impact on inflation and yields ‚Äî amplified by the BOJ‚Äôs duration-laden balance sheet ‚Äî has the potential to be systemic. And it won‚Äôt just be Japan‚Äôs problem.‚Äù

[23/05/2025, 10:35:52] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: A long winded note but this is perhaps the best thing I have read on what we are seeing in US nuclear and well worth a read ‚Äé<This message was edited>
[23/05/2025, 10:36:07] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: ‚ÄúA tactic that drags on too long becomes a drag.‚Äù‚ÄîSaul Alinsky

President Dwight D. Eisenhower was the original¬†driving force¬†behind the creation of the US civilian nuclear power sector. The vast majority of the current fleet of¬†94 operating reactors¬†in the country can be traced back to his personal leadership, beginning with the formation of the Atomic Energy Commission (AEC) in 1954. The AEC was charged with weapons development, safety regulations, and‚Äîcritically‚Äîencouraging private investment in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, especially for electric power. The subsequent two decades saw Eisenhower‚Äôs vision carried out with military discipline as the AEC partnered with industry to facilitate the construction of new reactors.

Ironically, things came to a grinding halt after the energy crisis of 1973. One might have expected the oil embargo to motivate the US to accelerate its civilian nuclear ambitions. Instead, the¬†Energy Reorganization Act of 1974¬†effectively abolished the AEC and transferred regulatory oversight to the newly formed Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). The NRC‚Äôs mandate was limited strictly to regulation and safety, while promotional objectives were deemphasized. It didn‚Äôt take long for the new regime to effectively halt new reactor construction in the country.

End of an era, beginning of an error | NRC

The main weapon of the NRC is the linear no-threshold (LNT) model‚Äîan unscientific ethos that treats all exposure to radiation, no matter how minute, as both dangerous and cumulative. In other words, there is no threshold below which otherwise insignificant exposures are considered harmless. Combined with the risk-averse bureaucrat mindset and you get this astonishing result: only two of the current fleet of US reactors were approved and built under the auspices of the NRC.

For anti-nuclear Malthusian environmentalists, the LNT model is ideal. It allows them to actively stunt the creation and distribution of energy abundance while shielding themselves behind the guise of safety and alleged expertise. Zero is an emotional number and when any amount of radiation is viewed as inherently bad, the complete absence of exposure is treated as inherently good, regardless of the positive tradeoffs foregone as a consequence.

For evidence, look no further than the medical industry where controlled radiation exposure can be incredibly powerful in treating sick patients. In diagnostics, radiation allows doctors to see inside the body with remarkable detail in a non-invasive manner. It is also used in various treatments, most commonly in the targeted destruction of cancer cells. Despite the medically beneficial attributes of radiation, its use in healthcare is greatly impeded by the LNT mindset. Patients arrive at clinics with unfounded fears that lead to avoidance of care. Excessive regulatory costs steer providers toward suboptimal treatment strategies that avoid radiation altogether. Innovation is stifled, as scientists and medical companies proactively avoid exploring the beneficial aspects of the technology. This is from a recent and scathing editorial published in¬†The Journal of Nuclear Medicine¬†last August:

‚ÄúHad the scientific community not adhered to the LNT model but instead explored radiation hormesis in clinical trials when it was proposed in the 1980s by Luckey, adoption of radiation hormesis might have led to reduction in cancer deaths by around 20%. This would have translated to preventing nearly 2 million cancer deaths in 2022 alone, given the staggering global toll of 9.7 million cancer deaths that year. Thus, the decision of advisory bodies to persist with the LNT model, despite published evidence supporting radiation hormesis, may have contributed to millions of preventable cancer deaths over recent decades.‚Äù

Amid the flurry of executive actions undertaken in the early days of President Donald Trump‚Äôs second administration, hopeful signs are emerging that the US may finally discard the destructive LNT framework. LNT is wholly incompatible with both his US energy dominance agenda and the military‚Äôs desire to win the artificial intelligence (AI) race‚Äîand it is this second objective that may provide Trump with the legal cover needed to reverse five decades of deeply flawed policy. Let‚Äôs explore why and gauge the odds of success.

On February 18, Trump signed¬†Executive Order 14215, titled¬†Ensuring Accountability for All Agencies. The order begins by noting that the US Constitution vests all executive power in the President alone, who ‚Äúin turn is regularly elected by and accountable to the American people.‚Äù It then outlines how independent agencies, including the NRC, have effectively usurped presidential authority and oversight:

‚ÄúHowever, previous administrations have allowed so-called ‚Äòindependent regulatory agencies‚Äô to operate with minimal Presidential supervision. These regulatory agencies currently exercise substantial executive authority without sufficient accountability to the President, and through him, to the American people. Moreover, these regulatory agencies have been permitted to promulgate significant regulations without review by the President.

These practices undermine such regulatory agencies' accountability to the American people and prevent a unified and coherent execution of Federal law. For the Federal Government to be truly accountable to the American people, officials who wield vast executive power must be supervised and controlled by the people's elected President.‚Äù

The expert class of do-gooders reacted to this order with predictable horror. Allison McFarlane, who was appointed to the NRC by former President Barack Obama in 2012 and became its chair in 2013, took to the pages of the¬†Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists¬†to¬†sound the alarm:

‚ÄúIn the past, the president and Congress, which has oversight capacity on the regulators, stayed at arm‚Äôs length from the regulators‚Äô decisions. This was meant to keep them isolated, ensuring their necessary independence from any outside interference. Trump‚Äôs executive order implies there are no longer independent regulators in the United States.

Independent regulators should not only be free from government and industry meddling; they also need to be adequately staffed with competent experts and have the budget to operate efficiently. They also need to be able to shut down facilities such as nuclear power plants that are not operating safely, according to regulations. To do this, they need government to support their independent decisions and rulemaking.‚Äù
Two weeks ago, drafts of potential follow-on orders building upon EO 14215 were leaked to various legacy media outlets, including¬†The Washington Post¬†and¬†The New York Times. In¬†The Washington Post, we learn that at least one of the drafts offers a clear diagnosis of the root cause of the country‚Äôs nuclear stagnation:

‚ÄúThe NRC does not view its duty as promoting safe, abundant nuclear energy with regulatory clarity, flexibility and speed but rather insulating Americans from the most remote risks without regard for the domestic or geopolitical costs of its risk aversion.‚Äù
For the clearest indication of Trump‚Äôs intent to radically accelerate the proper buildout of new reactors in the country, we turn to¬†The New York Times:

‚ÄúThe draft orders say the United States has fallen behind China in expanding nuclear power and call for a ‚Äòwholesale revision‚Äô of federal safety regulations to make it easier to build new plants. They envision the Department of Defense taking a prominent role in ordering reactors and installing them on military bases.

They would also set a goal of quadrupling the size of the nation‚Äôs fleet of nuclear power plants, from nearly 100 gigawatts of electric capacity today to 400 gigawatts by 2050. One gigawatt is enough to power nearly 1 million homes‚Ä¶

One option under consideration would be to designate certain A.I. data centers as ‚Äòdefense critical infrastructure‚Äô and allow them to be powered by reactors built on Department of Energy facilities, which may allow projects to avoid review by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.‚Äù

The concept of building nuclear-powered data centers on military bases is‚Äîto state it frankly‚Äîbrilliant. Presumably, Trump will lean heavily on the authority afforded to the president by the¬†Defense Production Act, among other justifications. As we have long chronicled in these pages, China is much further along in the AI race than most believe. And not by coincidence, the country is also set to¬†surpass¬†the US in installed nuclear power capacity:

‚ÄúChina has approved plans for building 10 nuclear reactors for 200 billion yuan ($27.7 billion), putting the country on track to push its nuclear power generation capacity past the US to become the world's largest by 2030.‚Äù

For all the controversy surrounding the man and his approach to governing, if President Trump succeeds in reining in the NRC, eliminating the LNT model, and catalyzing the construction of dozens of new nuclear power reactors across the US, he will bequeath future generations of Americans a legacy on par with that of Eisenhower. Here‚Äôs to hoping he gets it done.

Nuclear energy stocks soared in premarket trading Friday ahead of the prospective signing of executive orders by President Donald Trump.

The new orders are expected to kickstart the production of nuclear power in the U.S. by easing the regulatory process on approvals for new reactors and directing the Departments of Energy and Defense to identify federal lands for nuclear deployment, streamlining the current process under the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

Donald, is there really noone giving you intelligent perspective when you think this stuff up on the hoof?  Clearly not..

Nutstuff would assert that it is impossible to enforce any tariff on Bitcoin using blockchain data. 
Trump clearly has zero understanding of mining pool architecture and how transactions and blocks work. It's like trying to tax email based on where the server that processed it is based, its just technically incoherent.
Most blocks are produced by mining pools, which aggregate hashpower from contributors globally. The entity submitting the block (the pool) is not necessarily the one that did the actual hashing.
A block mined by a U.S.-based pool may include contributions from:
China, Russia, Venezuela. Unknown IPs via VPN/Tor. Put another way, imposing a tariff on non-U.S. mined Bitcoin is like a 19th-century government trying to levy a tax on foreign wind blowing across its borders.
Wind doesn‚Äôt recognise national boundaries. It moves freely, driven by natural forces beyond political control. You can‚Äôt fence it in, label it ‚Äúdomestic,‚Äù or charge it for arriving from overseas. The very attempt reveals a deep misunderstanding of its nature and the futility of using old tools on a new reality.
Bitcoin is digital wind, Borderless, Permissionless. Composed of math, not matter. Its value and motion arise from global consensus, not national decree.
Trying to apply tariffs or import duties to Bitcoin based on where they were mined is a relic of a world where power was enforced by controlling ports, rails, or oil wells. Bitcoin routes around all of that. The harder you try to bend it to old systems, the more it simply reflects their irrelevance.
[24/05/2025, 10:16:32] ~‚ÄØGR: Taxing crass stupidity could be the solution to eradicate national debt

[31/05/2025, 15:20:37] Nick finegold: From Nick L at OWL 

Last week, Bill Ackman enjoyed a big boost as shares of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac surged following President Trump‚Äôs announcement plans to take these government-controlled mortgage giants public. Ackman sees this restructuring as a historic opportunity to unlock significant value, estimating a potential $300 billion windfall.

Whilst Pershing Square‚Äôs shares have rallied 8% in May, the fund‚Äôs NAV has been growing even faster. As of Friday, PSH LN closed at ¬£39.14, representing a 34% discount to its NAV of ¬£59.28. I‚Äôve watched this stock closely since I helped list it in 2014, when its discount ranged from around 15-20% during stable markets to nearly 40% during periods of heightened volatility. Notably, in 2016 and before the 2020 market correction, the discount approached near-zero levels.

Adding to the positive outlook, asset manager Tidal Trust recently filed to launch an ETF based on Ackman‚Äôs concentrated portfolio, called the ‚ÄúVista Shares Pershing Square Select ETF ‚Äù further underscoring the market‚Äôs optimism surrounding Ackman‚Äôs strategy.

Owning UBER, HHH, CMG, BN, UMG, QSR as well as Fannie and Freddie at 35% discount isn't a bad trade.

[01/06/2025, 12:14:33] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: URA is a broader nuclear etf which includes nuclear infra + fuel 

URNM is dedicated to miners of uranium 

URNJ is for junior miners (we prefer to own Skyharbour Resources as they have interests in 36 assets in the Athabasca Basin so you get ETF style exposure but with single stock upside) 

GCL - focused primarily on North American miners where we think there is premium given the uranium deficit in the west far exceeds that of the East

Really depends what you want but URA is the broadest for the nuclear theme ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[02/06/2025, 07:14:37] ~‚ÄØKatie Jackson: *US Steel & Tariffs: ArcelorMittal Club Stock - US exposure exempt and secured against Nippon-US merger*

As we see Asian steel makers off this morning on the tariff news over the weekend, worth remembering that‚Ä¶ 

AM/NS Calvert in Alabama, a joint venture between ArcelorMittal and Nippon Steel, produce steel within the U.S. and are therefore exempt from these expanded import tariffs.

ArcelorMittal entered agreement with Nippon Steel in Oct ‚Äò24 to take full control of AM/NS Calvert JV (currently 50/50 with Nippon Steel) for $1 if NSC‚Äôs U.S. Steel deal closes. NSC also agreed to inject ~$900m into Calvert pre-sale to address antitrust.

Sources: 
https://corporate.arcelormittal.com/media/press-releases/nippon-steel-agrees-to-sell-its-interest-in-calvert-to-arcelormittal-at-the-request-of-nsc-pursuant-to-its-agreed-acquisition-of-us-steel?utm_source=chatgpt.com ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[02/06/2025, 19:49:58] Nick finegold: From Adam 


Morgan Stanley
Research
Image
Tesla Inc (TSLA.O)  Analyst Top Pick
American Autonomy: US Policy Considerations for the AI Robot Era
Read Full Report
(PDF: 11 Pages)
North America
Stock Rating   Overweight
Price Target   $410.00
Adam Jonas, CFA, Daniela M Haigian, William Tackett, CFA
June 2, 2025
From the perspective of physical machines, the next 5 or 10 years with AI could bring more innovation than a century pre-AI. Prepare for the tech to develop far faster than the policies can keep up, uncovering areas of risk prior to unlocking the opportunity.
I'd greatly appreciate your support for the Morgan Stanley Auto & Auto Parts team in this year's All-America Extel survey. Respectfully, AJ.

How to vote: To request a ballot, please go to https://www.extelinsights.com/voting and select ‚ÄúAll-American Research Team‚Äù.

Image

US made the imposition, China's now in pole position. If it's not yet totally clear that China is in the lead on agentic robots, you won't need to wait long. According to our discussions with subject matter experts in robotics and autonomy, China's proximity to a highly advanced, vertically integrated supply chain helps pad its lead in robotics.

Hope you'll not be too annoyed, with burgers flipped by humanoid. AI robots will come in countless form factors, but the human-shaped robot may be the most profound and fastest adopting 'shape' given its ability to learn (by imitating us) and integrating into a human world 'brown-fielded' for bipedal ambulation and opposable thumbs.

Advantages we need to gain, in battle for the human brain. We want to avoid a situation where the humans get dumber faster than the robots get smarter. The race for AI robotic supremacy is a contest for the best human minds working across the knowledge economy (bits/bytes), the physical economy (atoms/photons) and manufacturing world.

Best investment for a nation, close the gap on education. According to the World Population Review, the United States ranked 31st in ‚Äòeducational rank‚Äô which placed it between Hungary and Taiwan. South Korea, Denmark and The Netherlands got the top 3 spots. China ranked 13th in this survey, just after the UK.

Talent pool in dislocation, training for a new vocation. On Tesla's 4Q24 conference call, Elon Musk stated: "But in general, for talented Americans... we need to make manufacturing cool again in America. And like, I honestly think people should move from like law and finance into manufacturing. That's my honest opinion."

A lead in AI innovation, relies on thoughtful immigration. Elon Musk has been a consistent advocate for skilled immigration, arguing that talented immigrants are crucial for driving innovation and economic growth in the U.S., especially in fields like science, technology, and artificial intelligence. Currently 4 of the ‚ÄòMag 7‚Äô companies are led by CEOs who were immigrants to the US.

Imports for so long the rule, can manufacturing be cool? For the US to remain competitive in advanced robotics, it must at least slow (if not reverse) the 8-decade decline in manufacturing. Physical AI requires a persistent and rapid iteration between data capture, training and hardware optimization/manufacturing. Manufacturing expertise and critical material sourcing strategies require a wholesale re-evaluation, in our view.

I hate to drone on for eternity... but drones ensure security. China makes more drones in 1 day than the US makes in a year. The ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict continues to show the deterministic role of drones on the battlefield. Elon Musk recently stated on the 1Q25 conference call: ‚Äú‚Ä¶any country that cannot manufacture its own drones is doomed to be the vassal state of any country that can. And we can't ‚Äì America cannot currently manufacture its own drones. Let that sink in."

AI's growth in GPUs, demands a source of BTUs. A successful development of US robotic capability must go hand-in-hand with a diverse and resilient energy policy. As the robots propagate and scale, the energy demands from training VLA foundation models will increase. We estimate just the physical work conducted by 1bn humanoids (excluding training) may require >4,000 TWh of incremental annual electricity demand - roughly equal to 1 full US electric grid.

State AV patchwork is a fear, caught in headlights like a deer. In a recent discussion with US Transport Secretary Sean Duffy, Elon Musk stated, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôd be wonderful for the United States to have a national set of rules for autonomous driving instead of 50 state-specific standards.‚Äù We believe rapid improvement in AV tech both inside and outside of the US may accelerate Congressional attention on this issue.

Our rivals are not standing still, if we do nothing others will. On the 1Q25 conference call, Elon Musk stated: ‚ÄúWith respect to humanoid robots, I don't think there's any company in any country that can match Tesla. So and then now I'm a little concerned of that on the leaderboard, ranks 2 through 10 will be Chinese companies‚Ä¶‚Äù

Resiliency is ours to gain, re-architect the supply chain. The US economy runs on magnets. High end magnets require rare earths (NdPr, Dysprosium, Terbium). China controls 65% of mining/88% of refining of rare earths, exposing US national security vulnerabilities in the time of tariffs. Policies must determine what can/should be made on shore, near-shore and still with China.

Take a look around our shelves, we can't do it by ourselves. While there is clearly room to address critical imbalances and lopsided over-dependencies in key areas (from manufacturing to rare earth processing), we believe China will play a continuing important role in the re-architecting of a sustainable US autonomous future. Industrial and geopolitical rivalry does not exclude a healthy level of mutual economic cooperation. We look for China JVs and Chinese-derived car technology coming to US shores by end of decade.

For the safety of our nation, there's a need for regulation. The intersection of AI and robotics will transform the economy, geopolitics and societal structure. A host of moral, legal and ethical considerations will be brought to the fore. Comparisons between the propagation of AI and nuclear proliferation are accurate, in our view, and will require a robust and flexible regulatory framework to balance innovation, national security and public health and safety.

Robots not a want but need, if not TSLA who will lead? While there is a growing number of US efforts to push the boundaries of physical AI, we struggle to think of any other company as well positioned as Tesla in terms of data, robotics, energy, AI, manufacturing and supporting infrastructure (from fleet fulfillment to communications network, etc). We would love to see more competition for Tesla in these areas. In the meantime, we reiterate Tesla as our ‚ÄòTop Pick‚Äô in US autos.

Image

URANIUM: STOCKS/ POSITIONS: 
See todays Press release:
LTBR US just annointed: While the US governmentS consideration of providing highly enriched uranium for Lightbridge to use in FAST testing was under consideration prior to the executive orders, the government‚Äôs decision has now JUST been made!
Lightbridge will benefit from the groundbreaking FAST ("Fission Accelerated Steady-state Test") method using highly enriched uranium‚Äîa rare and tightly controlled government resource. It represents immediate implementation of Trump's directive to accelerate nuclear innovation.

URANIUM/ NUCLEAR EXPOSURES: STOCKS: LTBR (Nutstuff likes as this is Mkt cap is still tiny; $326m and is about existing and future fuel also have to think some Sell-side sponsorship shows up soon!) also ASPI, alongside RR/LN Rolls Royce (UK) OKLO & BWXT also some SPUT. If its a production play, then UEC US. 

The path to US self sufficiency in enrichment by 2030 is what matters, more investments will be needed beyond that. Conversion remains the main bottleneck, with limited near-term additions although the executive orders call for a plan to expand both conversion and enrichment to be developed by late September. For SMRs, HALEU is advancing but still pre-commercial. Can the Uranium supply chain keep up? Reshoring of the supply chain is a key focus. The US relies on imports for two-thirds of its enrichment and conversion needs, and virtually all mined uranium is sourced externally. The 2023 US mine restarts and new projects, which we estimate could meet ~40% of domestic needs by 2030, with Canada likely filling much of the remainder. Enrichment capacity is also expanding. 
‚ÄúTogether, Trump‚Äôs 2025 energy pivot anchored by the nuclear executive orders and EPA‚Äôs rollback of greenhouse gas rules is profoundly historic. Not just in scale, but in doctrinal ambition. It blows past any previous US energy shift. It is the single biggest US energy strategic realignment since, at least, the 1973 Oil Crisis, and the most aggressive pro-nuclear policy in world history.  No US administration since the Manhattan Project has ever tried to reorganise the nation‚Äôs entire power ecosystem supply chain, education, regulation, financing all at once. Welcome to 2025. You‚Äôre witnessing the birth of a post-climate, post-renewables energy doctrine, where not carbon but grid dominance becomes the organising principle of American power policy.‚Äù

[04/06/2025, 11:35:48] ~‚ÄØMatt H: I had to Chat GPT it: A ‚Äúscalded cat chart‚Äù is not a standard or widely recognized term in data analysis, finance, or statistics. However, the phrase likely comes from the idiom ‚Äúlike a scalded cat,‚Äù which is used to describe something moving very fast or erratically, usually due to shock or pain.

Possible Interpretations:
	1.	Colloquial Nickname for a Chart:
It might be a jargon or slang term used informally (e.g., in finance or tech circles) to describe a chart that shows:
	‚Ä¢	A sudden, sharp movement ‚Äî such as a stock price or metric shooting up (or down) very rapidly.
	‚Ä¢	Data with volatile or erratic behavior, resembling a ‚Äúspooked‚Äù or ‚Äúscalded‚Äù pattern.

[05/06/2025, 10:08:06] ~‚ÄØJB: Uranium Pricing
 
CGN Mining released a new pricing mechanism for the off-take agreement (2026-28) with its parent company.
Under the new mechanism, the proportion of fixed pricing will be reduced to 30% from 40% currently.
Most importantly, the fixed price in 2026E is set at US$94.22/lb (with +4.1% increment per year in 2027E/28E to $98.10 & $102.10), which is way higher than the US$61.78/lb in 2023 (with annual increment of 3.5% in 2024/25) under the current mechanism  vs current spot of $70.38 and term of $80.
[05/06/2025, 10:24:26] Adam Clib: üî•A new trade idea - If you are bullish on Uranium: URA FPüî•

Its in GBP, issued by Marex and a 2-year term.

There is no downside, except issuer risk.
The upside is capped at 40%
There is rebate of 18% if it closes higher.

So,
If in two years it's up 40%  you get back your capital and 40% return.
If in two years its up 45%, you get back 18% plus your capital
If its down you get back 100%

.  Please ping me if you want more information. üôèüèº

WISE exists as the very inverse of Dick Turpins cousins in most airports and Banks when dealing with Foreign exchange! ( picture below!) Banks and others foreign exchange charges are a massive hidden tax on SME‚Äôs and individuals. Customers of WISE save @2% per transaction on  WISE.   
I see commentary out there that Wise could achieve a valuation 8x its current market cap if was U.S.-listed! Wise specialises in low-cost, transparent cross-border payments, processing ¬£118.5 billion in transactions in FY24 and saving customers ¬£1.8 billion compared to banks. (Honestly HOW can big banks allow themselves to have their lunch eaten like this?!!!) U.S. peers like PayPal and Block offer broader services (e.g., domestic payments, merchant services), but Wise‚Äôs focus on cross-border transfers (3.5% of a $26 trillion market) suggests significant growth potential. Wise‚Äôs partnerships with BlackRock, Monzo, and Google Pay via Wise Platform enhance its scalability, unlike some U.S. peers reliant on direct-to-consumer models.Wise faces competition from Revolut, WorldRemit, and U.S. players like PayPal and Western Union. [06/06/2025, 21:02:35] ~‚ÄØSSCOOK: For those looking for a timely opportunity in an out favor idiosyncratic stock, in an under-owned sector then you should have a look at Unite Group (UTG LN). UTG is a one of kind hard asset play the U.K. property sector as the most liquid option (> ¬£5bn market cap) for investing in the UK student housing property sector. 

1.. What makes it a timely idea? Is the announcement yesterday of their non-binding > ¬£ 700 mil takeover bid for Empiric Student Property (ESP LN) a smaller listed player. Empiric has agreed to open the books to UTG, who has until July 3rd to make a formal offer or not.  The deal would expand UTG‚Äôs base of beds by 13% and the size of its portfolio by 18%. By my math the deals terms have been structured so this NTA neutral for UTG before any synergy assumptions are included. All in it values ESP LN @ a <10% discount to NTA and at today‚Äôs prices implies a take-out price of >105 or only + 2% from ESP LN‚Äôs close today. So the play here is clearly on the UTG side as bigger/better niche hard asset play and ESP brings to UTG some interesting student assets to the table (post grad initiative) and offers a lot of capital recycling optionality for UTG to monetize. 

2. Out of favor - pretty much describes the European property sector as a whole which has massively underperformed  (SX86P -1% vs SX5E +57% and FTSE 250 +14%) since ECB/BOE started raising rates in July 2022. UTG has been much worse than the SX86P (-21% since July 2022) and has been de-rated by 30-50%(depending on valuation metric) from the multiples it traded on prior to the central bank tightening cycles kicking off. This is despite UTG delivering +10% CGR cash earnings in the past 3 years (22-24). UTG trades 0.8x NTA (ex DPS), > 5.4% FFO yield, offers 4.5% dividend yield. 

3. Strong fundamentals - UTG has a lot of idiosyncratic levers at its disposal to create value: an attractive portfolio (Russell Group, London Uni assets); profitable leases (nomination contracts, CPI/RPI linkers); a new development angle in 2026-28 (adds +12% beds); a strong recapitalized balance sheet (18% LTV, ICR >6x); receding utility cost headwinds; two key JV‚Äôs - one with GIC as their partner; and a new CEO from January 2024.

4. Macro tailwind turning point ? Elevated interest rate levels remain a dark cloud over real estate sector sentiment in EUR/UK. Much of this headwind is already priced in and UTG has passed the worst of the portfolio adverse MTM from cap rate expansion in 2023 and 2024. This leaves embedded upside risk if the UK 5 year swap rates can make a healthy move back well below the 4% level (currently 4.10%). This is the key top-down catalyst that will tempt the generalists to pile back in! 

5. Stalled UK UNI biz? There has been a lot of chatter about subdued  1-3% in student growth #‚Äôs (both Brits and international) for UK unis. Lots of negative news-flow on this. Seems pretty well flagged UTG‚Äôs within in the 97%-98% occupancy expectations and this is where UTG having 93% of its beds in Russell Groups Unis kicks in. What Trump is doing to international students who want to come to college in the US has to be somewhat helpful for the UK Unis‚Ä¶impact TBD.  

6. Student housing structural growth opportunity  - longer term fundaments of the student housing property market are pretty favorable - with constrained supply and the opportunity to form JV partnerships with the Unis who are poor property landlords but yet still control 45% of the PBSA supply. This is who UTG is targeting for future value creation - like the 2k bed JV they have done in Newcastle already. UTG is projecting a ~ 7.3% YOC on this Uni JV vs 5.1% for existing portfolio! Watch this space.

[07/06/2025, 14:23:27] ~‚ÄØRobin Maxwell: Noteworthy as a sign money returning to the property theme is the recent performance of Supermarket Income REIT (SUPR - one of my core portfolio holdings) which during Covid traded at a premium to NAV only to fall to a near 30% discount by early 2025. There has been similar recovery in some other REITs although interestingly big daddies of the sector like Vonovia in Germany have not followed through after an initial recovery in 2024. I suspect capital growth from here at SUPR may become trickier without an NAV re-rating but the yield is still highly attractive for those looking for income. [12/06/2025, 08:46:33] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: So, WPP; ‚ÄúA MASSIVE WHAT IF‚Äù?!  How about a Digital Pivot?!
As WPP's CEO exits, a lot of folks either forget and/or dismiss the withering and sunset of AppNexus/Xandr. A massive acquisition of tech that was supposed to be a known entity (ad tech) but as they are finding out, AI is a wildly different animal.  It will be fascinating to see how this plays out.
WPP is a lumbering legacy advertising group with ~$15B in annual revenue, but structurally under threat from:
	‚Ä¢	In-housing of creative/media functions
	‚Ä¢	The dominance of Google/Facebook‚Äôs ad platforms
	‚Ä¢	AI commoditizing creative production
	‚Ä¢	Margin erosion from consultancy competition (Accenture Song, etc.)
Sacking Mark Read signals the board knows incrementalism isn‚Äôt working. So here‚Äôs the radical BTC treasury thesis, spelled out: BLUE-SKY THINKING:

How about a Simple Digital Pivot Thesis?: From Ad Conglomerate to Bitcoin Treasury Vehicle: WPP becomes a publicly listed Bitcoin holding and infrastructure company, using its remaining free cash flow, asset sales, and balance sheet strength to rotate fully into BTC.
Mechanics:
	‚Ä¢	Step 1: Fire sale of legacy ad units / roll-up non-core subsidiaries
	‚Ä¢	Step 2: Reallocate proceeds + cash flows into BTC
	‚Ä¢	Step 3: Signal a Saylor-style ‚Äúnever sell BTC‚Äù strategy
	‚Ä¢	Step 4: Rebrand as a capital-efficient holding vehicle for the Bitcoin economy (Bitcoin media, Bitcoin infra, etc.)
Rationale:
	‚Ä¢	The market rewards BTC-aligned equities with extreme mNAV premiums (MSTR, Metaplanet, ALTBG)
	‚Ä¢	WPP has brand and balance sheet optionality
	‚Ä¢	Being early to the ‚Äúadvertising is obsolete, digital hard money is the brand‚Äù thesis gives it cult-like backing
Outcome:
	‚Ä¢	WPP becomes the first FTSE-listed BTC treasury company
	‚Ä¢	Re-rates from 5‚Äì7x EBITDA to 1.5‚Äì3x BTC-per-share premium
	‚Ä¢	Institutional demand from UK investors unable to buy raw BTC but able to buy listed BTC proxy.

[12/06/2025, 11:50:07] Nick finegold: Safety
Waymo regularly publishes safety reports.[132] Waymo is required by the California DMV to report the number of incidents where the safety driver took control for safety reasons. Some incidents were not reported when simulations indicated that the car would have stopped safely on its own.[133] In 2023, Waymo claimed only 3 crashes with injuries over 7.1 million miles driven, nearly twice as safe as a human driver.[134] A 2025 peer-reviewed study by Waymo researchers found that collisions with bicycles and motorcycles were 82% less frequent for Waymo cars than for human drivers, and that collisions with pedestrians were 92% less frequent.[135]

Why do I care ?

[12/06/2025, 15:57:22] Nick finegold: For all those long defence stocks . 

Ukraine's defense industry says the fight against Russia has shown it that the West's approach to weapons is wrong
By Sin√©ad Baker
Jun 11, 2025, 10:47 AM BST
A Ukrainian industry rep has said the West is approaching weaponry for major conflicts the wrong way.
Countries need a lot of pretty good weapons instead of only a handful of excellent ones, he said.
It's a warning that industry officials, experts, and some European defense ministers have echoed.
Ukraine's defense industry is urging the West to abandon its longtime fixation on high-end, expensive weaponry in favor of cheaper, mass-produced arms, the kind needed to survive and win a grinding war of attrition against an adversary like Russia.

[16/06/2025, 10:00:52] ~‚ÄØRich McDonald: I think I‚Äôve got a video which explains the methodology (don‚Äôt shoot the messenger!) but essentially;  
- Mkt cap starts small with some bitcoin enthusiasts happy to buy stock at a 10x multiple to what the assets will be‚Ä¶ because let‚Äôs be honest - crypto investors don‚Äôt really pay attention to any fundamentals anyway 
- In the early days, sub ¬£100m mkt cap, ‚Å†this allows the company to do raise after raise at a 7-10x multiple of their bitcoin +cash holdings (MNAV). 
- ‚Å†because they issue equity at such high multiples, shareholders only get diluted by 7% whereas the MNAV increases by 30-50% 
- ‚Å†This means what seems like a crazy multiple now 10:1, quickly becomes a 1:1 mkt cap to Bitcoin within a matter of weeks and then in theory continues to grow like Metaplanet (>$5bln) or obvs Strategy
- ‚Å†As the market cap grows in theory the Premium to MNAV should come in‚Ä¶ 6x , 5x , 3x but the market is still pricing in confidence that it‚Äôs early days, hence the 9x still on SWC as he has managed to get listed in the US now as well.
[16/06/2025, 10:04:54] ~‚ÄØRich McDonald: That‚Äôs the reason they are buying these treasury models instead of just Bitcoin - but then you had the added intricacies of BTC going up, and bringing in Convertible debt into the picture - which is why Strategy is so genius. 
Being short Fiat debt versus Long leveraged, compounding BTC.
[16/06/2025, 10:10:39] ~‚ÄØRich McDonald: Risk warning:
It trades on Aquis - and when people end up wanting out of this thing, there won‚Äôt be any bids and it will look horrific. 
Risks: Multiple compression, Bitcoin dropping, any real small cap risk off,  any FCA commentary on the treasury model or a bit more left field: if there was any unknown limit to how much you can raise in a certain time period without a prospectus.
[16/06/2025, 10:30:44] ~‚ÄØChris Huggins: Thanks Rich. It is exactly as I thought. A scary, but an honest articulation of a ‚Äúgreater fool‚Äù strategy. 

The bet is that the stock rallies , they then raise say ¬£100mm from other valuation agnostic investors at a slightly lower premium (say 5x to the post raise holding of Bitcoin) 

As you say, this stock won‚Äôt trade on any gap down‚Ä¶.so a somewhat terrifying ‚Äúvalley of death‚Äù to cross before the premium normalises. 

Given there is zero moat to this strategy, it feels safer to wait and back the next listed entity who wants to raise equity at a (more modest) premium whilst identifying themselves as a bitcoin treasury player? (Providing the universe of valuation agnostic buyers haven‚Äôt all been exhausted/stopped out) ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[16/06/2025, 17:06:28] ~‚ÄØAdam Calman: What‚Äôs the potential impact of western bombs destroying Iran URAN enrichment capability on prices‚Ä¶?
[16/06/2025, 17:14:27] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: We sent the following to clients this morning:

On Iran: Its uranium inventory, conversion and enrichment capacity is inconsequential to global supply/demand. However, we are monitoring the situation from a nuclear proliferation perspective:

Iran‚Äôs relationship with the IAEA has significantly deteriorated. Despite remaining a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT), the IAEA  has formally declared Iran in breach of its obligations for the first time since 2005. This follows Tehran‚Äôs refusal to clarify the presence of undeclared nuclear material and its broader lack of cooperation with inspectors. In response to the IAEA‚Äôs resolution, Iran has announced it will cease sharing information on nuclear protection measures, effectively curtailing international oversight. At the same time, its stockpile of uranium enriched to 60% has risen by nearly 50%, reported to be 400kg, reaching levels sufficient for multiple nuclear weapons if further enriched. 

It is now being reported that Iran‚Äôs parliament is considering withdrawal from nuclear proliferation treaty. 

This significantly raises the risk of a nuclear arms race in the Middle East. Saudi Arabia has openly indicated it would seek a nuclear deterrent if Iran crosses the threshold, while Israel may accelerate its strategic posture. Other regional powers like Turkey and Egypt could also reassess their long-term security strategies in response, increasing the likelihood of horizontal proliferation.

We believe the situation is likely to encourage strategic, state-sponsored stockpiling of enriched uranium, particularly among regional powers looking to hedge without formally breaching the NPT. Civil nuclear programs, which can be framed as energy diversification, offer a credible cover for building dual-use infrastructure that can quickly shift from civilian to military applications if needed. At the same time, established nuclear states may bolster its forward reserves or fuel capabilities to reinforce deterrence.
[16/06/2025, 17:16:50] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Spot prices +$7 to $76

Key points

Tariffs are just a problem, they cap volumes too.

Italy's *Leonardo* buys a European cybersecurity company - BUT who???

Please submit your answers below‚Ä¶*

https://www.reuters.com/business/media-telecom/italys-leonardo-buys-european-cybersecurity-company-2025-06-17/#:~:text=PARIS%2C%20June%2017%20(Reuters),important%20in%20new%20combat%20systems.

_*no inside info please_ üòá
[17/06/2025, 13:34:01] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: The largest cybersecurity companies in the EU and UK, based on market presence, revenue, innovation, and industry impact.
The European cybersecurity market is fragmented, with a mix of global giants (e.g., Cisco, Palo Alto Networks) and specialized local players. Companies like Darktrace and Sophos stand out for their innovation in AI and endpoint security, while WithSecure and Bitdefender emphasize GDPR compliance and European data sovereignty.

United Kingdom
1. Darktrace (Cambridge, UK)
   - Overview: Founded in 2013, Darktrace is a global leader in AI-driven cybersecurity, specializing in autonomous threat detection and response using its Enterprise Immune System and Cyber AI Analyst.
   - Key Metrics: Over 6,500 customers worldwide, 1,700 employees, and 30+ offices globally. Significant market presence with a focus on real-time threat detection.
   - Services: AI-based threat detection, autonomous response, cloud security, and threat visualization.

2. Sophos (Abingdon, UK)
   - Overview: Established in 1985, Sophos provides next-generation cybersecurity solutions, protecting over 500,000 organizations and millions of consumers in 150+ countries.
   - Key Metrics: Known for endpoint protection, firewalls, and managed detection and response (MDR). Acquired by Thoma Bravo in 2020, with a strong European presence.
   - Services: Antivirus, encryption, network security, XDR, and ransomware protection.

3. NCC Group (Manchester, UK)
   - Overview: A global cybersecurity firm offering services like penetration testing, risk management, and incident response. Advises the UK government on telecom network security.
   - Key Metrics: Operates in 35+ locations worldwide, serving industries like finance, technology, and government.
   - Services: Penetration testing, managed security services, and data protection.

4. Mimecast (London, UK)
   - Overview: Founded in 2003, Mimecast specializes in email security and cyber resilience, with a web-based platform for threat detection and user training.
   - Key Metrics: Generated ¬£2.17 billion in gross value added (GVA) to the UK economy in 2023/24, with a 2015 IPO raising ¬£50.7 million.
   - Services: Email security, data loss prevention, and cybersecurity training.

5. Adarma (Edinburgh, UK)
   - Overview: Formerly ECS Security, Adarma is noted as one of the largest UK-based cybersecurity firms, serving FTSE 350 companies.
   - Key Metrics: Focuses on managed detection and response, zero trust, and cloud security.
   - Services: Managed security services, incident response, and threat monitoring.

Thought this was relevant to the WPP discussion: a Baidu e-commerce livestream featured two AI avatars co-hosting a 6-hour stream. Powered by Baidu‚Äôs ERNIE model, it had 13mn views, generated $8mn GMV, and significantly outsold the real human the avatars were modeled on.
This is real-time, reactive, hyper-personalized engagement. No fatigue, no downtime, and unlimited scalability.
Legacy agencies still think in terms of talent/media buying/campaign cycles. AI-native players operate on models/latency/data flywheels. That difference is only accelerating.
WPP‚Äôs TikTok Symphony partnership might seem forward-looking, but it's still built around roles that are on the verge of being fully replaced by integrated creative and deployment tools. I'm just not convinced WPP is even going to be in the same race. Hopefully they get a tech native CEO in next year but it could be too little too late.

[23/06/2025, 12:21:07] Nick finegold: Pharma Stocks Dip as RFK Jr. Pushes to Rein In Drug Ads
U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary RFK Jr. wants to make it harder and more expensive for pharmaceutical companies to advertise directly to patients. 
His proposals include requiring longer, more detailed risk disclosures in ads, making them costlier and less effective, and removing the tax deductibility of ad expenses for drugmakers. 
Drug advertisements work: A study from USC found that regions with higher ad exposure saw a 6% increase in prescriptions, 70% of which were new.
Pfizer and AbbVie, two of the biggest pharma advertisers, fell 1.7% and 2.3%, respectively, on the news. 
RFK Jr.‚Äôs primary obstacle will be the First Amendment. U.S. courts have consistently ruled since the 1970s that commercial speech, including pharma ads, is protected. He‚Äôll also have to fight an army of lobbyists: The pharmaceutical industry was the top spender on Capitol Hill last year, dispensing close to $400 million.
These policy changes wouldn‚Äôt just affect drugmakers: Pharma ads made up 10% to 12% of total U.S. TV ad revenue last year. Losing that spend would pressure TV networks already in decline.

 	
This would probably be the last nail in the broadcast TV industry‚Äôs coffin. Big picture, this feels like a gift to Alphabet and Meta. That $10 billion in pharma ad spend isn‚Äôt going away. It‚Äôll just get reallocated to digital. Expect a wave of content marketing and native advertising on Instagram and YouTube. The industry will find new ways to push the same products, just with better targeting and lower CPMs. So while this might be good for public health, it‚Äôs definitely bad for cable and great for tech.

On BITCOIN: This is an interesting signal worth watching: 
Yesterday/ June 22nd the BTC hashrate dropped sharply from 886m TH/s to 672m TH/s ‚Äî a 24% fall in a single day. This coincided exactly with the US strike on Iran‚Äôs Fordo nuclear site using 14 bunker busters.
This Raises a legitimate question: Could there have been miners operating off Iranian nuclear power, perhaps as part of a low-AISC setup quietly supporting state revenues?
If so, it would be a textbook case of state-subsidised mining tied to geopolitical energy infrastructure. Nutstuff thinks is worth putting on this on the radar, I am not saying it‚Äôs causal, but the correlation is striking.

A Few thoughts on Bitcoin Treasury: 
‚ÄúOwning the best Bitcoin treasury companies is like holding gold but gold that is wrapped in a shimmering mithril cloak woven from code, resistant to inflation, censorship, and clueless central bankers. It‚Äôs not just a store of value. It‚Äôs Frodo‚Äôs vest in the age of digital warfare. While others are lugging around rusty swords of fiat, you‚Äôre slipping silently through Mordor with sovereign-grade assets on your chest. And instead of Gandalf, you‚Äôve got Saylor whispering in your ear: ‚ÄòFly, you fools‚Äô‚Ä¶ into cold storage.‚Äù 
Now the serious point is: 
We‚Äôre now witnessing a bifurcation in BTC treasury companies: those with deep capital markets experience, and those without.
The most effective are fusing the ethos of Bitcoiners with the structuring skills of financial engineers. These teams understand both the cryptographic hardness of Bitcoin and the leverage that comes from balance sheet optimization, convertible instruments, and secondary market signaling. It‚Äôs the fusion of community and capital, underpinned by hard money principles. That‚Äôs where the real alchemy lies.
Bitcoin is basically destroying the meme coin by becoming one through the stocks on the capital markets!
The difference being that BTC has staying power so it‚Äôs generally healthy for BTC as the best will remove from market creating permanent capital never to be moved again.

[26/06/2025, 11:53:34] ~‚ÄØMatt H: Goldman on copper: The ongoing US Section 232 copper investigation continues to drive an unusually wide gap between COMEX (US) and LME (UK) prices, resulting in the US over-importing ~400kt of copper so far this year. US inventory has risen to over 100 days worth of consumption, up from just 33 days at the beginning of the year.
As a result, the ex-US copper market has tightened, causing fears of a regional copper shortage despite the global market currently being in surplus. The front of the LME curve has tightened substantially, with the LME Cash contract briefly trading over $10,000/t on June 23rd, and has traded at a $95-379/t premium to the 3 Month contract this week.
We upgrade our 2H 2025 LME copper price forecast to an average of $9,890, up from $9,140 previously. We expect the copper price to rise to a peak for the year of $10,050 in August due to (1) the tariff-driven reduction in ex-US stocks, and (2) China sentiment and activity remaining relatively resilient (for now), before declining to $9,700 by December. The expected decline reflects our base case (80% probability) of a 25% tariff being put in place on US copper imports by September, but a later-than-expected tariff implementation could keep LME prices higher for longer.
We reiterate our copper tariff trade of long Dec-25 COMEX-LME copper arbitrage as we believe that the current market implied tariff of 14% is significantly under-pricing the potential for a 25% or 50% tariff.
[26/06/2025, 12:17:11] ~‚ÄØLuke Dyas: Struggling with the linear thinking in the UBS Tesla report. They assume the robotaxi will work (or the forecast would be zero), but still only project 2.3mn on the road by by 2040, despite the model Y being the bestselling car globally for the last two years selling over 1mn a year, so are implying a major production collapse. Ark‚Äôs BEAR case is 7mn by 2030. UBS assumes $105k to $147k revenue per robotaxi! Their $3 per mile is too high but they only model 8 hours a day and robots don‚Äôt sleep so 16hours more likely. Owners get >70% of revenue according to Elon (so assume 70% of $100k). So what UBS misses is this provides a fully managed hypothetical annual yield of 200% on a $35k robotaxi! Even at a 20% yield, a robotaxi would fully pay for itself and buyers would flood in, availability would soar, per mile pricing would drop and new use cases would emerge. Begs the question why would you buy any other car? No other manufacturer plans to run this model so this should give Tesla total market dominance (in addition to already producing the entire Waymo fleet every 5 hours!).

[30/06/2025, 05:47:15] Nick finegold: I think the key to puzzle on search Luke is contained in podcast you sent. 

1/ Absolutely, no doubt Alphabet is loosing market share in search measured as a % of the total number of queries. 

2/ However , total number of queries would have expanded greatly. I personally don‚Äôt use chat GPT and Gemini the same way I use Google search. 

3/ The new ai can be used to optimise results for advertisers. No one has more data about consumers than Google , so one could assume it is this that is there moat , not an indefensible 90% market share. 

So the only way to measure the impact accurately is really advertising $ and digital continues to grow. 

Meantime YouTube , as revenues should grow aggressively, Google cloud clearly has some sort of TPU attractions and Waymo is not about the cost of cars it‚Äôs about safety and cost  where it also seems to have an edge.

‚Äé[02/07/2025, 11:21:47] ~‚ÄØPhilip Donald: Battle of the Ponzis.pdf ‚Ä¢ ‚Äé7 pages ‚Äédocument omitted
[02/07/2025, 11:45:21] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: PD. Def smart and inciteful..
A few thoughts if I may..

Yes, there‚Äôs a clear capital-raising arms race underway. Dozens of blockchain firms are chasing the same speculative capital, bidding up their own valuations in a race to secure short-term inflows. As dilution accelerates, many of these vehicles are bound to collapse‚Äîespecially those burdened by short-horizon debt or relying on sustained premiums over NAV. When bitcoins-per-share growth stalls, the illusion cracks, and so too will many of these structures. Meme coin culture shifting to Bitcoin may fade. 
But that‚Äôs only half the story.
A parallel track is actually emerging‚Äîone built on conviction, not hype. Those who‚Äôve done the work (10,000hrs - Gladwell) to truly understand Bitcoin don‚Äôt just see a volatile asset; they see pristine digital capital‚Äîa new kind of monetary foundation. ( no eye rolling!) 
The most strategically positioned treasuries‚Äîgeographically diversified, debt-light, and long-term aligned‚Äîare quietly making a play to become internet-native central banks for their respective regions. Even a 1% chance of that reality is worth a premium. And it‚Äôs no longer just theory. Political winds are shifting (Trump‚Äôs open embrace of Bitcoin being the latest signal), and the capital base for Bitcoin-denominated balance sheets is getting deeper, more strategic, and more sovereign.
Crucially, this isn't just about belief in Austrian economics anymore. What‚Äôs coming is conviction through utility. The abstract monetary thesis is becoming real, visible, and accessible: remittances that settle instantly, capital markets that clear in real time, sovereign-grade custody, and digitally native financial services that bypass traditional rails. These aren‚Äôt speculative dreams‚Äîthey‚Äôre tangible services people will use. The utility layer is what will separate short-term Ponzi dynamics from long-term monetary innovation.
Speculation will break. Conviction‚Äîand utility‚Äîwill build.

As was explaining to someone why my convictionon ROBINHOOD as have had for sometime: the CEO gets it..
George and me were discussing the ‚ÄúJack & Jill‚Äù of his message and it is..
  
Jack: ‚Äúso when he talks tokenisation, why would I care about a tokenised Apple or Tesla? Isn‚Äôt it just a copy of the real stock, and no one‚Äôs really trading it yet?‚Äù

Jill: ‚ÄúYes, liquidity might be low in the beginning ‚Äî just like crypto was at the start. But here‚Äôs the point: for the first time, you can own U.S. stocks directly, globally, 24/7, without needing a bank or brokerage. It‚Äôs not a claim on your app ‚Äî it‚Äôs a token you can actually custody yourself.‚Äù

Jack: ‚ÄúWait‚Ä¶ like in my digital / crypto wallet?‚Äù

Jill: ‚ÄúExactly. You can literally store Tesla, Apple, or even SpaceX in your head ‚Äî in your seed phrase. No counterparty, no opening hours, no middleman. It‚Äôs not just about trading ‚Äî it‚Äôs about ownership architecture.‚Äù

Jack: ‚ÄúSo I can hold SpaceX and Tesla in cold storage like I do Bitcoin?‚Äù

Jill: ‚ÄúYup. As the rails mature ‚Äî and staking, borrowing, and composability come online ‚Äî this becomes real programmable finance, not just equities with a facelift.‚Äù

Jack: ‚ÄúFeels like the start of stocks becoming internet-native.‚Äù

[03/07/2025, 10:06:32] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: 3 Things: 
Tungsten/ TUN LN. more funding.
ATOM LN as above. 

IN TATTOO-LANDMAN LAND: OFFSHORE: ( some +ve laterals from a deal)
See Turkish Petroleum has just acquired Eldorado Drilling‚Äôs two warm stacked 7th gen drillships at an all-in price of USD 325-350m per rig. The deal makes sense for both parties in my view and is positive for the global deepwater market by taking out two key assets from available supply. The all-in cost is also above current equity market valuations, suggesting ~60-75% upside to most heavily discounted VAL and SDRL. While older, it also suggests Saipem‚Äôs option for DVD‚Äôs highly efficient drillship (85-90% upside to current share price) is in the money.
For the overall deepwater market, I see this as ‚Äúhidden demand‚Äù not showing up in tendering lists, with two rigs corresponding to ~2-3% of global demand. Importantly, it also takes out two warm drillships owned by a smaller, tightly financed player, without the possibility to execute the same price discipline as the larger companies. Following the transaction, there are six stacked high spec. drillships (marketed for work), including 5 owned by the larger drillers (VAL, SDRL) and one owned by a shipyard.
All-In price above equity market valuations
Assuming an all-in price USD 338m, this implies a premium of ~75% in VAL, ~60% in SDRL and ~24% in NE, while RIG is priced ~3% above the transaction price on my calculations.

[03/07/2025, 21:48:43] ~‚ÄØLuke Dyas: One big drawback of Bitcoin treasury stocks that no one seems to mention (including the above critique) is corporate tax if gains are ever realised. BTC treasury rankings ignore this, but it can heavily distort NAV valuations. The lower the BTC acquisition price, the bigger the unrealised gain and potential tax hit. In Germany, I've discovered Bitcoin Group SE may have to pay ~29.8% tax on BTC gains if sold. Given their very low BTC acquisition price, c.55% of the NAV discount might be explained by potential tax. Even factoring  this in there‚Äôs still a 15‚Äì20% discount vs BTC/ETH holdings, and the core biz has value ‚Äî so it‚Äôs still interesting, just not as cheap as it looks. BTC treasury stocks are therefore perhaps a much less efficient way for retail to hold BTC vs ETFs. So I'm shifting more into COIN, just hope TFG hasn't pushed the price up first!

‚Äé[08/07/2025, 18:21:49] ~‚ÄØRich McDonald: ‚Äéimage omitted
[08/07/2025, 19:10:58] ~‚ÄØKatie Jackson: Goldman on copper: The ongoing US Section 232 copper investigation continues to drive an unusually wide gap between COMEX (US) and LME (UK) prices, resulting in the US over-importing ~400kt of copper so far this year. US inventory has risen to over 100 days worth of consumption, up from just 33 days at the beginning of the year.
As a result, the ex-US copper market has tightened, causing fears of a regional copper shortage despite the global market currently being in surplus. The front of the LME curve has tightened substantially, with the LME Cash contract briefly trading over $10,000/t on June 23rd, and has traded at a $95-379/t premium to the 3 Month contract this week.
We upgrade our 2H 2025 LME copper price forecast to an average of $9,890, up from $9,140 previously. We expect the copper price to rise to a peak for the year of $10,050 in August due to (1) the tariff-driven reduction in ex-US stocks, and (2) China sentiment and activity remaining relatively resilient (for now), before declining to $9,700 by December. The expected decline reflects our base case (80% probability) of a 25% tariff being put in place on US copper imports by September, but a later-than-expected tariff implementation could keep LME prices higher for longer.
We reiterate our copper tariff trade of long Dec-25 COMEX-LME copper arbitrage as we believe that the current market implied tariff of 14% is significantly under-pricing the potential for a 25% or 50% tariff.
