[09/07/2025, 16:26:33] ~‚ÄØMatt H: Jeffries on copper
[09/07/2025, 16:26:35] ~‚ÄØMatt H: Trump's announced 50% tariff on copper imports sent shock waves through the copper market, with the COMEX price spiking to a new high of $5.90/lb before settling at +11% on the day to $5.58/lb at 7pm EST. The COMEX-LME spread closed at 25%. Presumably this new tariff is a result of the Dept of Commerce investigation, as Secretary Lutnick indicated, but further clarity and details may be needed before the market fully believes. Freeport benefits most.

The US does not have nearly enough mine/smelter/refinery capacity to be self-sufficient in copper. As a result, import tariffs are likely to lead to continued significant price premiums in the US relative to other regions. All else equal, Freeport, Asarco (Grupo Mexico) and Rio Tinto are likely to be the biggest beneficiaries of these new tariffs.

Copper Supply to the US (kt), 2020-2024
29e8ccb3-93c2-4285-aaea-8027d5d881eb@bluematrix.png
Source: Company filings, Wood Mackenzie, USGS, Jefferies
We estimate that - all else held equal - a 50% copper tariff in the US should lead to approximately $2.8bn of incremental annual FCF for Freeport.

Freeport's 2026E EBITDA, EPS and FCF Sensitivities (US$ millions, except per share data)
6ca4dd7d-b711-4a82-a607-bfc5f5c12daf@bluematrix.png
Source: Company filings, Bloomberg, Jefferies' estimates
In this report, we discuss the potential short-term and longer-term consequences of US copper tariffs, and we provide a detailed analysis of the US copper industry.

Tariffs in Play: The US Department of Commerce (DOC) initiated an investigation into copper imports as a potential national security concern in February and had until mid-November (270 days) to complete this investigation. We had expected the DOC to conclude that copper imports do qualify as a national security concern. We had also believed this could be the trigger for President Trump to roll out 25% tariffs on copper imports under Section 232. Trump's announced 50% tariffs on copper imports came as a surprise in terms of timing and magnitude, but tariffs were likely coming at some point. Higher copper prices in the US should ultimately incentivize growth investment in mines and new smelters/refineries. We believe the longer term aim of the Trump administration may be for the US to be fully self-sufficient in copper, but mines take too long to develop for this to be achieved in less than a 10-year time horizon, in our view. Getting there faster from a smelting/refining perspective is possible and would erode a competitive advantage that China currently has in the copper supply chain. However, as we discuss in this note, the US will still rely on foreign mines to meet demand for the foreseeable future. It is therefore possible that tariffs on refined copper imports will persist for a relatively long duration, which is what we have seen in the US steel industry following the roll-out of section 232 tariffs for steel by President Trump in 2018.

The Proverbial Air Pocket: While the COMEX copper price spiked today, the concern that some have now is that US buyers who have accumulated excess copper inventory will step out of the market as a result of the spike in prices (relevant charts and analysis are in this report). This could lead to temporary downward pressure on COMEX (and LME) prices, but the COMEX-LME spread should still widen. We assume that today's relatively muted response in share prices of copper miners that would benefit most from these tariffs (FCX closing up just 2.5%, for instance) is a reflection of 'buy the rumor, sell the news'. While a short-term air pocket with lower prices is possible, we would buy our preferred copper mining equities on any near-term weakness (FCX, TECK, LUN, FM, GLEN, AAL).

The Freeport Edge: Freeport accounts for about 60% of US mined copper production and also has a smelter in the US. We estimate that - all else held equal - a 50% copper tariff in the US should lead to approximately $2.8bn of incremental annual FCF for Freeport (note that we currently model a US price premium of 11% for four years, and we have not adjusted our model for today's announced 50% tariff). This is material relative to Freeport's current market cap of ~$66bn. The appropriate multiple to put on this incremental cash flow of course depends on the duration of the cash flow as well as the risk that the tariff rate is lowered. We believe an accelerated share buyback under the company's existing $3bn authorization would be a positive for Freeport's equity valuation.

[10/07/2025, 07:52:00] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: I‚Äôd still rather use my credit card on my crypto account cos it protects me.
[10/07/2025, 07:52:44] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: To Davids point‚Ä¶

Visa and Mastercard‚Äôs role in a blockchain-integrated financial system is not just payment rails ‚Äî it‚Äôs recourse infrastructure. Their primary utility becomes the clawback mechanism in the event of fraud, charge disputes, or systemic failures ‚Äî something that on-chain systems, by design, struggle to handle due to their immutable nature.

In this way, they‚Äôre evolving into the consumer protection layer or the "bug buffer" on top of smart contract systems ‚Äî a critical trust bridge between traditional finance users and on-chain applications. As Web3 frontends mature, these card networks are positioned to become the UX abstraction layer that gives users familiar tools with embedded protections ‚Äî even as the backend moves entirely on-chain.

Basically the are becoming on sliver of the stack not THE STACK.

The two-year old AI company‚Äîmost recently in the news when its chatbot praised Hitler‚Äîsaid in a blog post Monday that it has launched a new division, called ‚ÄúGrok with Government‚Äù and signed a contract worth up to $200 million with the Department of Defense. xAI also announced that it had been added to the General Services Administration schedule, meaning that xAI products will now be available for purchase across every government office and agency.

ü©∂ *Silver‚Äôs Bullish Setup =* Structural squeeze + macro tailwinds 

‚õèÔ∏è *Supply shrinking*

Global silver output is falling ‚Äì only 835m oz expected in 2025, down >7% vs 2014. Lower ore grades, depleted resources & 7‚Äì10 year project timelines = tight pipeline.

ü™ô¬†*Demand surging*

- 2024 industrial demand hit record 680.5m oz (4th straight year)
- Solar to drive 14% of global silver demand in 2025 (vs 5% in 2014)
- EVs use 50% more silver ‚Äì 2025 sales = 600+ tonnes demand
- Electronics + 5G = strong secular pull

‚ûï*Investment tailwinds*

- Inflation hedge (avg 4.2%)
- Safe-haven appeal in uncertain geopolitics
- Gold/silver ratio still ~90 i.e. silver deeply undervalued

üîë About *58% of silver demand* in 2025 comes from industrial uses - notably much higher than gold. This demand is hitting record highs and is projected to rise further. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[17/07/2025, 13:57:19] Nick finegold: Economic data bottom line: the 8:30amET numbers were bullish in aggregate from a growth perspective (robust retail sales, higher Philadelphia Fed Manufacturing, lower claims, etc.) but will also likely push rates higher and bolster the Fed‚Äôs view that standing on the sidelines makes the most sense right now (which risks inflaming tensions between Trump and Powell). 
US retail sales were very strong in June, coming in at +0.6% M/M on the headline (vs. the Street +0.1%). The control group was also above plan at +0.5% M/M (vs. the Street +0.3%), although control revisions were neg. for May (now +0.2% vs. the prior +0.4%). Areas of strength in June included autos (+1.2%), building materials/garden supply (+0.9%), clothing (+0.9%), and miscellaneous store retailers (+1.8%). Areas of weakness included furniture/home furnishings (-0.1%), electronics/appliances (-0.1%), gas stations (flat), sporting goods/musical instruments (+0.2%), and department stores (-0.8%). 
The Philadelphia Fed Manufacturing Index for July was very strong at 15.9, up from -4 in June and above the consensus forecast of -1, as both demand and prices climbed. ‚ÄúThe survey‚Äôs indicator for general activity returned to positive territory, and the indexes for new orders and shipments both increased this month. All three indexes recorded their highest readings since February. The employment index turned positive, suggesting overall increases in employment. Both price indexes rose after declining last month and continue to suggest overall price increases‚Äù.
Weekly jobless claims moved in an encouraging direction, with initials falling to 221K (down from 228K in the prior month) while continuing eased lower from the recent highs.
Import/export prices for June were mixed, with import prices coming in cooler than anticipated (+0.1% M/M vs. the Street +0.3%) while export prices jumped 0.5% (vs. the Street forecast of flat).

[18/07/2025, 08:04:03] Nick finegold: This is interesting, from Adam , the current talent war in the big caps just reinforced their dominance as start up can‚Äôt afford to hire . 

Talent War: As cars become AI-driven robots, how can legacy auto keep up with tech firm offers for multi-hundred-million-$ contracts for top talent?

Tech companies' move into the physical/manufacturing world is, in some ways, a validation of the tremendous potential value unlock in automating road transportation, defense and humanoid markets. At the same time, it's a potentially concerning sign for incumbent players to have to 'pay up' to attract new talent and keep their best talent on board.
The recent amping up of the AI/robotics talent war is a key reason why we expect Tesla to host an 'AI Day' in the not-too-distant future. The recruiting value alone is a key priority, in our view. ‚Äé<This message was edited>
[18/07/2025, 08:05:36] Nick finegold: Also ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ 

The best argument I have heard to date for camera only driving. It‚Äôs not one I believe in particularly unless cameras can see in the dark or fog , but it‚Äôs the most rationale one I have heard .
[18/07/2025, 08:05:59] Nick finegold: No LiDAR: As Tesla continues to 'expand' its robotaxi geofence in the Austin area, including new plans to inaugurate new cities in other US States (Arizona, California, etc.), investors continue to see the company 'doubling down' on its rather novel approach to on-board autonomy - camera only.

"Annoyingly... Elon is right." These were the words of a vision expert at a rival autonomous vehicle startup when discussing the pros and cons of using sensor fusion (camera + Radar + LiDAR) vs. Tesla's camera only approach to autonomy for its robotaxi fleet.
The analogy of the two 'Baby Tarzans' is helpful. Imagine two ‚ÄòBaby Tarzans‚Äô dropped into different parts of a vast jungle with one singular goal: survive a full year on your own. Baby Tarzan 1 was equipped with water, energy bars, night vision goggles, a laser gun, a fire-starting kit, a poncho, a tent, an assortment of knives and medical supplies. Baby Tarzan 2 was given nothing. BT1 will likely eat that first night and sleep comfortably by the fire. BT2 may go hungry that night‚Ä¶ maybe for several nights. When a year had passed, both had survived. Who learned more?
We don't think investors fully appreciate the potential advantages of 'sensorial parsimony' as practiced by Tesla's current robotaxi fleet... purposely depriving the vehicles of LiDAR to force the vehicles to achieve a different pace of learning.
Through a hypothetical lens ask yourself what is better: (a) a robotaxi with a hardware/sensor approach that is slightly safer today but with a slower rate of improvement? Or (b) a robotaxi that may be slightly less safe today but with a much faster rate of improvement that could make it 10 to 100x safer in the next 5 to 10 years vs. the fusion approach?
[18/07/2025, 08:44:12] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: ‚ÄéThis message was deleted by admin ~‚ÄØKatie Jackson.
[18/07/2025, 10:50:09] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Good to see ATOM LN waking up again and BTC LN which has been dire‚Ä¶

On QUANTUM/ AI. Chapeau to the excellent Conor on his Quantum plays..
I thought this useful from todays Nutstuff..

‚ÄúMaybe Quantum isn‚Äôt the end of the world. Maybe it‚Äôs us finally remembering where we came from‚Äù. 
(A lot of focus on the intersection of AI & Quantum so I thought worth some focus): 
AI is artificial. It ingests all the sensors and data in the world to form patterns and predictions. It reflects us our behavior, our biases, our inputs. It‚Äôs a feedback loop of digital mimicry. Powerful, but derivative. A mezzanine to quantum.  Quantum, by contrast, is organic.  It‚Äôs not trying to simulate intelligence. It is intelligence, natural, probabilistic, and in harmony with the deeper structures of reality. Humans, in our curiosity, have tried to build a machine not to dominate nature, but to reflect it. A machine that doesn‚Äôt impose order, but reveals the equilibrium that was always there. Like the story of the world made in six days: structured, ordered, sacred.    And here‚Äôs the key difference:  Nature although ‚Äòbrutal‚Äô (see David Attenborough) doesn‚Äôt use passwords.  It doesn‚Äôt need to. Its systems are secured by symbiosis, not encryption. Quantum eats passwords for breakfast, not to threaten the world, but to restore balance. It is a return, not an attack. A return to a kind of logic where trust is inherent in the design of the universe, not something patched on afterward.  Of course, quantum is terrifying to a world so often out of balance, fractured, over-secured, and mistrustful.  But that‚Äôs just humans being humans.  And humans are nature, too.  Which means maybe, just maybe, quantum isn‚Äôt the end of the world. Maybe it‚Äôs us finally remembering where we came from.  Good luck to those trying to monetise true distributed quantum. It doesn‚Äôt bend to layers, systems, or schemes. It actually undoes them.
Quantum isn‚Äôt a feature of our world, it IS the world. And every artificial structure we‚Äôve laid over nature ‚Äî passwords, patents, pyramids of power, all dissolve in its presence.
Nature doesn‚Äôt need control. It runs on balance. Quantum eats control systems for breakfast and returns the world to equilibrium. The key question is: why would Microsoft release something that destroys their cash cow? They won‚Äôt, unless they can own or control the replacement. This is the paradox at the edge of real tech change: the most powerful technologies (like AGI or distributed quantum) threaten margins, control, and scarcity economics. The incumbents will only let them loose if they can wrap them in a product moat. Otherwise, they‚Äôll suppress or slow-roll it. Put another way: ‚ÄúThe dragon only gets released if they get to ride it.‚Äù

[22/07/2025, 06:39:11] Nick finegold: I explain BTC as follows . 

Even if you are 99% certain  crypto is a dangerous ponzi scheme ( as Dimon did ) you have to have  to have some small exposure just in case the 1% chance you are wrong materialises and it does go to $1m as the evangelists predict . If everyone does that it does go to $1m over time . 

As usual our industry has a habit of inventing a crypto language designed to cast intellectual superiority over its audience so they can charge fees for managing the asset. 

When all you really need to understand is that are going to be more buyers than sellers over time .

[23/07/2025, 14:00:35] ~‚ÄØJason M: Hi. Question on Uranium.
Been in this space for 5/6 years now and big believer in nuclear. Although moved from uranium funds/miners to builders of the kit.
I find it interesting that most clever people seem to be long, give a v persuasive account of the inbalance in the market and that it is a matter of time before a spike occurs. 
Yet despite problems on supply side, people like Sprott buying up large quantities the price has gone down/sideways for 18months. I never hear a bear story.
So I was intrigued a few weeks ago when I long term bull told me he had cut exposure. The reason that the next generation of nuclear reactors uses a tiny fraction of the Uranium the old ones use. SMRs also use a tiny fraction. There are also competing technologies such as using Thorium where China already has a prototype up and running. Appreciate some of this stuff long way off. 
Just thought interesting counter argument to something most people evangelically bullish on.
[23/07/2025, 14:11:39] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Jason - we deal with these types of questions quite often. I think one thing to remember is prices have gone up 3.5x since 2019 and have as you say rebased at ~$70/lb. The issue is that we will not see $150/lb uranium in spot price terms until utilities come into the market - we cannot rely on traders swapping 100k lbs here 200k lbs there to really move the market. 

The bear story is that utilities continue to not budge - but one fact that is true is that the market has produced about 25-30% less than it consumes for 7 consecutive years. That has to end at some point and there are not 100s of idle uranium mines sat waiting for higher prices. There a very very few and the few (particularly in the U.S. + Paladin) that have come back online, have faced ramp up issues across the board. 

The SMR point I don‚Äôt love because the world needs more GW scale nuclear (traditional) than it does SMRs. Fermi are building an 11GW data centre, Stargate 5GW. You need a hell of a lot of SMRs to power those. Oklo reactors are 75MW! 

Yes there are many many use cases for SMRs outside of data centres but I think the market slightly forgets that the more pressing issue is for us to build GW scale nuclear that requires ~600k lbs of uranium per year. That‚Äôs what China are doing and they can see it like a beach ball. 

More than happy to chat offline if helpful.
[23/07/2025, 14:16:29] ~‚ÄØJason M: Thanks I am not trying to be clever.

If you had told me the news on nuclear over the last 18months I would have guessed uranium would have doubled yet here we are. Just makes me wonder what we are missing. Just feels like more money to be made in next generation stuff possibly than the commodity/miners. The bull story feels tired‚Ä¶but maybe I am just impatient.

[28/07/2025, 10:02:00] Nick finegold: Been thinking about Reddit ahead of numbers , which I owned and sold and currently have no exposure to. 

Reddit: Where Retail Rules. Not cheap but very interesting. 

We‚Äôre living through the most retail-driven market in history ‚Äî a time when the tail wags the dog.

Every institutional desk is now tuned in to what retail traders are doing. But where do those signals originate? It‚Äôs No longer Bloomberg & CNBC that rocks a stick . It‚Äôs Reddit.

At the heart of it all is WallStreetBets ‚Äî a subreddit with millions of followers, where narratives are born, options flow is dissected, and cult stocks are germinated. 

Reddit is deeply human.
It‚Äôs not polished. It‚Äôs not performative. It‚Äôs not bots liking bots. It‚Äôs raw, original content ‚Äî from real people with real opinions.

That matters for two big reasons:
	1.	Advertisers want humans. Reddit offers authenticity at scale, not artificial engagement.
	2.	AI needs humans. When training large models, original user-generated content is gold dust. Reddit has a treasure trove of it.

As the retail investor becomes a market-moving force ‚Äî and as AI and ad engines seek real-world training and targeting data ‚Äî Reddit becomes a nexus of relevance.

It‚Äôs not just a community.
It‚Äôs a source code.
And in a retail-driven world, that makes it one of the most interesting platforms ‚Äî and possibly stocks ‚Äî on the planet.
[28/07/2025, 11:03:42] ~‚ÄØEd Farquhar: NCC Group: The UK Breakup Story Hiding in Plain Sight

What‚Äôs happening:
Manchester-based NCC Group (market cap: ¬£460M) is quietly unlocking value the UK market has overlooked for years. With both its divisions now under strategic review, a sum-of-the-parts breakup could deliver 60p‚Äì90p of upside near term.

Why it matters:
UK takeovers have made headlines, but genuine breakups like Ascential (200p ‚Üí 550p) have been even more lucrative. NCC is next in line.

‚∏ª

üß± The Business

NCC has two distinct divisions:
	1.	Escode ‚Äì The world leader in software escrow
	2.	Cyber Security ‚Äì One of the last pure-play listed cyber consultancies in London post-Darktrace

Each unit is now independently up for sale. The market hasn‚Äôt priced in their full value.

‚∏ª

üíæ Escode: One of the highest-quality earnings stories in the UK
	‚Ä¢	What it does: Think of Escode as insurance for mission-critical software. It stores code for 10,000+ clients (including 50% of the Fortune 500) and ensures access if vendors fail or go under.
	‚Ä¢	Revenue: ~¬£65M
	‚Ä¢	EBIT: ~¬£33M
	‚Ä¢	Margins: Best-in-class, capital-light, >50%
	‚Ä¢	Valuation range: ¬£300M‚Äì¬£400M
	‚Ä¢	Buyer interest: Four PE firms reported circling
	‚Ä¢	Key edge: No significant competitor over ¬£5M revenue. It‚Äôs a monopoly with regulation-driven demand and evergreen B2B contracts.

üìà Regulators now nudge companies to adopt escrow. Escode invented the category.

‚∏ª

üîê Cyber Security: Next in line
	‚Ä¢	Revenue: ~¬£250M
	‚Ä¢	Est. valuation: ¬£300M‚Äì¬£400M
	‚Ä¢	Potential sale timeline: Before calendar year-end
	‚Ä¢	Strategic angle: Following Darktrace‚Äôs path to private ownership

üìå Together, the two businesses could unlock ¬£600M‚Äì¬£800M in sale proceeds vs today‚Äôs ¬£460M market cap.

‚∏ª

üß† Smart Money Involved

NCC‚Äôs shareholder register is a who‚Äôs who of UK small-cap Jedi:
	‚Ä¢	Richard Griffiths (14%)
	‚Ä¢	Harwood Capital (11%) ‚Äì incl. Stuart Widdowson (ex-HG Capital)

üì£ No weak hands. No structural sellers. Just a clean, experienced register of value-driven long-term holders.

‚∏ª

üìä Bottom Line

With both divisions now on the block and high-quality buyers in play, NCC‚Äôs breakup story is real, active, and potentially explosive.

If Escode fetches ¬£350M+ and Cyber hits ¬£300M‚Äì¬£400M, a 200p‚Äì240p price target looks realistic.
That‚Äôs a 30%‚Äì65% upside from today ‚Äî in months, not years.

‚è≥ Market‚Äôs asleep. But the deal clock is ticking.

I share an office with Harwood Capital and it is public knowledge that management are running a sale process of Escode.

[29/07/2025, 06:20:37] Nick finegold: The Metal Company 

Having listened to the  Ivanhoe mines CEO yesterday in a post that Matt shared and read various articles about whether Chilean Copper will be tariff free , it‚Äôs clear to me that the Trump administration feels similarly about copper as it does rare earths and all other metals it deems to be important to national security.
  
Now it‚Äôs hard to buy a stock that‚Äôs up 400% but I asked chat gpt this morning if the copper contained in polymetalic nodules is in concentrations that make it commercially viable to mine . 

This is the answer I got. 

üîã Summary:

Yes, 1.1% copper is commercially attractive, especially in the context of the multi-metal revenue stream, lower overburden (no blasting or digging), and rising global demand for clean energy metals. The bigger hurdles are regulatory, ESG, and technological, not ore grade.

So this raises some interesting questions about whether this administration might do a MP Materials type deal with TMC or other providers of metals they deem to be highly significant. 

I have no idea, but what‚Äôs clear is that this administration if hell bent on supporting any businesses that can provide the US with supply chain security.  China has been playing this game for years and it‚Äôs clearly a priority that the US catches up .

[29/07/2025, 07:13:42] ~‚ÄØMatt H: Vitol Group¬†handed a record $10.6 billion to its executives and senior staff through share buybacks last year, as the fallout of the energy crisis continued to deliver extraordinary riches to the world‚Äôs commodity traders.

The share repurchase ‚Äî almost certainly the highest such payout in the industry‚Äôs history ‚Äî means privately held Vitol has distributed over $31 billion to its partners in the past decade, according to the company‚Äôs audited annual accounts seen by Bloomberg News.

The numbers show how the disruptions that followed Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine have handed a spectacular bonanza to a small group of commodity traders that their predecessors could only have dreamed of. Vitol has paid out more through buybacks in the past three years than in the previous 17 years combined.

The world‚Äôs largest commodity trading house, the company is owned by 450-500 of its employees, a senior executive told a New York court last year. Based on that number, the 2024 payout would represent an average of over $20 million per partner, with some top executives and traders likely having received multiples of that.

The results also cement Vitol‚Äôs position as the most profitable commodity trading house by far: its net profit for the year of $8.7 billion was more than the combined profits of its four closest rivals, Glencore Plc, Trafigura Group, Mercuria Energy Group Ltd. and Gunvor Group.

Still, the huge payout comes as earnings are moderating across the industry. Vitol‚Äôs buyback in 2024 outstripped its profit for the year, meaning that the group‚Äôs equity dropped from $32.5 billion at the end of 2023 to $30.7 billion at the end of 2024.

[29/07/2025, 07:40:24] ~‚ÄØJerry de Leeuw: For those with an interest in ENSHITTIFICATION (see Wikipedia) of the web and social media. Might be of interest for your long-term overall SWOT analysis on BigTech, incl. Google / Alphabet.

https://youtu.be/CgJ6isBJiWI?si=LrCDamu-fzKiTY77

[Note: Throughout 0:00-1:23 and 5:13-5:30 some Dutch language; the rest in English]

Nowadays, when you type a search term into Google, the first page no longer shows useful results, but mostly ads. And a few scams.

The endless stream of advertisements on Instagram, the countless tricks used to avoid showing people the lowest price, YouTube seemingly wanting to show nothing but ads‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs not just a source of daily frustration, but a real cause for concern: what‚Äôs going on? Is the internet truly falling apart?

The American activist and writer Cory Doctorow coined a term that captures in a single word what‚Äôs wrong with the internet: enshittification.

Doctorow didn‚Äôt just come up with the term enshittification to describe what‚Äôs going wrong with the internet; he also provided a thorough analysis of how it‚Äôs come to this. Why the major American tech companies are able to enshittify their products without consequence, and why we keep using them anyway. Because the classic economic idea (that if a product or service deteriorates, the free market will naturally make room for better alternatives) clearly no longer applies in the digital economy.

What I DO feel passionately is that more than ever this¬†next decade will be the golden decade of Digital assets/ Blockchain Protocols and of course Bitcoin, with greater Institutional adoption and a 40% CAGR, dropping down to @24% in 2035.
A HUGE day for Markets & Macro. The strategic BTC reserve report is the real wildcard here - this could be the catalyst that breaks Bitcoin out of its consolidation around $118k. PCE data will set the tone for the Fed meeting. If we get softer inflation prints, it strengthens the case for that September rate cut. Lower rates = risk-on environment = crypto benefits. MSFT and META earnings I sense matter more than people think. Big tech cash flows often correlate with institutional crypto appetite. If they're printing money, some of that eventually finds its way into digital assets. The timing is perfect with Bitcoin sitting just 4% off ATH at $118k. If the strategic reserve report is even remotely positive, combined with dovish Fed signals, you could see a breakout above $122k resistance. The 98 companies that have raised $43B+ for crypto purchases since June are waiting for exactly this kind of macro clarity. [30/07/2025, 20:15:06] ~‚ÄØGiles Fitzpatrick: According to Perplexity AI: Historical analysis and multiple sources on copper market volatility indicate that, in the last 50 years, copper has not experienced a single-day drop of 20% or more. While the metal is known for extreme volatility and there have been multi-day or multi-week plunges greater than 20%‚Äînotably during the 2008 Global Financial Crisis and in spring 2025‚Äîno record indicates that copper‚Äôs price has ever fallen 20% or more in a single trading day over this period.
For example:
	‚Ä¢	In 2008, copper fell nearly 70% over six months, but this prolonged decline did not include any day with a single-session drop of 20%.
	‚Ä¢	The most volatile sessions in copper history, such as May 2006 and several days during 2025‚Äôs tariff-induced bear market, included single-day drops or spikes in the 7‚Äì13% range, but not at or above 20%.
	‚Ä¢	Even during the ‚Äúworst setback ever‚Äù in the copper market, the sharpest daily moves remained well below 20%

Meta & Microsoft: AI Supercharged. Margins Exploded.

üß† What‚Äôs happening: Both Meta and Microsoft smashed expectations in their June quarters, driven by AI-fueled efficiency, margin expansion, and robust enterprise demand.

‚∏ª

Meta (META)
EPS beat big. Cost discipline even bigger.
	‚Ä¢	EPS: $7.14 vs. $5.89 est. (+38%)
	‚Ä¢	Revenue: $47.5B (+22%) vs. $44.8B est.
	‚Ä¢	Margins: Operating margin soared 500bps Y/Y to 43% ‚Äî despite rising headcount (+7%) and AI spend.
	‚Ä¢	User base: 3.48B daily active people (+6%), ahead of 3.42B est.
	‚Ä¢	Ad growth: Driven by +11% more impressions and +9% higher pricing.
	‚Ä¢	Q3 guide: $49B revenue at midpoint vs. $46B est.
	‚Ä¢	2026 warning: Meta flags ‚Äúmeaningful upward pressure‚Äù on future costs ‚Äî particularly depreciation and comp.
	‚Ä¢	Capex: 2025 range unchanged at $66‚Äì72B. 2026? A jaw-dropping ~$100B vs. $80B Street est.

üí• Bottom line: A monster quarter ‚Äî but 2026 cost guidance might spook longer-term models.

‚∏ª

Microsoft (MSFT)
Cloud king. Margin machine. Nothing to nitpick.
	‚Ä¢	EPS: $3.65 vs. $3.37 est. (+24%)
	‚Ä¢	Revenue: $76.4B (+18%) vs. $73.9B est.
	‚Ä¢	Operating income: $34.3B vs. $32.1B est.
	‚Ä¢	Margin: 45%, up 200bps Y/Y
	‚Ä¢	Azure: +39% growth ‚Äî a 400bps acceleration Q/Q, and way ahead of 34.2% est.
	‚Ä¢	Bookings: Commercial bookings surged +30% (from +17% in Q3)
	‚Ä¢	RPO (backlog): $368B, up from $315B
	‚Ä¢	Capex (cash): $17.1B, up 23%
	‚Ä¢	Free cash flow: $25.6B vs. $21.1B est.

‚úÖ Bottom line: Flawless. The only caution flag is valuation ‚Äî everything else screams dominance.

[31/07/2025, 12:04:41] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Cameco Q2 Reaction 

Going through CCJ numbers now. At first glance not much in there you don't already know. Westinghouse guidance has been increased in line with the $170m CEZ contract they won during the Q but market reacting favourably to this with shares +3% pre market.

Note uranium inventories down ~30% during the Q from 11.2m lbs to 7.5m lbs. This is interesting...note the world's largest producer KAP has inventories at decade lows as well. We will dig into this some more.

Production guidance remains in line for the year although we do note that CCJ have warned about potential changes to this which is not something we have seen before:

"Our 2025 production outlook assumes ground freezing and development in new mining areas advance as planned, that we maintain access to adequate skilled labour, and that new equipment is commissioned on time."

Nothing to report on Inkai and market purchase obligations are unchanged at 3m lbs for the year. We might get more colour on this when KAP report tomorrow but CCJ do note potential for disruption from ongoing sulphuric acid shortages in the CIS region.

Despite weak contract volumes in the first half of the year CCJ note:

"we continue to have a large and growing pipeline of business under discussion, and as the pace of contracting improves, we expect to selectively continue layering in long-term volumes that capture greater future upside and downside protection using market-related pricing mechanisms."

[31/07/2025, 15:29:49] ~‚ÄØWill Meadon: https://x.com/ryandetrick/status/1950880432582509007?s=12&t=CgN7v136U7YF4kUjMOK_Bw
[31/07/2025, 15:48:12] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Hi all.
Remains focus:
CRDL US/ Cardiol is a $123 million biotech that just might have stumbled into the cardiac equivalent of El Dorado. Next week it will publish Phase 2 data in acute myocarditis ‚Äì and management, usually as talkative as a Trappist monk, are practically humming with confidence. When biotech execs start looking smug, you either short them for hubris or buy them for glory. Here, it‚Äôs glory. Why? Because acute myocarditis is the last unclaimed frontier of cardiology. There is no approved drug, no standard of care ‚Äì just supportive therapy and prayer. Its cousin, recurrent pericarditis, has one approved drug ‚Äì Arcalyst ‚Äì a toxic little brute owned by Kiniksa that still manages a $2 billion market. Cardiol‚Äôs molecule, by contrast, looks cleaner and could take both indications. Call pericarditis $2B; acute myocarditis could be more. If the FDA fast‚Äëtracks this ‚Äì and it should, given the gaping therapeutic hole ‚Äì Cardiol goes from penny dreadful to market belle overnight. And that‚Äôs before you mention the heart failure programme ‚Äì promising in mice, and already whispered about in Novo Nordisk corridors (yes, that Novo).  This is what makes the current valuation ‚Äì $123 million ‚Äì feel like a misprint. The market is valuing a cardiac goldmine like a forgotten AIM oil driller. If pericarditis alone is worth $2B, myocarditis is diamonds. The set‚Äëup is binary, yes, but gloriously asymmetric: data next week, upside if right, and possibly the biotech trade of the year if the whisper mill proves true. WN.

[01/08/2025, 12:24:30] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Fyi to all those following HELIUM/ HNT. 
Weakness attributable to ‚Äúhalving‚Äù..

Helium‚Äôs halving is when the number of new HNT tokens created ‚Äî and paid to network participants ‚Äî is cut in half. It happens every two years and is designed to make the token scarcer over time, similar to Bitcoin. For miners, it means fewer rewards unless demand for the network (and the token) rises. For investors, it‚Äôs seen as a potential catalyst for price ‚Äî supply drops while usage, in theory, keeps growing.

[03/08/2025, 07:16:42] Nick finegold: Then If I could ask everyone to watch/listen to this podcast from Eric Schmidt . It‚Äôs measured and insightful .

The first few mins are very powerul. 

~ The limit of ai will governed by access to cheap electricity not chips. Electricity supply is what will hold back ai. 

We all know hyoerscalers are falling over themselves to gain capacity , but the clear message is it  wont arrive in time or sufficient quantities, as the velocity of ai outstrips our capacity to build new base load power. This is profoundly important for numerous sectors , utilities, chips , infrastructure, metals etc . 

This impending market dislocation is why I will subscribe to the geothermal deal that Ocean Wall are doing with Nikon and Schlumberber. It could be geothermals fracking moment . 

Geothermal is quick to market and largely unfollowed by market practioners . Whether it can make a dent in the demand side of the equation is my only question.

Numerous other positives and negatives to weigh up on ai in the podcast . if you can afford the time. 

Have a great weekend and please give it a listen.

[05/08/2025, 13:32:02] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: For those who bought the Embraer (ERJ) dip‚Ä¶

Brazilian planemaker Embraer EMBR3.SA on Tuesday reaffirmed its 2025 outlook and said U.S. tariffs did not significantly affect its second-quarter results, even as it described the levies as a "major concern" amid ongoing trade uncertainties.

The company avoided a potential setback last week when U.S. President Donald Trump exempted aircraft from a 50% tariff imposed on U.S. imports from Brazil, but still faces a 10% duty first imposed in April, which it indicated was harmful but manageable.

As it reported its April-June earnings, Embraer said it advocates for a "swift return to zero tariff rules for all aviation and aerospace industries" and again sought to underscore its ties to the U.S., including local jobs and investments.
Embraer, whose E175 narrowbody is a workhorse of U.S. regional aviation, flagged last month that a 50% tariff from its No. 1 market could have triggered order cancellations, deferred deliveries and hammered its revenue like the pandemic did.

Following last week's relief, Embraer now reiterated it expects to deliver between 77 and 85 commercial aircraft this year, and 145 to 155 executive jets. Full-year net revenue is forecast to hit $7 billion to $7.5 billion.

The company on Tuesday posted an adjusted net loss of $4.7 million for the period, down from a profit of $80.4 million a year earlier, weighed by a net change in deferred income tax and social contribution.

Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) reached $245.5 million, up from $190.4 million a year earlier. Net revenue came in at $1.82 billion, a 22% year-on-year increase.

[06/08/2025, 13:00:48] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: CARDIOL / CRDL US: We finally have the Phase 2 Acute Myocarditis. The results were AMAZING! I am told more details to follow.
Highlights here: The Company will now have a second drug in phase 3 heart disease. I cant say much more at the moment on the press release which is limited in detail. I suspect for a very good reason.

image
A thesis reminder: CARDIOL is a $110 million biotech that just might have stumbled into the cardiac equivalent of El Dorado. Acute myocarditis is heart failure for young people, by the way, not the sort of creaky coronary you get after 50 years of too much lager and chips. No treatment exists. None. Zero. Which makes the potential market vast. Meanwhile, their other heart drug, for recurrent pericarditis, is already in Phase 3. And if this one works, they‚Äôll push into general heart failure, these are the big leagues. Three swings at multi‚Äëbillion‚Äëdollar diseases, and yet the whole company‚Äôs worth about as much as a small semi‚Äëdetached in Croydon. Again, Acute myocarditis is a cruel, capricious affliction that ambushes the young, the fit and the ones who haven‚Äôt yet learned to distrust their own bodies. There is no approved drug, no standard of care just supportive therapy and prayer. Its cousin, recurrent pericarditis, has one approved drug Arcalyst, a toxic and expensive little brute owned by Kiniksa that still manages a $2 billion market. Cardiol‚Äôs molecule, by contrast, looks cleaner and could take both indications. Call pericarditis $2B; acute myocarditis could be more.  If the FDA fast‚Äëtracks this  and it should, given the gaping therapeutic hole,  Cardiol goes from being a penny dreadful to a market rock-star overnight. And that‚Äôs before you mention the heart failure programme, promising in mice, and already whispered about in certain well-respected much larger corridors! This is what makes the current valuation $123 million feel like a misprint. The market is valuing a cardiac goldmine like a forgotten AIM oil driller. If pericarditis alone is worth $2B, myocarditis is diamonds. The set‚Äëup is binary, yes, but gloriously asymmetric. Boo‚Äëhoo, biotech‚Äôs hard, but Nutstuff loves asymmetric alpha and this remains very possibly a significant biotech trade.

CROCS: I did this for my eldest into numbers as she works there in investor relations.

Numbers are due today! ‚ÄúCrocs are not shoes. Not really. They are the Platonic ideal of anti-shoes, rubbery confessionals for people who‚Äôve given up caring what their feet look like. They are also, improbably, a billion‚Äëdollar empire. The plastic clogs that launched a thousand sneers are now so popular they‚Äôve been franchised into Hey Dude, a brand which sounds like a children‚Äôs cartoon about a cowboy with unresolved emotional issues, but is in fact another casual shoe business.  Together they form a phenomenon that no self-respecting fashion critic would admit to understanding and yet, in the arithmetic of Wall Street, they‚Äôre gorgeous. The margins are fat, the cash pours in, and the growth, even with Hey Dude‚Äôs wobble, has kept the company squarely in the footwear aristocracy. This Thursday‚Äôs earnings aren‚Äôt about whether Crocs will sell more foam clogs (they will, they always do); it‚Äôs about whether Hey Dude can stop being the slightly embarrassing younger brother at the family reunion and start pulling its weight. If the numbers surprise on the upside, the co & analysts will dress it up in jargon about ‚Äúchannel inventory normalisation‚Äù and ‚ÄúDTC penetration‚Äù. But really, it‚Äôs simpler than that: ugly shoes might still be a beautiful business.‚Äù

[08/08/2025, 06:50:08] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Another day and another curved ball‚Ä¶
Trump tarrifs Swiss Gold bars! Yes the ones COMEX uses! 

There‚Äôs always been something reassuringly adult about gold. It doesn‚Äôt promise, it doesn‚Äôt tweet, it doesn‚Äôt explain itself. It just is dense, indifferent, and quietly universal. It has no quarterly earnings, no roadmap, no sudden forks in the night. And for 5,000 years, it has arguably never been someone else‚Äôs liability. Bitcoin, by contrast, is gold‚Äôs adolescent cousin charming, unruly, brilliant at parties, terrible in a crisis. It lives in your phone, not your vault. It doesn‚Äôt tarnish, but it does crash. It‚Äôs democratic, decentralised, and just unstable enough to feel exciting like a libertarian rave held in a volcano. And now along comes the Orange Orangutan Trump, with all the subtlety of a bull in a central bank, slapping a 39% tariff on Swiss kilo and 100 oz gold bars the exact bars COMEX uses to settle physical contracts. A golden brick lobbed at the windows of Bretton Woods. Remind yourself again of the asset that Trump owns?!! Gold may still be the sanctuary for many, but Bitcoin is starting to look like the escape hatch.

HERE‚ÄôS THE NBIS PITCH AGAIN: ‚ÄúYou want peace in Ukraine?  Nebius isn‚Äôt just in that war they‚Äôre building the bl**dy battlefield.‚Äù 
‚ÄúNEBIUS has scarcity, the CEO a Russian tech founder who didn‚Äôt end up flogging dodgy crypto or poisoned underpants. Instead, Arkady Volozh the man who built Yandex into Russia‚Äôs answer to Google, Amazon and most of Silicon Valley before breakfast, left the Kremlin, took a few hundred genius engineers with him, and built Nebius, a cloud company that actually makes something. Not an app. Not a token. Not a walled garden for depressed influencers. But proper infrastructure. Big, humming, power-hungry, Nvidia GPU-chomping cloud infrastructure. It doesn‚Äôt rent servers. It builds data centres, the actual GPU data centres. The racks. The cooling. The power. The firmware. All tuned to the only thing that matters in AI performance at scale, it does this in Finland, Iceland & America. With its own cooling systems, its own racks, its own power supply because clearly relying on PG&E or National Grid is the sort of decision made by people who think TikTok is a news service. It is rare, outside of Cupertino and Pyongyang, to see such vertical integration. Put another way, this is AWS with soul, this is the brains of Helsinki, the patience of Tel Aviv, and the power grid of a small Balkan republic, all stitched together under a founder who knows the stakes and is playing for a legacy. Unlike many of Silicon Valley‚Äôs delusional cap table hobbyists, Nebius makes money. Revenues are + 625%. Quarter-on-quarter! It just raised ARR guidance to over a $1billion. And it‚Äôs only just got started. Meanwhile, the palo Alto unicorns are choking on stock-based comp. There‚Äôs no debt. $1.4 billion in cash. Not a single customer big enough to hold them hostage. And they have a grip on their capex like a Yorkshireman with a ¬£20 note. The real story is this: while the West is sleepwalking into an AI bottleneck, Nebius is quietly laying pipes, building racks, and preparing to sell compute to anyone desperate enough to need it, which is to say, everyone. Startups. Governments. Labs. TikTok‚Äôs moderators. You name it. In addition they‚Äôve got a robotaxi company (Avride), a booming data labeller (Toloka), an EdTech rocketship (TripleTen), and a stake in ClickHouse. Finally, here‚Äôs the real rub it‚Äôs part of my ‚ÄúPortfolio for Peace‚Äù, in Ukraine story for good reason, because while Nebius was born from the ashes of Yandex and the bitter bifurcation of a nation, it now sits outside of that war, outside of that state, building the tools that might one day allow a different kind of power to flourish, one not built on oil or tanks or territorial grievance, but on compute, collaboration, and code. If war is fought with drones and data, then peace will be brokered with infrastructure. And Nebius may just be the one selling many of the servers when it comes.‚Äù ‚Äé<This message was edited>

Nutstuff on the Americas Cup: 

‚ÄúSo, the America‚Äôs Cup, a travelling court of the wealthy and weathered and sailing‚Äôs longest-running excuse for very rich men to dress like sailors and shout at each other from carbon-fibre spaceships has finally decided to ‚Äúmodernise‚Äù.
Which in this case means letting everyone have a say, scheduling it every two years, and sticking an Instagram influencer on board during the race. Because nothing says ‚Äúpinnacle of human engineering‚Äù quite like having a lifestyle blogger shrieking into their phone while you tack into a headwind. They‚Äôve thrown in a few nods to inclusivity a token woman on board, youth events, and a nationality rule to make sure at least some of the crew know which country they‚Äôre allegedly representing. And there‚Äôs a cost cap, wow rationing billionaires is a novel concept, which will no doubt keep this famously frugal sport from getting too flashy. All of this is billed as the ‚Äúboldest change in 174 years‚Äù which is a posh way of saying they‚Äôve finally worked out the old system was confusing, self-serving, and impossible to sell to anyone who doesn‚Äôt own a vineyard. Now it‚Äôs a ‚Äúshared vision‚Äù translation: an elaborate agreement to make sure the billionaires keep racing against each other in exactly the same boats, but with better sponsorship deals. Bring on Naples 2027, where the champagne will be cold, the sun will be hot, and the yachts will be worth more than the host city‚Äôs annual GDP. For the UK, the man behind Athena Racing isn‚Äôt a faceless corporate committee it‚Äôs Sir Ben Ainslie himself (or is it?!) Ben is the most decorated Olympic sailor Britain has ever produced and now wears at least four hats: Owner, Team Principal, CEO, and Skipper all rolled into one carbon-fibre package. The ‚ÄúAthena‚Äù name makes it sound like some sleek, well-funded syndicate, but really it‚Äôs Ben and whoever‚Äôs rich enough or patriotic enough to sign up. Nutstuff thinks he knows a few! Athena Racing, under his leadership, has now become the Challenger of Record for the 38th America‚Äôs Cup, fully representing the Royal Yacht Squadron. It‚Äôs Ainslie‚Äôs team, his vision, and come hell or high water his run to Naples in 2027. But it‚Äôs not just about Ben, he it seems is also heading the Athena Pathway project, bringing in youth and women sailors, and reviving some semblance of hope and inclusion into the ancient sport. And where‚Äôs Grumpy Sir Jim Ratcliffe in all this? Not on deck, that‚Äôs for sure. After chucking a couple of hundred million at the last campaign, Britain‚Äôs richest petrochemical patriot has walked away. Why? Because the whole thing moved at the speed of a becalmed dinghy and he‚Äôs got other toys to play with. Negotiations with the new Challenger of Record went on so long that Ratcliffe‚Äôs Ineos Britannia simply packed up and left. Which, given his recent luck in sport, a Chelsea shareholding, Manchester United minority stake, cycling team that peaked a decade ago might be a mercy killing.‚Äù (Nutstuff August ‚Äò25). ‚Äé<This message was edited>

To Nutstuff it‚Äôs the perfect contrarian set-up: everyone‚Äôs bored, nobody believes, and the upside is a once-a-decade legal high.

[13/08/2025, 14:00:34] Nick finegold: Oh , wrong group you did post it .
[13/08/2025, 14:02:45] Calum Curation: Marex Q2 2025 Earnings: 5 key points. 

1. Record Earnings and powerful growth:
Marex posted record results for Q2 2025, with adjusted profit before tax (PBT) of $106.4m, up 16% YoY, and revenue of $500.1m, up 18% YoY. For H1, adjusted PBT hit $202.7m (+27% YoY) on $967.4m revenue (+23% YoY). These results show strong momentum in both top-line and bottom-line growth. The uplift isn't a fluke; it comes off a tough comparator and demonstrates quality execution and strategic discipline.

2. Agency & Execution (Prime Services) transformation:
The Agency & Execution segment delivered explosive growth, with Q2 revenue jumping 59% YoY to $260.8m and adjusted PBT up 208% to $69m. Most importantly, Securities revenues (including Prime Services) soared 80% to $168.6m, highlighting the impact of integrating TD Cowen‚Äôs Prime Services business. Margin here expanded massively, and Prime Services is now a pillar of recurring, high-margin income‚Äîremarkable for a relatively new business line in the group.

3. Strategic M&A and Geographic/Product Expansion:
Marex continued executing on its M&A pipeline, closing deals (e.g., Agrinvest and Hamilton Court Group post-period) and announced the acquisition of Winterflood Securities in July 2025. These add exposure to South American agri markets, bolster FX capabilities in EMEA, and significantly enhance UK equity market making. The cumulative effect: powerful diversification, minimal capital outlay, and expanding franchise reach‚Äîall with clear, actionable integration stories.

4. Resilient risk management and liquidity:
Despite market volatility (notably the April US tariff shock), Marex maintained low credit losses and robust liquidity. Total liquid resources reached $3.4bn, with capital ratio at 242%‚Äîwell above regulatory minimums, and surplus liquidity further strengthened by a $500m senior note issuance. That‚Äôs ballast for navigating unpredictable markets and staying investor-grade.

5. Shareholder Value with strong ROE and lower PE overhang:
Return on equity remains stellar at 28% for Q2, and adjusted ROE at 31.4%. Additionally, the private equity overhang continues to shrink, now just 17% of shares after major blocks sold in April and following months; a cleaner cap table is a positive for public investors. Marex also declared a $0.15/share quarterly dividend, underlining capital discipline and confidence in future cash flows.

Bottom Line:
Marex‚Äôs powerful and diversified profit growth, sharp execution on prime services, strategic deal activity, rock-solid risk management, and cap table cleanup together make this quarter compelling for professional investors. It‚Äôs a shifting story from transactional to platform-driven, recurring, and institutional‚Äîone where scale, integration, and capital management really matter.

[14/08/2025, 11:52:29] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: A few thoughts on Bitcoin & Digital assets love the imagery of HELIUM and BULLISH! 

I guess it should be expected that Bitcoins dominance is sliding, which in crypto-speak means traders have decided they fancy a bit more sex and violence in their portfolios. 
Although many portfolios still have none and remind me of damp dark wet churches where it may be good to hide on roasting 40 Degree days but its all rather miserable and cool but not that COOL! 
Now Solana‚Äôs the current teacher‚Äôs pet, but even Helium that slightly baffling wireless thing ( with insanely +ve user data) and Dogecoin the internet‚Äôs favourite cartoon coin are picking up a tailwind. And then look who else is staggering back onto the pitch: Ethereum, still half the player it was in its glory days; then there‚Äôs Chainlink, criminally overlooked despite doing all the grunt work; Gala, the gaming token that‚Äôs been out in the cold for two years and Toncoin, riding a wave of Telegram-powered hype. All still miles off their all-time highs, but suddenly with a whiff of possibility about them. The lending markets are twitching back to life, liquidity‚Äôs on the turn, and Washington and Westminster are busy removing roadblocks for the very engines that drive these rallies. If history‚Äôs anything to go by, this is the bit where the forgotten coins start going on ridiculous runs and half of Twitter pretends they saw it coming. 
Oh and dont get me started on ‚ÄúBLSH / Bullish, the name alone is a naff wink to financial seriousness , its the City‚Äôs equivalent of a man in mirrored sunglasses telling you he‚Äôs in the know and aiming to be the BlackRock of Crypto, courting $100T of global AUM safely into digital assets.
With nearly $2B in BTC and a profitable core biz in trading (+78% yoy) and media (CoinDesk). Well as everyone is commenting it just pirouetted onto the NYSE yesterday, and has been rewarded with a 220% leap in value before the first glass of warm prosecco lost its fizz. $10bn dollars for a business that made $80 million last year and contrived to lose more than that in the first quarter. It is a delicious little irony. Crypto, the swaggering enfant terrible that swore to topple the banking citadel, has chosen instead to knock politely, hand its coat to JPMorgan, and float itself into the warm, chlorinated pool of Wall Street capital. Communists in pinstripes, raising money from the very thing they vowed to destroy.  There‚Äôs now $400 billion of these crypto-badged equities bobbing about in U.S. markets, exchanges, miners, the digital treasure chests of listed companies all tethered to assets with value only so long as another hand is willing to take them. Two years ago, in the black comedy of the FTX collapse, they were worth much less.  Seeing things like this has a few justified in asking whether blockchain will indeed become the great arterial system of global finance or maybe Bullish is just another golden helium balloon, drifting upwards on hot air, waiting for the pin.‚Äù ( Nutstuff). ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[14/08/2025, 21:03:08] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Oh, here we go again the internet‚Äôs favourite miracle. The car that runs on water. [15/08/2025, 12:08:00] Nick finegold: Pioneer Power Solutions +60% pre open 

For those tracking Pioneer Power Solutions, the micro cap company delivered earnings in line with the guidance they‚Äôve maintained all year.

Pioneer provides mobile power generation to grid gaps , is aligned somewhat to the roll out of Av‚Äôs in time and particularly valuable in remote or underserved areas. 

One of the most intriguing future use cases: as Hyperscalers increasingly drain capacity from the grid, Pioneer‚Äôs upcoming e-mobility home generator (launching late 2025/early 2026) could give homeowners reliable independent, clean propane-powered generation.

The stock is indicated up ~60% pre-market. Still a micro-cap and not for everyone ‚Äî but an interesting one to keep on the radar. I think other Achilles heel is a lack of ability to produce the products they‚Äôre selling in sufficient scale . 

For disclosure I have owned the stock for a year it‚Äôs been an awful performer and have no real intention of selling it or buying more just yet.

[15/08/2025, 14:00:04] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: https://ir.aspisotopes.com/news-events/press-releases/detail/75/asp-isotopes-inc-and-its-subsidiary-quantum-leap-energy
[15/08/2025, 14:00:23] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: ASP Isotopes, Quantum Leap Energy and Fermi America Join Forces to Power the Future of U.S. Nuclear Fuel ‚Äî Ocean Wall Advises on Landmark Deal
 

ASP Isotopes Inc (NASDAQ: ASPI) and subsidiary Quantum Leap Energy LLC (QLE) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding with Fermi America to develop a High Assay Low Enriched Uranium (HALEU) enrichment facility at the planned 11GW HyperGrid Campus in Texas ‚Äî set to be the world‚Äôs largest hybrid energy and data infrastructure site.

The state-of-the-art facility will produce advanced nuclear fuels for small modular reactors, alongside a separate ASP Isotopes-owned site manufacturing stable isotopes for high-growth sectors such as quantum computing, nuclear medicine and next-generation semiconductors.

Co-founded by former U.S. Energy Secretary Rick Perry, Fermi America will lead regulatory approvals, with the HyperGrid site offering unique proximity to the DOE‚Äôs Pantex Plant.

ASP Isotopes has received interest from potential customers who collectively require over $37 billion of HALEU between the present day and 2037, at current market prices.

Ocean Wall Limited acted as exclusive adviser to both ASP Isotopes and Fermi America, playing a critical role in securing this strategic partnership
[15/08/2025, 14:05:06] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Another great deal!
[15/08/2025, 14:08:57] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: I am about to land back in London having spent 3 days in Dallas visiting Fermi America. Their data centre project is 2.5x the size of Stargate and will total 11GW - that is the same amount of power required by the entire state of Tennessee, or 3.5x the city of Dallas. It will include nuclear, gas, solar, battery back up.

Importantly, their neighbours are Pantex - one of the if not the most strategically important nuclear facility in the U.S. - it‚Äôs where the bunker bombs for the recent Iran bombings were built. This means expedited build times for nuclear, and public acceptance already baked in. We could not dream up a more perfect site for ASPI/QLE to commence their ground presence in the U.S. 

The Fermi team are very well connected, backed by Governor Rick Perry and ex CEO of Quantum Energy Partners Toby Neugebaur.

Realistic End-of-Year Range

Based on these collective forecasts and current market dynamics, a well-reasoned estimation for the PPSI stock price by year-end would be:

Base scenario: approximately $10.00‚Äì$11.00, reflecting consensus moderate upside (~140‚Äì160%)

Bullish scenario: up to $12.00, especially if momentum from Q2 results and EV charging demand continues

Downside risk: if execution falters or broader market volatility intensifies, the price might remain below $9.00

‚ÄúUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said he will now travel to Washington to meet with US President Donald Trump to discuss the end of Russia's invasion. ‚Äú

My precursor to Trump meeting Putin in Alaska was: 
The West went all out to destroy Russia and it didn‚Äôt collapse because their strategy was wrong and their narrative was wrong etc Russia now has a huge war conditioned army and the West is in trouble with no Ammo, no men and less and less money. The USA now has different interests in a new world and Europe is not so important. Eurasia with 5 billion people plus is! So you have two simple options, destroy Russia or work with Russia. 

I THINK THIS MORE THAN HELD UP! 
To Nutstuff it is inconceivable that any other US president would have welcomed the Russian with such theatrical warmth. Biden would have wheezed out a rebuke from Delaware; Obama would have made a speech about values. Trump pours the vodka and calls it progress. The Media, Ukrainians and their cheerleaders are having collective aneurysms, but the truth is obvious: Russia‚Äôs had the upper hand for years. Five-to-one on manpower, seven-to-one on kit, and no amount of Western daydreaming about magic weapons changes that. Putin says he wants peace, Trump says ‚Äúno deal yet but maybe next time in Moscow.‚Äù Which is Trump for: I‚Äôll sell it to Zelensky when I can. No ceasefire, no treaty, no champagne just the quiet acceptance that Ukraine can‚Äôt win a war of attrition and will eventually have to sign away land to stop the bleeding. The media are flapping as if it‚Äôs Munich all over again, but the only real takeaway is that both men came out smiling, neither gave an inch, and both know they‚Äôre not actually enemies. So, yes progress, if you can call it that, made over coffee in Anchorage.

[17/08/2025, 17:04:09] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Comment on ASP Isotopes from this weekend‚Äôs The Nuclear Review 

ASP Isoptopes 

Nuclear firms pledge 1,000 jobs at old reactor site. ASP Isotope‚Äôs QLE is partnering with a nuclear fusion company, Astral Systems, to utilize the decommissioned Berkeley nuclear power station in Gloucestershire. QLE says the plant could be commissioned two years after starting. The venture is still in the idea phase, with significant hurdles to overcome on the financial, regulatory, and civil works fronts.

ASP Isotopes enters into a MOU with Fermi America. A major announcement between the massive Fermi project in Texas and ASPI was announced just as we were writing the report. Some major takeaways from the press release:

‚ÄúMOU contemplates the formation of a joint venture between QLE and Fermi America for the development of a HALEU enrichment research and commercial production facility (the ‚ÄúTX JV HALEU Project‚Äù)‚Äù

The significance here is ASPI has finally found a way into the domestic market to claim status as a US owned and operated uranium enrichment company:

‚ÄúFermi America is expected to be responsible for obtaining all licenses, permits, governmental and regulatory approvals, and other required consents for the JV HALEU Project‚Äù

‚ÄúThe property leased by Fermi America ‚Ä¶ is strategically located near the DOE-operated Pantex Plant ‚Ä¶ The site is pre-qualified for nuclear deployment under DOE and NRC precedent studies‚Äù

NR Comments: Entrance into the US market will enable ASPI/QLE to finally potentially compete with Centrus and General Matter. A very significant development for their spinoff of QLE, which is still targeted for Q4 this year.

Burkle, the controlling shareholder, would roll over his stake under the arrangement being discussed, the paper said, citing people familiar with the matter.   Apollo Global Management Inc. would contribute more than $700 million in financing, the paper added. The new equity investors would be led by MCR Hotels, the paper said.

PELOTON/ PTON US. The Market loves a come-back kid! Peloton‚Äôs chart looks like the ECG of a man already being embalmed, but October brings a chance of its improbable resurrection: ‚ÄúPeloton Intelligence‚Äù, an AI nanny that personalises, nags, translates and flatters in real time. The bikes and treadmills are now just props; the real play is the subscription, high-margin, low-churn, AWS-polished. What was once a lump of iron in your living room is trying to reappear as a concierge in your life. But here‚Äôs the thing, the corpse is twitching. They‚Äôve stopped pretending to be a fancy bike shop for bored lawyers in Brooklyn and started acting like a subscription business. Proper sticky stuff too: AI trainers that nag you in real time, workout plans you don‚Äôt have to think about, multilingual subtitles so even the French can understand, and all of it stitched together with AWS so the back end doesn‚Äôt collapse every five minutes. Churn‚Äôs down to 1.2%, margins up at 69%. That‚Äôs software economics, not metal frame and plastic pedal economics. They‚Äôre flogging refurbished gear now, with self-assembly, so you don‚Äôt need a delivery crew in Lycra charging you ¬£200 to screw in a bolt. The bet? They can relaunch in October with their so-called ‚ÄúPeloton Intelligence‚Äù and stop being the punchline of lockdown stocks. If it works, they‚Äôre not a bike company anymore they‚Äôre a sticky AI fitness cult and that =re-rating. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

üìâ *Sell Pitch (Bear case)*
*Intel (INTC US) ‚Äì Sell the Dream*
SoftBank‚Äôs $2bn investment and potential US government stake only buy Intel time ‚Äì they don‚Äôt fix the core problem: strategic paralysis. Intel lost its nerve under Gelsinger, abandoned catch-up investment with TSMC, and has no clear breakup plan under new CEO Tan. Meanwhile, AMD, Nvidia, and Qualcomm are steadily eating Intel‚Äôs market share in PCs and data centres. Customers are losing confidence, competition is accelerating, and execution remains absent. The asset class was the tell: liquidity sloshing around, governments desperate for control, and the dawning realisation that ‚Äústrategic‚Äù really means ‚Äúours, not theirs.‚Äù Meanwhile in Beijing, the firehose of fiscal stimulus still can‚Äôt lift them out of a deflationary undertow. Which means more is coming a lot more. That‚Äôs the other big buy theme: China!!!

‚Äé[21/08/2025, 06:58:51] ~‚ÄØKatie Jackson: ‚Äéimage omitted
[21/08/2025, 09:49:36] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: To this end ‚Ä¶

Nutstuff loves all these rapidly emerging AI doom mongers..

Their case is essentially : 

AI: Another bubble, another load of wide-eyed mugs convinced they‚Äôre buying into the future, when really they‚Äôre just funding the most expensive bonfire since WeWork. $400bn billion on data centres this year sheds stuffed with GPUs that‚Äôll be obsolete before your laptop battery dies. And what do they make? $15bn in revenue. That‚Äôs it. A kebab shop in Croydon makes better margins. ¬£40bn in depreciation before you‚Äôve even sold a licence. Negative 1900% gross margin. They‚Äôre literally giving the stuff away  ‚Äúhave some AI with your latte, sir.‚Äù It‚Äôs lunacy on stilts. But don‚Äôt worry, the tech pm‚Äôs analysts tell us, once revenues grow 10X everything will be fine. Sure. And I‚Äôll be dating Margot Robbie by Christmas. We‚Äôve seen it all before: Global Crossing sank billions into fibre (they used a lot of debt!), shale drillers set fire to cash, cannabis farmers filled warehouses with weed nobody wanted. Now the MAG7 are doing the same. It‚Äôs FOMO as a business model. And where does it end? With these ‚Äúmagnificent‚Äù tech stocks valued like grubby shale firms, 3X cashflow, if they‚Äôre lucky. Investors who cheered it on will suddenly discover they‚Äôve ‚Äúbought a pup‚Äù. The guillotine falls, management gets the sack, shareholders get shafted. Same script, bigger numbers, same idiots funding it.  AI? It‚Äôs not intelligence, artificial or otherwise. It‚Äôs just another bubble, and the only thing it‚Äôs really done is fed greed & disrupted common sense. 

Nutstuffs response is‚Ä¶

$400bn flung at humming sheds of silicon & $15bn trickling back, negative margins that would shame that kebab van at closing time. To the cautious eye, it‚Äôs lunacy a bonfire of capital, d√©j√† vu from fibre, shale, cannabis (lots of alpha YTD for yours truly!) But here‚Äôs the thing: lunacy built the world you live in. FCF has funded it not the $12bn of debt Global crossing accumulated. The bankrupt dot-coms laid the cables your phone still feeds on. The ‚Äúloss-making‚Äù cloud turned into a $100bn utility. Smartphones, derided as toys, reshaped civilisation. Every revolution arrives disguised as financial suicide. Yes, the maths looks grotesque now $40bn in depreciation against $15bn of sales. But depreciation is the down payment on empire. The companies writing these cheques aren‚Äôt start-up chancers, they‚Äôre trillion-dollar leviathans who can afford to lose more money in a quarter than most nations collect in tax. And the governments themselves terrified of being second-tier in the AI arms race will shovel cash in too. So, sneer if you like. Call it a bubble, and you‚Äôll maybe be right, in the short term. The guillotine will fall on plenty of investors. But the survivors will own the rails of the next thirty years (Nutstuff argues for Blockchain rails and the New Protocols, the ‚ÄúBlock 7‚Äù) finance, compute, telecom, infrastructure which means a chance less rent paid to the older world leviathans but still a lot. AI isn‚Äôt just burning cash. It‚Äôs setting fire to the old order. And when the smoke clears, you‚Äôll realise the only thing more absurd than spending $400bn now was not spending it at all. 

BUT I‚Äôd also add: The is/was one of the greatest market pi**-ups in market history $9.6 trillion in four months, all on the back of a few AI fairytales and Nvidia‚Äôs wet dream of infinite growth and most of the City and Wall Street missed it. They sat there, sober, muttering about valuations while the nerds in pyjamas were mainlining call options. Now the charts have cracked, and suddenly every sour-faced fund manager who didn‚Äôt get an invite to the orgy is desperate to call last orders. Not because the technology‚Äôs dead, or because Nvidia suddenly forgot how to print chips but because they can‚Äôt stand the thought of anyone else having made money while they sat it out. That‚Äôs the market now: not bulls versus bears, but the hangover brigade cheering for everyone to throw up. Every dip will be celebrated like England winning a penalty shoot-out. Every dead-cat bounce will be sneered at as ‚Äúfroth‚Äù.
It isn‚Äôt game over for AI. It‚Äôs game over for the mania. And the people most invested in killing it are the ones who never owned a damned share!

‚Äé[21/08/2025, 13:25:44] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: ‚Äéimage omitted

[21/08/2025, 16:02:32] Matt Jonns: I read a wonderful piece on this a couple of years ago that articulated it much better than I ever could ! 

https://www.generalist.com/p/productive-bubbles

If not a subscriber quick summary below‚Ä¶

There are different kinds of bubbles:
	‚Ä¢	Some bubbles destroy value (e.g. tulip mania‚Ä¶lots of hype, nothing lasting..)
	‚Ä¢	Some bubbles actually create value, even if investors lose money (e.g. the railway boom ,, many investors went bust, but the rail network laid the foundation for decades of growth).
	‚Ä¢	AI feels more like a ‚Äúrailway bubble‚Äù‚Ä¶insane amounts of capital will be (is ! Now we are 2 years later it‚Äôs being proven to be true ) deployed, many players won‚Äôt survive, but the infrastructure built (models, compute, tooling, talent base) will massively accelerate future innovation.

‚ÄúPart of the reason even productive bubbles are wasteful is that it‚Äôs incredibly difficult to find ‚Äúkiller applications‚Äù for novel technology. For example, one early use case for the telephone was listening to music; meanwhile, radios only embraced broadcast after World War I. It may take decades for innovation to find its ideal implementation.‚Äù
[21/08/2025, 16:08:33] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Its all too easy to do the railways ‚Äúmisallocation of capital‚Äù argument all because investors lost money. There is so much more to this debate than that, Railways created modern life, cities, trade, time itself even ran on their timetables. Whether Victorian shareholders went bust is frankly trivia. Same with AI: it may be messy, overbuilt and badly valued, but it‚Äôs not optional. It‚Äôs the future turning up, whether you like the valuations or margins! ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[22/08/2025, 06:56:49] Nick finegold: Zoom reported last night , modest single digit growth, but the best numbers in 11 quarters. PE 12x  which is an ex growth multiple. 

However, with almost $8bn of cash vs $21bn of market, $500m of free cash flow per quarter and buying back 5-6m shares a quarter, it now reminds me of eBay , or let‚Äôs call it Value tech ! EBay has gone up 30% post the numbers as the unloved tech companies of yesterday stage a quiet unnoticed comeback .

Financial‚Äôs 
	‚Ä¢	Cash and Liquidity:
Zoom ended the quarter with about $7.8 billion in cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities, excluding restricted cash. 
	‚Ä¢	Share Buyback:
Zoom has a $2.7 billion share buyback plan and accelerated execution in Q2 by purchasing 6 million shares for $463 million. This was an increase of approximately 389,000 shares purchased compared to the previous quarter. This buyback reflects Zoom‚Äôs commitment to returning value to shareholders.
	‚Ä¢	Q3 Revenue Guidance:
Zoom expects Q3 revenue between $1.21 billion and $1.215 billion, representing around 3% year-over-year growth at the midpoint.
	‚Ä¢	Profitability Guidance:
Non-GAAP operating income is expected to be between $465 million and $470 million, translating to an operating margin around 38.6% at the midpoint.
	‚Ä¢	Earnings Per Share (EPS) Guidance:
Non-GAAP EPS is anticipated in the range of $1.42 to $1.44 per share, based on approximately 307 million shares outstanding. Note that this EPS guidance does not account for any future share repurchases.
Overall, Zoom is showing steady revenue growth, healthy operating margins, and is actively buying back shares to enhance shareholder value.

[22/08/2025, 07:42:28] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Writing up our thoughts on this. The world‚Äôs largest producer responsible for >40% of global uranium supply has said its production capabilities are 10% lower than previously announced, removing ~5% of global supply from the market. In addition to this, Kazatomprom are able to exercise an option to produce 20% below this production capability, which they said they intend to exercise given they ‚Äòvalue over volume‚Äô approach. This is essentially Kazatomprom recognising - finally - their pricing power in uranium and will force utilities into the term market to contract. View this release as very smart, very positive for uranium names ahead of WNA in London first week of September.

SOHO-HOUSE: I am amused to see all the celebrity and media spin on this Apollo buy-out. Nick Finegold persuaded me a few years back to speak to management and look at this, and I came away being super impressed with what Nick Jones had built but resoundingly negative on what I saw happening as Ron Burkle got involved. Apollo throwing $850m of their own or others money into Soho House is the financial equivalent of sticking your todger in a blender and hoping it‚Äôll make you a smoothie. The place has never made a profit in 30 years, unless you count the bar staff pocketing the service charge. The whole ‚Äúexclusive club‚Äù aura feels a bit ‚Äúshot‚Äù, there are more members than there are chairs. You‚Äôre paying thousands a year for the privilege of queuing for a flat white next to three influencers, a property developer, and a man in white trainers who looks like he‚Äôs just been turned down for Love Island. The books? A dog‚Äôs breakfast. Fanciful EBITDA, 100-year depreciation schedules, cash flow so bad it makes WeWork look like ‚Ä¶Every trick in the accountant‚Äôs manual short of claiming the Martini glasses as assets. Apollo aren‚Äôt buying a business, they‚Äôre propping up a lifestyle hospice. It‚Äôs not ‚Äúinvestment‚Äù, it‚Äôs charity for the terminally pretentious. And in a few years‚Äô time, when the debt crushes it, Soho House will likely go the way of WeWork with better cocktails. Or some one,  make me a member and show & tell me why I am wrong!

QCOM: so the market has gone full ‚ÄúBacchanal‚Äù ( you should have studied harder in latin!) on AI NVIDIA at $4 trillion, AMD and Broadcom priced like they‚Äôre curing cancer all the while poor old Qualcomm, the company that actually puts the silicon in your pocket, sits sulking in the corner at 13x. Nutstuff remembers taking Irwin Jacobs around Europe twenty-odd years ago. He knew exactly how to tell the story: Qualcomm makes the wireless brain that everything else plugs into. That hasn‚Äôt changed only now it‚Äôs AI, not CDMA. The great AI orgy of 2025 has everyone queuing up to spray money at data centres, but the hangover is coming. Hyperscaler capex will turn into a bonfire of write-downs, and the only AI names left standing will be the ones selling the actual shovels. Qualcomm sells the shovels that go in your pocket,on your face, and into your car.  Phones are becoming inference engines, smart glasses are quietly exploding (Meta Ray-Bans +200%, I addicted to mine!), and every car dashboard refresh is more silicon sold. Meanwhile Qualcomm buys back 1:10 shares and pays you to wait.  
Many ask: Why so cheap? My sense is its simple because the market‚Äôs drunk, high, and tediously hanging off Jensen Huang‚Äôs every leather cladded word, lets wait until Wednesday! But when the come-down hits, Qualcomm will still be compounding, quietly, boringly, at 15x!

Demand for Carbon-12 significantly exceeds the demand for Carbon-14 and the Company is assessing the potential to expand the capacity of the Carbon enrichment facility to be able to supply both Carbon-12 and Carbon-14 from this facility."

Humanoid Horizons: Beijing‚Äôs Robot Games & $5k Androids

Tesla (TSLA) remains analyst top pick with a $410 PT, as humanoid robotics hit a new inflection.

üèü Beijing‚Äôs Big Show
	‚Ä¢	The World Robot Conference (WRC) and the first-ever World Humanoid Robot Games (WHRG) ran just days apart.
	‚Ä¢	200 robotics firms showcased advances; 500+ humanoids competed in athletic and scenario events.
	‚Ä¢	Viral highlights: robots falling, colliding, and malfunctioning ‚Äî but progress mirrors the early days of AVs.
	‚Ä¢	Key takeaway: China has made humanoids a national priority, using the same playbook that vaulted it into EVs, batteries, drones, and solar dominance.

üí° The $5k Breakthrough
	‚Ä¢	Chinese startups (Unitree, EngineAI) unveiled humanoids priced around $5‚Äì6k, opening the door to mass adoption.
	‚Ä¢	The Unitree R1 and EngineAI SA02 aren‚Äôt the most advanced, but they‚Äôre cheap, mass-produced, and critical for gathering training data.
	‚Ä¢	For context: the Unitree G1 ($16k) is already widely deployed ‚Äî even by US universities for AI research.

üá®üá≥ vs üá∫üá∏: Sentiment Gap
	‚Ä¢	Morgan Stanley survey (2k US & China respondents):
	‚Ä¢	US: Net positive 34‚Äì32% on humanoid use cases and 5-year adoption.
	‚Ä¢	China: Net positive 67‚Äì66%, roughly double the US.
	‚Ä¢	On ‚Äúpositive impact on society‚Äù: US just +5%, China a whopping +61%.
	‚Ä¢	Interpretation: state support + media coverage drive Chinese optimism; Western sentiment remains skeptical.

üìà Market Performance
	‚Ä¢	Humanoid 100 Index: +18% since Feb, outpacing S&P 500 and Europe, trailing only MSCI China & Korea.
	‚Ä¢	China Humanoid Value Chain: +16.3% MTD, driven by body (+17.6%), integrators (+15.1%), and brain (+8.1%) plays.
	‚Ä¢	Top performers: Lynas Rare Earths, Northern Rare Earths, Teradyne, Tuopu.

‚öîÔ∏è The Bigger Battle
	‚Ä¢	Beyond hardware, the ‚Äúrobot race‚Äù is a fight for human talent and creativity.
	‚Ä¢	China is cultivating a cultural embrace of robotics across generations, while US policy lags in both support and education.

‚∏ª

üëâ Bottom line: $5k humanoids mark the Model T moment for robotics, and China is steering the race.
