[27/08/2025, 10:42:50] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Ok my last on this for now but to paint colours to the mast again! 

Great question! 
What‚Äôs nuclear trying to achieve? One line: it‚Äôs about not being bent over by Russia every winter! 
In the West, Nuclear is dressed up as ‚Äúgreen power‚Äù because we‚Äôre desperate to virtue-signal. In reality it‚Äôs about one thing: energy security. A lump of uranium the size of a Coke can can power your life for decades. Try doing that with windmills and solar panels in a country that spends half the year under clouds.  
And yes, China has 3,300 coal plants and is building 400 more which makes our suicidal irrational hair-shirt obsession with net zero looks even more lunatic. But here‚Äôs the difference: China also builds nuclear. 
They don‚Äôt see it as either/or, they see it as both. Nuclear back up actually. Coal keeps the lights on now, nuclear secures the furure. Profitable? Eventually, yes. ( oh gosh shall we talk AI for a moment?!) 
A nuclear plant is like building an aircraft carrier: eye-watering upfront, but once it‚Äôs there it churns out power 24/7 for 50 years at a marginal cost close to zero. Gas plants bleed you every year on fuel imports, nuclear doesn‚Äôt. France has had cheap, reliable power for half a century precisely because it built a fleet of reactors while we were still arguing about coal strikes. Nuclear isn‚Äôt about being ‚Äúgreen‚Äù, as to profitable? Only if you measure profit over decades, not quarterly earnings.

[27/08/2025, 17:14:37] ~‚ÄØMatt H: Only some market news: Lithium - Chinese lithium prices retreat, but peak-season restocking gains momentum (Platts):  Chinese domestic lithium spot prices fell in the week ended Aug. 22, as sentiment weakened following a sharp drop in lithium carbonate futures on the Guangzhou Futures Exchange. Market participants attributed the futures decline to aggressive long liquidation rather than fundamentals. As spot prices slipped below Yuan 83,000/mt, trading activity picked up sharply. Sources said the lower prices encouraged downstream restocking. A major battery maker was heard reducing the supply of lithium carbonate to its cathode customers as its lepidolite mine suspended production, while other cathode producers replenished inventories ahead of the September‚ÄìOctober peak season.
=> Asia seaborne lithium inch lower tracking domestic lithium prices: Asian seaborne lithium saw a slight downtrend Aug. 22, tracking the domestic Chinese lithium chemical prices. An offer for battery-grade lithium carbonate on a CIF North Asia basis was reported at $9,600/mt on Aug. 22.
"There's been more inquiries in the market for battery-grade lithium carbonate for imports to China," said a trader, however, cautioning that he was unsure if it was driven by actual demand or sentiments. The trader maintained that the lithium market remained in a surplus.

[28/08/2025, 09:17:14] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Nutstuff might take a smidge of credit but met them and then saw CEO post Lansdowne day! 

TUNGSTEN: China‚Äôs dominance in critical-mineral mining and processing grants it a substantial advantage and jeopardises global supply-chain reliability. Tungsten is one such critical mineral. Tungsten is significant in several industries due to its exceptional properties, including its melting point (3,442¬∞C), the highest among metals; high density; extreme hardness; and appropriate electrical and thermal conductivity. Additionally, its chemical stability and corrosion resistance make it perfect for industrial applications. Unlike lead and uranium, tungsten is non-toxic and environmentally harmless, making it a preferred material in specialised equipment. The U.S. hasn‚Äôt mined tungsten in a decade, whereas China supplies 82.7% of global consumption. According to the latest United States Geological Survey (USGS) data, China holds over 52% of international reserves, while the U.S. has zero.  Vietnam is the second-largest miner, supplying 4.2% of global production, followed by Russia and North Korea at 2.5% and 2.1%, respectively. Together with China, the four countries produce over 90% of the world‚Äôs tungsten. More importantly, Vietnam‚Äôs production relies on a single mine (Nui Phao, the largest mine outside China), which has reported a steady drop in output from around 4,800 tons in 2022 to 3,400 tons in 2024, owing primarily to deteriorating-ore grades. Tungsten is a pivotal mineral for innovating and making next-generation technologies more efficient. In the military sector, tungsten is vital for armor-piercing munitions, tank armor, and missiles. It is also an essential raw material for Abram M1 tanks, the Phalanx anti-missile Gatling guns, GNU-44 Viper strike missiles, and hypersonic weapons. Due to its extreme-heat resistance, tungsten enhances the efficiency of solar panels, semiconductors, robotics, and nuclear-fusion reactors. There IS a very real UK play: TUNGSTEN LN.

[28/08/2025, 21:24:00] Nick finegold: Newmont (NYSE:NEM) may impose deep job cuts as part of a sweeping cost-cutting drive, Bloomberg reported Wednesday.

Newmont's (NYSE:NEM) costs jumped following its $15B acquisition of Newcrest Mining in 2023, with its all-in sustaining costs rising to an all-time high earlier this year, taking a chunk out of strong earnings generated by record gold prices that hit an all time high of $3,500/oz in April.

The world's largest gold miner reportedly has told managers it wants to be more in line with its lowest-cost peers, which would mean cutting costs by as much as $300/oz, or ~20%.

[29/08/2025, 07:28:12] Nick finegold: For anyone not on Jonny Haycock‚Äôs newsletter on gold & silver it‚Äôs excellent and here‚Äôs a summary . 

Gold vs. Treasuries: A Historic Shift
	‚Ä¢	For the first time since 1996, foreign central banks now hold more gold than U.S. Treasuries (Tavi Costa). Echoes of the 1970s suggest this could be the start of a major global rebalancing.

Drivers of Demand
	1.	China: Regulators already require big insurers to hold 1% of assets in physical gold. That may soon apply to all insurers, with the quota rising to 5% ‚Äî a seismic shift.
	2.	India: Pension funds may lift their 5% cap on gold ETFs, adding institutional weight in one of the world‚Äôs largest gold markets. ETF assets already grew 96% YoY.
	3.	GLD: A record $1bn dark-pool trade went through this week ‚Äî likely sovereign wealth fund buying.

Silver Joins the Party
	‚Ä¢	U.S. added silver to its Strategic Minerals list for the first time ‚Äî key for defence, EVs, solar. At $39/oz, silver is far below its 2011 peak ($48) and deeply undervalued relative to gold. Tight physical supply suggests any new buyer could trigger a price spike.

Macro Backdrop
	‚Ä¢	In the UK, economists warn Rachel Reeves may need an IMF bailout to stabilize government finances. Long-end gilt yields are already higher than during the Liz Truss crisis ‚Äî bond markets may act before the Autumn budget.

The Big Picture
	‚Ä¢	After months of consolidation, gold and silver face converging tailwinds: central banks, insurers, pensions, SWFs, and geopolitics.
	‚Ä¢	Pressure is building for the next leg higher.

They‚Äôve got PET Labs churning out record doses of medical isotopes, giving free treatments to children in South Africa (think SA government goodwill), they‚Äôre spinning out Quantum Leap Energy for HALEU fuel, they‚Äôve just listed in Johannesburg to tap new capital pools, and institutional ownership is already over 70%.
The Management bench has gone from two blokes and a Bunsen burner to 170 PhDs and ex-army planners.
Valuation? Yes, it‚Äôs a run, but you‚Äôre buying a first-mover in one of the rarest businesses on Earth, isotope enrichment all tied directly into megatrends: nuclear power, semiconductors, oncology. 
Management reckon $300m in EBITDA by 2030 and Mkt cap today of $850m.
Even if they miss, you‚Äôve still got a company controlling bottlenecks that Washington, Beijing, and every hospital oncology ward can‚Äôt live without.

[04/09/2025, 06:22:23] ~‚ÄØKatie Jackson: FT Big Read: How to make British homes affordable again‚Ä¶

https://on.ft.com/46iEfno


üá¨üáßüè† *UK Housing Market ‚Äì Dysfunction at its Core*
	‚Ä¢	House prices have quadrupled since 1997, far outpacing incomes.
	‚Ä¢	Problems: poor housing stock, high rents, shrinking social housing, rising homelessness.
	‚Ä¢	Land, not buildings, makes up 70%+ of home value ‚Äì fuelling rent-seeking over productivity.
	‚Ä¢	Supply-side focus (1.5m new homes) won‚Äôt fix affordability ‚Äì evidence suggests the issue is more about demand, credit liberalisation, and unequal distribution.
	‚Ä¢	Current property taxes (stamp duty, council tax) distort the market.

*Conclusion:*
True reform needs bold land and property tax changes ‚Äì not just more building. Without addressing affordability, land values, and tax distortions, the UK‚Äôs housing dysfunction will persist.

üßø *3i Group*: The Action-Packed Compounding Machine

3i isn‚Äôt your typical PE firm. It‚Äôs capital-light, cash-rich, and built around *Action* - Europe‚Äôs fastest-growing discount retailer.

üìà *Since 2012*, under Simon Borrows, NAV/share has grown 9√ó, TSR CAGR >20%, and the dividend‚Äôs up 20% YoY.

*üéØ The Thesis:*

- *Action = The Engine* ‚Üí 2,900+ stores, ‚Ç¨2.3bn run-rate EBITDA, 6.9% LFL growth YTD. Mgmt sees capacity to *triple* footprint.
- *Simon Borrows = The Edge* ‚Üí Rare capital allocator. ¬£700m skin in the game. High ROIC, low churn, no hype.
- *Cash Machine* ‚Üí ¬£2.4bn realised in 2025, 3% gearing, rising dividends, no external LPs.

*Catalysts üîú:*

- üìÜ Near term: More store rollouts + realisations (MPM was 3.2x MoM).
- üõí Medium: Action expands into new markets (Portugal, Romania, UK/US optionality).
- üß¨ Long term: New ‚ÄúAction-like‚Äù bets (Royal Sanders, EBG) + clarity on succession.

In a market full of noise, 3i is disciplined, shareholder-friendly, and still under-owned.

Premium? Yes. But sometimes *you pay up for quality*.

[04/09/2025, 14:33:23] ~‚ÄØKatie Jackson: üí¨ *Table Talk*

_*A Summary of Curation Collective‚Äôs Roundtable Discussion: A Year Half Full*_

üîó¬†*Replay: https://vimeo.com/1115752264?share=copy#t=0*

*üáÆüá≥¬†India: High-Growth Consumption Plays*

- *India = Fastest-growing major economy* (7.8% GDP growth)
- *Policy Bazaar*: Dominates online insurance (~94% digital share)
- *Swiggy*: Leader in food & quick commerce, 35%+ revenue CAGR
- *MakeMyTrip*: US-listed proxy on Indian travel boom (54‚Äì60% OTA share)

---

*üá¨üáß¬†UK: Fiscal Stress & North Sea Special Sits*

- *UK macro under pressure*: Debt >100% of GDP, rising gilts, weak sterling
- *North Sea oil = under-owned hedge* amid tax changes and supply security push
- Stocks flagged:
    - *Jersey Oil & Gas, Hartshead, Ithaca, Kistos, Serica* ‚Äì energy upside
    - *Ashtead Tech, National Grid, Balfour Beatty* ‚Äì infra, tools, grid

---

*üá®üá≥¬†China: Opportunity Amid Sinophobia*

- *Geopolitics shifting*: Russia-China-India realignment
- *Stimulus bets*: Solar, semis, education, gaming
- Stocks covered:
    - *Tencent*: Solid growth
    - *Las Vegas Sands*: Asia travel proxy via Marina Bay Sands

---

*üíõü©∂ Gold, Silver & Digital Hedging*

- *Gold = Inflation + geopolitical hedge*; digital gold in focus
- *India households hold 18% in gold* ‚Äì structural demand
- *Silver*: Rising industrial use in tech, batteries, solar
- *Target of $10,000 gold* discussed ‚Äì not consensus but part of bull case

[05/09/2025, 09:24:28] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: QUANTUM COMPUTING/UK: Hats off to Brit Ilyas Khan for raising cash for Quantinuum at a $10bn valuation in its latest fundraising. For those head-scratching Normal computers are basically light switches, billions of them, that flip between 0 and 1 really fast. Quantum computers are more like a pint of Guinness that can be both full and empty at the same time until you look at it. That‚Äôs because the ‚Äúquantum bits‚Äù (qubits) can be 0, 1, or both, thanks to spooky physics. Stack enough of these Guinness-bits together and you can, in theory, solve certain problems millions of times faster than even the beefiest supercomputer. Yes, yes this is the threat to Bitcoin et al, but frankly the Bitcoin network will patch itself and restore much quicker than Banking and Enterprise security so spare me the tales ofrypto Doom from your Web 2.0 world!

[05/09/2025, 12:10:29] ~‚ÄØSSCOOK: ASHM - reported FY results today and the -6% reaction shows that their problems in core EM debt biz  (50% of AUM) continues to weigh on them. 

For FY 25 group outflows were 12% of beg AUM and EM debt fee erosion continues - management fees are down to 25-30bps. Their local currency EM biz (the gem of group) has been hit hardest by outflows so not seeing any tailwind from DM debt coming their way‚Ä¶yet through end of June.  Looks like spreads on their all their EM products are already tight relative to recent history so this may not be the catalyst unless it can push into a new range. Strangely, their EM debt performance has been pretty good in 1 & 3 year view but has not been able to stop outflow momentum. 

Best part of story is DPS yield 11% and xs capital 45% of market cap (they have never bought back shares). I like your point on inside ownership and have often wondered when they would sell. Shockingly their AUM is $48bn at June 2025 down from $94bn in June 2021 so they really missed out a lot not cashing out earlier. 

Commentary on EM is positive - has been all the way down and sounds like they are pushing how well their EM equity biz (18% of AUM) is doing and not their EM debt so much‚Ä¶

[05/09/2025, 19:00:52] ~‚ÄØJim: Hi Philip, they are slightly different business models. Coinshares is essentially an asset manager whose revenue is fee linked to the funds they manage. It‚Äôs roughly 70% from Bitcoin related ETP‚Äôs and the rest is Solana and Ethereum. They also have income lines from staking, advisory and trading. They currently have a net cash position. If you assume current asset prices the earnings power from here is $200m pa. The current market cap is $800m so is on a forward p/e today of 4x. The cash conversion is huge so ex investments the free cashflow yield is north of 20%. So with Coinshares you are playing predominantly Bitcoin with a sprinkling of Ethereum and Solana but   I think the upside comes with the rerating. It‚Äôs appallingly covered given its legacy Swedish listing but hopefully the proposed move to the US will help realise the inherent value . Club call with Coinshares on 17th Sept.
[06/09/2025, 08:14:27] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: In simpler terms: 
Coinbase is the slick casino,
$50bn market cap, hyped to the moon, one regulator away from obliteration but just mints money when volumes rip. CoinShares is the scruffy bookmaker in Jersey tiny mkt cap, steady ETP fees, real dividends, valued like it‚Äôs one scandal from zero. One is flashy Vegas glitz, the other‚Äôs a cheap pint in a pub. 
So, Coinbase = high-beta trade on digital asset mania.
CoinShares = a asymmetric ‚Äúsleeper‚Äù on similar with some takeover optionality.
Hope helpful‚Ä¶

[08/09/2025, 16:59:15] ~‚ÄØAndrew Draycott: Lithium remains one of the most cyclical commodities today‚Äînot because demand is weak, but because the industry is still maturing. Short-term price swings are often driven by small, fragmented supply sources, yet demand continues to grow strongly. Once dominated by the EV narrative, the outlook is now substantially amplified by the rise in battery energy storage systems (BESS). This shift is widely recognized‚Äîincluding in recent Goldman Sachs research highlighting the surge in energy storage deployments that underpin expanding lithium requirements.

Africa illustrates this dual reality well. It is home to two of the top five lithium deposits globally‚ÄîGoulamina in Mali and Manono in the DRC‚Äîdemonstrating its importance as a future hub of large-scale supply. At the same time, the continent also saw a wave of low-cost artisanal production enter the market in the last cycle, pushing prices down. That artisanal supply is inherently unsustainable and difficult to grow, and as the industry matures, it is becoming far less influential. Instead, the market is being reshaped around scalable Tier 1 assets, which require higher, stable prices to justify the capital and operating expenditure needed to bring them online.

Lithium Argentina stands out as a rare, world-class platform, backed by Ganfeng‚Äîthe world‚Äôs largest integrated lithium company. It gives investors direct exposure to one of the most strategic producing regions on the planet, with access to capital, technical capability, and offtake that others simply cannot match. The current downturn offers a compelling entry point: valuations today reflect the bottom of the cycle, not the future tightening of supply against structural demand. For investors seeking optionality, Lithium Africa‚Äîalso partnered with Ganfeng‚Äîprovides a speculative, higher-risk avenue into Africa‚Äôs emerging potential.

[08/09/2025, 20:36:55] ~‚ÄØMatt H: In my opinion China controls most of the minor metals in the world. Lithium had a huge rise a few years ago because the local & governmental agencies in China would only issue permits to build battery factories that could secure mineral supply and prove it( not just lithium, nickel, manganese etc) . All the battery manufacturers competed with each other to secure supply and prices went parabolic in for want of a better term the gold rush(EV/battrey rush). Lithium is one of the most abundant minerals in the world and isn‚Äôt that difficult to extract with some Chinese miners being able to bring on supply in 12 months. The Chinese control  lithium and other minor metals & after the initial rush they know exactly what the cost of production is globally and will let producers make a small margin, enough to keep them going, to ensure there is a stable supply but they don‚Äôt let prices run too high as it is to their determent. Lithium is in this category and while you will see price movements the Chinese will quash it if runs too hard. 
Rare earths and some other minor metals which are not abundant are different. The US and Europe have woken up to the fact that outsourced environmental pollution that comes with the processing of these metals is almost solely controlled by the Chinese and while there are rare earths deposits in the West and Africa the environmental cost of producing them is hard to stomach. They are very dirty. Building smelters and refineries is tough. The State department has a huge focus on securing minerals considered essential for US security. It will take upto ten years or more for the US to even touch the sides of China‚Äôs dominance which means you will get wild price swings in minor metals. Lithium I am not as bullish about in the long term despite the projected demand.

[09/09/2025, 14:46:54] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Energy Fuels (UUUU) just hit a major milestone. Their U.S.-mined and Utah-processed NdPr oxide has now been manufactured into commercial-scale rare earth permanent magnets for EV and hybrid drive units ‚Äî the first fully U.S. ‚Äúmine-to-magnet‚Äù supply chain.
Key points:
NdPr from Florida & Georgia, processed in Utah, converted into NdFeB magnets by South Korea‚Äôs largest motor core maker, fully validated by major automakers.
Enough magnets already produced to power ~1,500 EVs, with immediate entry into the supply chain.
Pilot production of 99.9% dysprosium oxide underway, with heavy REE capacity coming in 2026.
This move materially reduces reliance on China and positions Energy Fuels as the only U.S. company with a complete rare earth supply chain.
Clear strategic and commercial implications as they now enter long-term supply negotiations with global OEMs.

‚Äé[10/09/2025, 15:37:41] ~‚ÄØCharlie Morris: ‚Äéimage omitted
[10/09/2025, 15:41:31] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Yes but everyone is missing the point, bla bla old men talking about Optical fibre and Cisco and Global crossing etc.

Yes Oracle is suddenly the belle of the AI ball, but the real magic trick happened years ago, Larry quietly shrank the share count by 30% at a $55 average while the Street was yawning. That‚Äôs financial engineering on steroids: it turbo-charges EPS, juices the multiple, and now with AI tailwinds and a trillion-dollar valuation in sight makes Oracle look like a rocket ship. The kicker? They still need fresh financing muscle to deliver on finger in the air promises and build the data-centre empire, but to a degree the heavy lifting for shareholders is already done.

[12/09/2025, 11:07:16] Nick finegold: Maybe the most interesting thing about Atome is that they are creating a blue print for repetition . 

Ie we have always maintained that it‚Äôs pretty incredible that a ¬£25m market cap company can raise ¬£650m of debt and equity . 

The only way this is possible is by 

1) having proven technology that investors know works. 

2) having a stable and tax beneficial country in which to build the plant with plentiful clean power tied up . 

3) having a legally binding offtake agreement that means you know you will sell everything you make once it‚Äôs built. Those are the cornerstones of the financing packages it provides reasonable surety front to back. 

At current market prices this plant should do ¬£60m+ of ebit. As I have said before we need greater clarity on how much falls through to the bottom line of the PLC . 

However , the thing the company doesn‚Äôt really talk about is that they have now established a blue print that is repeatable in other locations so plant 2 & 3 are also possible at some stage  etc . 

We shall see but an interesting one to watch .

[12/09/2025, 16:38:02] ~‚ÄØKC Shetty: I have no  expertise to value add  but sharing below , from a friend, on BMNR, as mentioned often here...



We looked at them a couple of years ago, as bankers were pitching them as a distressed asset. Tom Lee is a great guy, but the mNAV premium for his DAT has has all but disappeared, and the ability to generate an mNAV premium without levering up is difficult, even with a rock star like Tom. We had dinner at a table with Michael Saylor last night, and his big pitch is to utilize preferred shares to create layers of debt that effectively never mature and require very little share dilution to cover the cost of dividends. Of course, all of this works in bull markets; it is not clear how Strategy will fare when the market goes south, as Strategy had an mNAV discount for a while in the past bear market. All that being said, Saylor is reasonably humble in all of this, and he knows there are limitations on a DAT strategy.
[12/09/2025, 16:40:18] ~‚ÄØChris Dale: Not sure on that one. The one I don‚Äôt like is EDPR
[12/09/2025, 17:44:04] ~‚ÄØAdam Calman: Really sorry to hear about Richard‚Äòs situation. I myself had a brain tumour, albeit thankfully benign, 10 years ago. 

My experience on insurance is as follows, albeit not on health, but on income replacement. Understanding small print and nuanced tax law, saved me a fortune.

I had an income replacement policy through LivVic, on which I was given advice by my IFA to pay for myself, out of PAYE taxed income, rather than my employer paying the premiums for me and then treating that policy as a benefit in kind.

The result, when I successfully claimed the income replacement, following my brain surgery and subsequent ‚Äúretirement‚Äù due to the mental effects from the brain surgery, was that the ‚Äúsalary‚Äù was paid gross, without any income tax deducted. 

The revenue deems this a non-taxable payment, from an insurance policy, so for 10 years, I‚Äôve had the benefit of my entire cover paid to me without deduction tax. 

Saved me +40% all the way up. 

The advice therefore is to check your whether your employer is happy to arrange the policy is this way.

Happy to have offline chats if anyone wants‚Ä¶

[12/09/2025, 17:54:09] ~‚ÄØWilliam Johnston: I think Tom Lee should stay in his lane. He is a great bull strategist, but he is a sell out when it comes to shitcoins. Frankly I have a pretty dim view of Ethereum which backs BMNR. I invested back in 2016. But a wallet got hacked in one of their smart contracts. The Ethereum foundation then forked the protocol to freeze out the hacked coins.  This is no different from a Central Bank controlling your money. Since then I have been 100% Bitcoin. Ethereum has since morphed into a proof of stake protocol like the rest of the shitcoins.  Proof of stake, as opposed to Bitcoin‚Äôs, proof of work favours the holders with the largest supply of coins. Bitcoin is a democracy of nodes. So whales have no influence.  Also Tom Lee was a supporter of a fork of Bitcoin, BSV that was created by the fraud Craig Wright who claimed to be Satoshi who had the book thrown at him by the UK law courts, and has since fled the county. At the highs industrialists, global and local  institutional managers, analysts would be bullish and reverse at the lows.

[14/09/2025, 12:02:50] ~‚ÄØDipesh Patel: The idea, as you say, is you're buying before it turns. That turn can come from 
1) a reversal/less obvious headwind from Apple's move away from Qual (both the 17 and 17 pro use Qualcomm modems because they are much faster than Apple's own). Qualcomm has already guided to zero Apple modems from this year so headwind > tailwind 
2) a material shift in revs and profits from Qualcomm's position in autos which appears to be showing structural shifts. One theme I'm playing is that the cars of tomorrow are totally different eco systems. We've already started to see this but it may end up on steroids! London to Bristol driverless is a movie with surround sound or a whole office set up much more than today. All that connectivity is Qualcomm, Horizon Robotics (for ADAS) etc.
3) faster connectivity processing more AI, faster LLMs and related apps will all require faster leading modems = Qualcomm. 
It's cheap enough to take the risk IMO.

[15/09/2025, 19:31:31] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Hearing that US Government are set to announce replenishment of strategic uranium reserves. We saw a similar program in the first Trump Admin but only $150m. I would assume this programme will be significantly larger. North American names are up 10-15%.
‚Äé[15/09/2025, 19:31:45] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: ‚Äéimage omitted
[15/09/2025, 19:37:24] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-09-15/us-looks-to-boost-strategic-uranium-reserve-for-nuclear-power#:~:text=The%20Trump%20administration's%20top%20energy,prospects%20of%20nuclear%20power%20generation.
[15/09/2025, 20:09:16] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Spoke to Scott Melbye, Chairman of Uranium Producers of America who has been lobbying for this for some time.

Their main focus has been on: 

* Reducing reliance on Russia and China
* Expand the US Strategic Uranium Reserve not just for energy but defence
* Get uranium on the Critical Minerals list which brings with it expedited permitting and licensing 

Today‚Äôs announcement feels like a starter for ten and we expect more granular details to follow such as pricing, volumes, and which producers will be the beneficiaries of these deals.

It seems unlikely to us that UEC will not be at outsized winner in this space given their grip on permitted uranium assets, mills, and recently conversion. In 2022, UEC was paid >30% premium for lbs during Trump‚Äôs first $150m Strategic Reserve purchase. At the time, Trump recommended $1.5bn spent over 10 years on the Strategic Reserve, BUT that was before Trump‚Äôs stated goal of quadrupling nuclear power, and before we really started to see the AI power movement accelerate.

We would therefore expect to see at a minimum $1.5bn of announced purchasing by the US Government in follow up announcements. That would equate to ~20m lbs, less than half of what the US consumes on an annual basis. There is a high likelihood in our view that the programme could be more aggressive than that. 

UEC has pounded the drum on remaining unhedged and not selling lbs into the term market. While production ramp up remains in its infancy stage, the premium for US uranium is only increasing day-by-day. 

We will write up fuller thoughts as we get more details on the terms of this announcement but the sector has reacted positively with major names up 5-10%.

[17/09/2025, 14:41:10] ~‚ÄØJonny Haycock: June 18, 1815. The Battle of Waterloo.

Cannons thundered in Belgium. In London, traders held their breath.

If Napoleon won, British bonds would collapse. If Wellington won, they‚Äôd soar.

Legend says Nathan Rothschild had something no one else had:

A flock of carrier pigeons waiting on the battlefield.

While official couriers would take days, his birds flew through the night.

At dawn on June 19, a pigeon landed in London with a tiny message tied to its leg:

Wellington had won.

Rothschild rushed to the Exchange. But instead of buying, he began to sell.

Aggressively. Publicly. Relentlessly.

Panic spread. ‚ÄúIf Rothschild is selling, Napoleon must have won.‚Äù

Prices collapsed as traders dumped their bonds in fear.

Only in the final moments did Rothschild signal his agents.

They bought everything at rock-bottom prices.

The next morning, the official news arrived: Wellington‚Äôs victory.

British bonds soared. Rothschild‚Äôs fortune soared with them.

Did it happen exactly this way? Historians debate it.

But the story survives because it reveals a truth bigger than the trade:

Markets aren‚Äôt just numbers on a screen.

They‚Äôre human emotion, compressed into prices.

Fear. Greed. Hope. Despair.

And the greatest fortunes in history weren‚Äôt built by chasing speed.

They were built by mastering patience.

By seeing through the fog of panic when everyone else is blind.

By remembering that chaos is temporary, but discipline compounds forever.

Rothschild‚Äôs pigeons are long gone.

But his lesson is eternal:

The strongest signal in markets isn‚Äôt in the data. It‚Äôs in human behavior.

And if you can stay calm when the world around you trembles, the future will always fly in your direction.
[17/09/2025, 14:42:22] ~‚ÄØJonny Haycock: Appreciate that this is bottom up stock picking chat but I was reminded of this great story and all the lessons within it and thought worth sharing.

[18/09/2025, 06:10:16] Nick finegold: Evolv Meeting 
Takeaway

Maybe the hardest thing in investing is holding on to a stock that‚Äôs a true winner. 

Evolv‚Äôs management were deeply impressive, their execution since taking charge close to perfect ‚Äî the team seem to  benchmark themselves against Axon, a hardware and software package that delivers unrelenting recurring revenues , I bought Axon 4 years ago its since gone up 3,000% and  I sold after it too had doubled.  I won‚Äôt be making the same mistake with Evolv .


Evlv doesn‚Äôt have the same moat but these are 4 year contracts with an intelligent software package attached. 

The lesson: conviction and patience matter most.

Evolv‚Äôs team estimates they‚Äôre in just 7,000 doorways out of 700,000‚Äîbarely 1% penetration‚Äîso they‚Äôre creating an entirely new category rather than displacing incumbents. The addressable market is already vast, and likely understated. 

The real challenge for us as investors?

Simply holding on 

For disclosure Evlv as you know is by far my biggest personal position. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

Yet, trading on just ~10√ó earnings, it remains hidden in plain sight.

I‚Äôve  asked Raj at Stoic Point Capital to dig deeper into how the SPAC structure might take shape. He is a world expert on Spac structures and it‚Äôs not a very that they will end up with $600m of cash , not that it changes too much . 

We‚Äôll update members once he‚Äôs spoken to the company. 

For now, this feels like a rare, overlooked opportunity first spotted by Jim Rutherford to whom I am deeply grateful . This stock is an example of the club working at its absolute best to find simple profitable overlooked opportunities hidden in plain sight .

[19/09/2025, 17:00:30] ~‚ÄØMatt H: A long AI query on silver. 
Bottom Line: SLV is experiencing an extreme shortage of borrowable shares due to a combination of high short interest, massive options expiry, and potential short squeeze conditions.
Key Factors Behind the Borrowable Share Shortage:
1. Dramatic Reduction in Available Shares
The number of SLV shares available for borrowing has plummeted from 10 million to a mere 10,000 in just two weeks, representing a 99.9% reduction The number of SLV shares available for borrowing has plummeted from 10 million to a mere 10,000 in just two weeks. This creates an extremely tight supply of shares available for short sellers to borrow.
2. Massive Options Expiry Pressure
A staggering 47,000 in-the-money (ITM) calls on the iShares Silver Trust (SLV) ETF are set to expire, representing a potential demand for 4.7 million shares The number of SLV shares available for borrowing has plummeted from 10 million to a mere 10,000 in just two weeks. With only 10,000 shares available to borrow, this creates a 470:1 imbalance between potential demand and available supply.
3. Skyrocketing Borrowing Costs
The borrowing fee for SLV has recently skyrocketed, increasing tenfold in a single day to reach 11.51% SubstackUSAGOLD. These extreme borrowing costs indicate severe market stress and supply shortages.
4. High Short Interest
The latest short interest data for the largest silver exchange traded fund (ETF) iShares Silver Trust 'SLV', holding 454 million (M) oz. of silver, are dated March 31, 2025 and show a growth of shorts now to 69.6M shares or 14% of the total 499M shares issued - the largest short interest in 2025 iShares SLV Silver ETF Short Interest Is Cooking Higher.
5. Physical Redemption Pressure
Investors appear to be redeeming SLV shares for physical silver at an accelerating rate, draining the ETF's liquidity while simultaneously driving up the cost of maintaining short positions Silver Squeeze Intensifies: SLV ETF Faces Physical Redemption Crisis As Borrowing Costs Soar To 11.5% - USAGOLD.
Market Implications:
The convergence of these factors - the large number of ITM calls expiring, the minimal shares available to borrow, and the soaring borrowing fees - suggests that silver shorts are indeed in a precarious position. The potential for a short squeeze has increased significantly, which could lead to rapid upward price movements in silver SubstackUSAGOLD.
This situation is creating what analysts describe as unprecedented stress as a drastic reduction in available shares for borrowing collides with surging demand for physical redemptions Silver Squeeze Intensifies: SLV ETF Faces Physical Redemption Crisis As Borrowing Costs Soar To 11.5% - USAGOLD, making it extremely difficult for short sellers to find shares to borrow for covering positions or establishing new short positions into expiry.

[20/09/2025, 13:11:30] ~‚ÄØSimon Brewer: The gold bullion price has touched the US$3,700/oz level this week, above GREED & fear‚Äôs initial gold price target of US$3,400/oz set back in December 2002. The methodology of the target is to adjust the 1980 peak gold price of US$850/oz by the growth in US disposable personal income per capita which has occurred since January 1980.

Based on the latest data on US disposable income per capita, a price of US$6,600/oz is now a reasonable price target for gold at the peak of the current secular bull market. GREED & fear maintains the 40% weight in bullion in the global portfolio for a US dollar-denominated pension fund first set up at the end of 3Q02. That 40% weighting has been a minimum allocation to gold bullion ever since. Gold was reduced from 50% in December 2020 when GREED & fear first allocated an investment in Bitcoin in the same portfolio.

AI & BUBBLES: of course Classic Economist! Owned by Grumpie old men and read by them. 
Honestly, the only thing more tedious than the endless chorus of ‚Äúthis can‚Äôt last‚Äù is the sheer confidence with which people who‚Äôve been wrong for a decade keep repeating it. It‚Äôs like listening to your drunk uncle at Christmas misquote Churchill while spilling gravy down his tie. Markets don‚Äôt give a toss about your feelings, your faintly Marxist ‚Äúvaluations are stretched‚Äù mantra, or your half-remembered Economy 101 lectures. They care about capital flows, supply and demand, and who‚Äôs actually making money. The irony is that most of these doom-botherers have missed every rally since Netscape, spend their lives shorting Amazon in 1999, Bitcoin in 2014, and AI today and then wonder why nobody takes them seriously. The naysayer‚Äôs role in markets is a bit like a wasp at lunch outside: buzzing, unpleasant, occasionally stinging someone who deserves it  but mostly an irritant that everyone else wishes would sod off so we can enjoy the sunshine.
Consider this: in the dot-com era, the ‚ÄúChatGPT moment‚Äù was Netscape in 1995. Five years later the bubble popped barely enough time to lay fibre, let alone build a flywheel. Now what? We‚Äôre now building off a mountain, not a molehill & oceans of data, industrial-scale compute, hyperscaler infrastructure. This isn‚Äôt Pets.com flogging dog food; it‚Äôs machines teaching machines at exponential pace. When a Tesla spots a kangaroo, within minutes every Tesla knows how kangaroos bounce. That‚Äôs not linear, it‚Äôs compounding. Eric Schmidt says AI is under hyped. Jensen Huang says demand is exponential. Safra Catz says it‚Äôs insatiable. (They would you say!) but yes Palantir reckons sales go up tenfold. Anthropic says compute doubles every six months. And that‚Äôs before computers start training computers. Expensive? Sure. A short-term top? Possibly. A bubble? Don‚Äôt be ridiculous. Calling this a bubble is like standing on the shoreline during the Industrial Revolution, sneering at steam engines because coal prices just went up. It‚Äôs not a fad this is the plumbing of the next century. If you want to use Golf club analogies ( the 3rd owner is the one who makes the money) probably thats where you should be.

‚ÄúAI‚Äù: KWEB US, QCOM, INTEL, ALIBABA, TENCENT, NEBIUS, GOOGL, ASML.

[20/09/2025, 15:23:54] ~‚ÄØMark: Practical strategy of what hyperscalers actually do‚Ä¶
	‚Ä¢	Tier 1 (cutting-edge): newest GPUs for training + latency-critical or huge-context inference.
	‚Ä¢	Tier 2 (steady, high-volume inference): ASICs/custom parts where the perf/W delta ‚â•2√ó and the model/API is stable for 2‚Äì3 years.
	‚Ä¢	Tier 3 (long tail / batch / experiments): older GPUs until power or memory becomes the bottleneck; then retire or resell.

Obsolescence will depend a lot on perf/watt progression.

But I dont think anyone should be surprised if you find modern day cutting edge chips still work horsing away on Tail workloads in 7 years time.

Yes, all get similar charts now, yes the chart screams erosion, but context matters here. Stablecoins are still in their very first innings: we‚Äôve honestly barely scratched the surface of global trade, on-chain treasuries, and tokenised bonds equities etc. Ethereum may have lost the easy retail transfers, but it‚Äôs digging in in trenches where the real money will flow; regulated stablecoins, institutional DeFi, RWAs, settlement layers built on L2s with compliance baked in. Sure, Solana and Tron win on speed and fees, but when the next wave is JPMorgan, BlackRock, and sovereign digital bonds, they‚Äôll want Ethereum‚Äôs security, tooling, and institutional comfort. In other words: ETH has ceded some of the streets, but it‚Äôs still building the skyscrapers.

[22/09/2025, 10:57:56] Calum Curation: *Rainbow Rare Earths* is up 15% today (and +60% since our club call in July) after it reported further successful test work at its Phalaborwa project this morning. The team has now incorporated a cerium (Ce) depletion step, which improves the quality of the rare earth product while reducing costs and simplifying the separation process. This step has helped produce a high-purity mixed REE product, and the final separation circuit for NdPr and SEG+ (medium/heavy REEs including Dy and Tb) is on track to be finalised in Q4 2025.

*Why it matters*: Phalaborwa is already one of the highest-margin, lowest-cost, and most environmentally responsible REE projects. With scalable technology also being applied to Uberaba in Brazil, Rainbow is very well-positioned to supply critical rare earths for EVs, wind turbines, robotics, and defense applications.

Check the updated showcase here: https://app.curationconnect.com/company/Rainbow-Rare-Earths-90903?utm_source=collective

UK & NORTH SEA: I see a Miliband Fudge is being talked about: ‚ÄúTie-Backs‚Äù. This is essentially allowing new exploration to adjacent fields, without breaking election pledge of no new drilling. So is a fudge. But good for growth!‚Äù 
WHAT LAST WEEK SHOULD HAVE CONFIRMED: If Britain is serious about AI, it needs serious energy. Training one GPT-4‚Äìclass model eats >500 MWh (150 UK homes for a year). A hyperscale data centre draws as much power as a city of 200,000. Miliband‚Äôs Net Zero hair-shirt doesn‚Äôt square with that reality. North Sea output has halved since 2000, imports now cover >50% of UK gas, and new licensing barely registers (¬£1bn vs Norway‚Äôs $20bn+). AI only happens if the basin reopens. On Uranium, as ever Team OW are on it, but on ORKLO etc

NUCLEAR HAS ITS ‚ÄúMEME MOMENT‚Äù: 
Oklo, $20.7bn ! with no revenue, no NRC license, and a rejected 1.5 MWe design, now trades at a fatter valuation than BWXT, Curtiss-Wright, or AtkinsR√©alis companies that actually build and service reactors, sell isotopes, or engineer infrastructure worldwide. It‚Äôs arguably a ‚ÄúTheranos-with-fuel-rods‚Äù story: glossy renderings and Silicon Valley swagger being priced as if sodium fast reactors were already commercial, when even Rosatom struggles with them at scale. Meanwhile, the real value sits with the incumbents and the fuel chain: BWXT making sub cores, UEC pushing U.S. supply, URNM indexing the cycle, ASPI and LTBR riding the technology and enrichment angles. Oklo‚Äôs hype will collapse under the weight of licensing and physics, but the capital rotation it represents nuclear‚Äôs ‚Äúmeme moment‚Äù and arguably only drives more attention and eventual flows into the companies with actual kilowatts, customers, and cash flow. Silex has a mkt cap of $1.1bn and owns 51% of GLE which will make LEU. Cameco will likely exercise its option to buy another 25% of GLE from Silex. LTBR has a mkt cap of ‚Äúonly‚Äù $540m. 
Ocean Wall reminded me yesterday that ASPI‚Äôs mkt cap is $1bn for: 
1. HALEU producer - likely 3 sites in 3 countries - GLE has only one site in North Carolina - Paducah
2. Silicon 28 - 80kg of capacity and rising - for next gen semis.
3. ‚Å†Yttebium 176 for cancer drugs - massive shortage.
4. ‚Å†Carbon 12 and 14 for imaging and electronic warfare. 
5. ‚Å†Lithium 6 and 7 for various nuclear processes. 
6. ‚Å†Pet Labs - radio pharmacy using cyclotrons to 10x EBITDA.
7. ‚Å†Renergen: ASPI is buying the best helium asset in the world for cents in the $.
Oh; can we talk about Amarillo Texas yet?!!!

It‚Äôs sailing under the radar at just $120‚ÄØmillion USD market cap basically pocket change next to miners like Cameco ($32‚ÄØbillion), Kazatomprom ($14‚ÄØbillion), and Uranium Energy ($4.9‚ÄØbillion). That makes Aura a 20x+ upside candidate if it executes on Tiris and H√§gg√•n. projects backed by offtakes, institutional backing (47%), and imminent permitting wins. Yes it‚Äôs loss-making and early‚Äëstage, but that‚Äôs expected in a pre‚Äëproduction junior. In short: while big names move in slow, Aura is the nimble, cheap pick with leverage to a uranium price surge and the nuclear renaissance. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

Barack Obama at the O‚ÇÇ was frankly the perfect metaphor for his presidency: beautiful packaging, zero payload. Ninety minutes of civilised waffle, as smooth as a hotel lobby piano, and just as forgettable. Not a spark, not a namecheck for Trump, not even the suggestion that the world is now tearing itself apart on the fault lines of the very order he supposedly ‚Äúled.‚Äù
This is the man who promised change and delivered managerialism. Who spoke of hope while presiding over drone wars, hollowed-out institutions, and a global system so fragile that it cracked the moment he left office. Obama‚Äôs ‚Äúnew world order‚Äù was a PowerPoint fantasy that left America paralysed and its enemies emboldened. He mistook eloquence for strategy, optics for outcomes. The result? The revenge of the colonised, the rise of the oppressed , the return of hard men with harder armies.
The oppressed are not rising because they were inspired by Obama‚Äôs America. They are rising because they saw its emptiness the carefully balanced speeches, the risk-averse half-measures, the absence of will. The empire didn‚Äôt fall to force; it sighed itself into irrelevance.
And here he is, in London, reduced to after-dinner speaking for the devout, a travelling salesman for a memoir, still too cautious to even utter his nemesis‚Äôs name. Obama is not a fighter. He never was. He was the usher at history‚Äôs funeral, and he still doesn‚Äôt know it.

[26/09/2025, 08:33:50] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Exactly!
From todays Nutstuff on UEC..
And exactly the point we discussed at OW hosting ASPI. 

URANIUM/ UEC: was a $3.50 entry for Nutstuff vs $13.40 today, and have never waivered on my Uranium conviction for 3+ years! ( but was grim for al long time!) 
UEC is still not a ‚Äúmine today‚Äù story, it‚Äôs a leveraged call option on U.S. nuclear security policy + $100 uranium. The patient strategy (no sub-$80 contracts, slow ramp) looks prescient. With the U.S. government explicitly signalling it will treat uranium like rare earths, strategic, subsidised, stockpiled. UEC is the liquid vehicle. You buy it for the day Washington writes a floor price under the market and utilities scramble to secure domestic supply. The last 3 years have been a 4x rerate the next 3 could rhyme if uranium goes where it always does in a tight cycle: way higher than anyone thinks. At $6bn this has quietly become the best-positioned U.S. ISR producer: Texas, Wyoming, Saskatchewan all underpinned by a balance sheet with $271m cash/ATM and no debt. The strategy has been simple but shrewd: no long-term contracts, no need to buy pounds in the market, maximum leverage to spot. I see a path to $25+. On NAV sensitivity: $60/lb = $11/sh, $100/lb = $18.50/sh.
[26/09/2025, 08:35:50] Nick finegold: Intel is a lot rarer than uranium miners  . Ditto Samsung . These foundries simply must succeed . ‚Äé<This message was edited>
‚Äé[26/09/2025, 08:36:24] Nick finegold: ‚Äéimage omitted
[26/09/2025, 08:37:23] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: And to yours and my agreement on any portfolio core must own of GOOGL..

 GOOGL & BITCOIN MINERS: For years Bitcoin miners were the energy world‚Äôs orphans condemned to hunt stranded megawatts, finance on junk terms, and dump their own coins just to stay solvent. Their competitive edge was never the coins, but the infrastructure: knowing where to plant a 100MW shed, how to strip cooling costs to the bone, how to arbitrage grid volatility.  Now Google has validated that edge with hard cash. 	
‚Ä¢Cipher Mining: a 10-year, 168MW hosting deal worth ~$3B. Google is on the hook for $1.4B of obligations and walks away with warrants for ~5.4% equity. 	
‚Ä¢: circling ~$3B in financing for new compute campuses, again with Google‚Äôs backing.  
This is strategic, not opportunistic. Hyperscalers are realising that the path to scaling AI infrastructure is not just more GPUs, it‚Äôs energy arbitrage exactly the miner‚Äôs trade. The boundary between ‚Äúmining‚Äù and ‚ÄúAI data-centres‚Äù is disappearing.  For miners, it flips the model: Contracted revenues (AI hosting) alongside volatile block rewards. Access to capital via investment-grade counterparty guarantees, rather than death-spiral equity raises. Load balancing between cycles, Bitcoin halving seasons metered with AI training bursts. It also highlights the paradox: both AI and Bitcoin are born of the same parent, the high-density compute warehouse, yet they represent opposite economics. AI is infinite output, lowering the marginal cost of intelligence to zero. Bitcoin is absolute scarcity, a hard cap on digital money. Both feed on the same turbines and cooling rigs, but one floods while the other withholds. The endgame is obvious: miners and AI operators merge into energy-arbitrage landlords, owning the cheapest megawatts and renting them out in whatever form the market demands. GPU cycles or SHA-256 hashes. Google‚Äôs billions are the tell. Whoever controls the low-cost energy campuses won‚Äôt just be running miners or AI labs; they‚Äôll be running the backbone of digital abundance and digital scarcity simultaneously.

[26/09/2025, 20:10:42] ~‚ÄØPhilip Donald: And I had literally just downloaded  EA sports fifa26 an hour ago‚Ä¶
[27/09/2025, 09:39:07] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: ELECTRONIC ARTS $50bn LBO/ take private!
A glance at a longer term px chart and you can see EA has spent a long time treading water. In a world of trillion $ companies, If EA really goes at $50bn yes it‚Äôs the mother of all LBOs, but is hardly another top of the market sign IMHO. More a sign again of the magnitude of flows and money chasing returns. Yes,  the maths likely only works if you believe video games are the next toll road of digital media. Live-services, Ultimate Team, Sims packs: they throw off subscription-like cash flows that PE can lever to the hilt, then flip back to the market once the multiple resets. At 22√ó EV/EBITDA you‚Äôre paying Netflix-style multiples for NFL-franchise stickiness, and that makes sense when Roblox is still a $30bn meme platform on barely $750m of EBITDA, or Take-Two trades at $20bn on GTA hype alone. Microsoft had to cough up $69bn for Activision, Sony‚Äôs a $100bn media-hardware hybrid, Nintendo $70bn for Mario + Zelda IP. Against that backdrop, $50bn for FIFA, Madden, Apex and Sims is less mad than it initially looks, it‚Äôs maybe PE‚Äôs way of simply buying the next Hollywood+NFL bundle before Wall Street remembers it‚Äôs growth, not value.
To be clear, this is NOT for me. In a DeFi/DePIN gaming world, EA and TTWO only win if they pivot from rent-takers to protocol owners. Their IP is gold: FIFA, Madden, GTA, but blockchain rails strip out the toll booths and hand the power to players. Either they tokenise and control the new pipes, or they end up like Blockbuster watching the streaming era roll past. Fascinated to watch how this unfolds.

[01/10/2025, 13:17:02] ~‚ÄØWilliam Johnston: As a portfolio manage for over 3 decades I find these conclusions fascinating.  Also how badly investors are served by the asset management industry.  I consider the 60:40 portfolio is dead. 40% invested in bonds is wealth destruction. You have to be very careful with your equity selection since the odds you picking a great stock are not great.  My conclusion is concentrate on investments with transformative, scalable, and network effect technologies that create asymmetric growth opportunities. 

Here‚Äôs a five-bullet-point summary of the key findings from Hendrik Bessembinder‚Äôs "Shareholder Wealth Enhancement, 1926 to 2022":

- **Extreme Skewness in Returns**: The top 4% of U.S. stocks (approximately 1,000 firms) accounted for the entire net wealth creation in the stock market from 1926 to 2022, while the remaining 96% collectively matched or underperformed one-month Treasury bills.
- **Wealth Concentration**: Just 0.25% of stocks (about 64 firms) generated over half of the total market‚Äôs wealth, highlighting the dominance of a few "superstocks" like major tech firms.
- **Underperformance of Most Stocks**: Approximately 58% of individual stocks failed to outperform one-month Treasury bills over their lifetimes, indicating that most stocks do not contribute to positive equity index performance.
- **Consistency Over Time**: The findings hold across subperiods, with the top-performing stocks consistently driving market returns, regardless of economic conditions or market cycles.
- **Global Applicability**: The updated analysis confirms similar patterns in global markets, where the top 2.4% of firms drove all net wealth creation over three decades, emphasizing the universal nature of this skewness.


https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=4448099 ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[01/10/2025, 14:06:14] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: PELOTON. Get on yer bike!
News out is absolutely on track with Nutstuff buy thesis of 2+ mths ago: 
I love a dead-mans cardiogram! 
This: https://x.com/ftr_investors/status/1973357887281037767?s=46
At $7, Peloton was trading like a busted fad, priced for bankruptcy with negative sentiment maxed out. But underneath, the pieces of a turnaround were to me visible: a sticky subscription base that still pays every month, a cult brand with global resonance, and hardware that can be reinvented rather than scrapped. The bear case was fully in the price. The bull case was asymmetric: if management delivered even modest wins it is palpable with price hikes, refreshed hardware, commercial partnerships, or AI-driven training , the equity had / has leverage. That‚Äôs exactly what‚Äôs happening now. Short interest near 20% just adds fuel. At $7, Peloton was less a broken bike company and more a deeply out-of-the-money call option on a health and wellness platform, simple and cheap optionality in a market that usually overpays for growth.( see NIKE!)

[02/10/2025, 17:54:51] ~‚ÄØMark Astley: I agree with William's logic;, the market extremes in gold and silver (and Nasdaq) are such that a significant sell-off/retracement is more likely than a mild pullback.
I am familiar with DeMark and also observe the signals from Parallax Financial Research which examines the Hurst exponent of a time series to judge how non-random the trend is in historical context.  The further it moves away from a random walk and commences a trend there comes a point where the probability of further gains become minimal as it is so "extended".  This measure, describes the degree of extension. (Apologies for the nerdy explanation). As of yesterday, both gold and silver have achieved equivalent levels to the 1999 Nasdaq top.  
It is noteworthy also that, typical of a top, intraday volatility is growing (eg silver today) and of course, many brokers are competing with each other to raise their price targets.
Beware...

[03/10/2025, 14:54:32] ~‚ÄØDavid Haysey: Hi Andrew,
To take your points in reverse order.
GLPs etc. The Bytetree piece covered some of this in more detail but obvs must b some effect recently within the v long term DM trend of falling alcohol consumption on a volume basis. Interestingly was some work from Jefferys recently suggesting wine falling worse than spirits/beer. Might be GLP specific as wine commonly drunk with food?
Also youth seem to favour beer and spirits. Is clear DGE doing well within its particular categories, but equally the 5-7% (abandoned) sales growth target unrealistic.
Debt is complex. Co accounts in $ but borrows in array of currencies. Overwhelmingly fixed rate. At year end (June) $24bn debt o/w $2.9 due within one year. Thereafter repayment cadence pretty even with no big cliff maturities. Effective interest rate 4.1% so your number looks fair. 
On divi paid $2.3bn last FY. Accounting net was $2.5bn.FCF $2.7bn. Unsurprisingly they stopped the buyback program which was $1bn and $1.6bn in the two prior years. 
I think in general there‚Äôs been a tendency in the staples sector to grow divis at rates that aren‚Äôt perhaps justified by top line growth as currently observed. 
Not sure about CEO search but think Nik the acting one gave pretty good account of self on last earnings call. 
If can bring capex back to historic levels and sell some non-core stuff at good prices think could rerate quite quickly.

This is positioned as a stronger hedge against inflation in the current environment, where U.S. equities offer limited upside relative to Treasuries and bond yields are elevated.
Wilson explains: ‚ÄúGold is now the anti-fragile asset to own, rather than Treasuries. High-quality equities and gold are the best hedges.‚Äù He emphasizes gold‚Äôs role as a safe-haven asset that performs well when real rates fall during downturns, complementing equities‚Äô growth-linked inflation protection

[06/10/2025, 11:54:56] Calum Curation: If people are interested in a fascinating special-sit in the bitcoin space then worth looking at Semler Scientific. Semler is a Bitcoin treasury company with a small healthcare business on the side. Two weeks ago when its share price was $29 it was acquired by Strive for a ‚Äú200%+ premium at c$90/share‚Äù. Today you can buy Semler shares for $30.50. Why haven‚Äôt the shares gone up? Well the deal was all paper. Strive offered 21.05 Strive shares per Semler share when strive was trading on $4.3. It seems like a massive premium but Strive bitcoin per share actually rises as it effectively bought Semler at a discount to its bitcoin MNAV using Strive shares valued at its own MNAV.

Fast forward to today and Strive is trading at $2.65. If the merger goes ahead then Semler shareholders will get 21.05x2.66 which equals $56. Nearly 100% upside from the current share price of $30‚Ä¶ both companies want to push this through quickly so hopefully it‚Äôs all done by January. Doing some research it seems likely to go through and if it doesn‚Äôt then Strive owes Semler $50m which is a lot for a $300m mkt cap company‚Ä¶.the risk arb on this is crazy. 

If you look to value the merged company‚Ä¶they will hold 10,800 Bitcoin. At the current price this is nearly $1.5/share. Strive also owns a rapidly growing asset mgmt business with $2bn of AuM. They also own a social media division and Semler‚Äôs healthcare business (which they will look to offload or monetise). Given its scale (Michael Saylor said last week he thinks strive is one of the best Bitcoin treasury company which could 100x) then some sort of premium is justified. Even with no premium though as a worst case scenario then it‚Äôs worth $1.8. This is $38 per Semler shares which is nearly 30% upside. 

But strive is currently on $2.6. If bitcoin keeps rising as MSTR keeps its breakout momentum I think there‚Äôs every chance Strive shares are $3-3.5+ when the merger closes in 3 months which is $63-73 per Semler shares vs $30 today. Given Strive was trading on $12 a few weeks ago the blue sky for holding Semler today is clearly materially higher (5-10x bagger). I might be missing something but the risk / reward seems incredible. 
Full disclose I hold a fair few Semler shares.

[06/10/2025, 18:08:05] ~‚ÄØNH: each of your questions could fill out en entire book but at a high level these are my thoughts: 

1. Recent sellers: There have been quite a few long time dormant accounts (BTC wallets that have been inactive for +10-12 yrs) that have woken up in the last few weeks and started selling. Probably monetising positions that are up several 1000%. 
2. Theoretically you could do a 51% attack which means you‚Äôd control over 50% of BTCs hashing power and control the system that checks and secures the entire blockchain. If you were able to do that, you could double spend, alter transaction history, block other miners from adding blocks etc. There have been multiple attempts to estimate the cost of doing such an attack and given the computational intensity of such an undertaking, it is estimated that such an attack would cost multiple billions. However, the flip slide of this, if someone ever managed to do it, they would have control over a digital asset who‚Äôs value would instantly collapse to zero as thats one of BTC‚Äôs major USPs - so not really a good ROIC‚Ä¶ Putin‚Äôs time probably best spent doing other stuff TBH‚Ä¶

The chance of you guessing that number or Putin is kind of impossible. On the flow of funds please see my post at the weekend on money flow. Essentially there have been large whales selling. Personally, I enjoy  a bit of digital assets in this chat because it‚Äôs a vastly important asset class. 

However , I don‚Äôt want it to become overwhelmed with chat in any particular subject , because the strength of this group is its diversity of subject matter .

It‚Äôs also important not to police this chat group too heavily . Its raw nature and the brilliance of the contributors is its life blood .

All I would say is our industry has spent decades making something that‚Äôs very simple very complicated. They do this through the invention of a language that makes it hard to follow what they are saying so they can charge fees .


More buyers than Sellers it goes up , and visa versa .

Let‚Äôs use the brilliance of this  group to make sure we make complex issues simple not simple issues complex .

[07/10/2025, 07:31:44] Nick finegold: From Adam :

Tesla‚Äôs Oct 7 Reveal ‚Äî Wheels, Wings, or Wires?

What happened:
Tesla dropped two short teasers this week ‚Äî one showing a rapidly spinning electrical component, the other a set of illuminated headlights. That‚Äôs all Elon needed to set the internet ablaze.

Three theories dominate the chatter:
	‚Ä¢	Aviation or Drones: The ‚Äúrotor‚Äù clip looked more aerospace than automotive. Elon has long flirted with the idea of ‚ÄúTesla Aviation,‚Äù and Morgan Stanley has described the company as a defence contractor disguised as a consumer brand something we brought to everyone‚Äôs attention a few mints back . 
	‚Ä¢	Affordable EV: With subsidies fading and margins tightening, Tesla needs a lower-priced model to sustain growth ‚Äî perhaps the final human-driven Tesla before the company goes fully autonomous?
	‚Ä¢	Roadster Resurrection: A halo supercar could re-energise the brand while showing off new propulsion and aerodynamic tech.

‚∏ª

ü§ñ The Deeper Story ‚Äî Tesla‚Äôs AI & Robotics Pivot

Morgan Stanley‚Äôs latest note frames Tesla as less a carmaker, more a hardware shell for embodied AI.
The firm highlights 10 questions investors should ask of any robotics company ‚Äî and Tesla quietly ticks most of them: world-class AI talent, mass-manufacturing experience, deep vertical integration, real-world data capture and a simulation stack built for humanoids.

Elon‚Äôs long-derided ‚Äúvision-only‚Äù approach (no LIDAR, no radar) is starting to look prescient as GenAI blurs the line between cars, robots, and adaptive learning systems.

‚∏ª

Why It Matters ?

Tesla‚Äôs reveal won‚Äôt just be about a new product ‚Äî it‚Äôs about strategic direction.
Every clue suggests Musk wants to reposition Tesla as the world‚Äôs first AI-industrial platform ‚Äî spanning cars, robots, drones and energy.

Whether it‚Äôs a fan blade or a steering wheel, the company‚Äôs endgame is clear: embodied intelligence at scale.

‚∏ª
Fat Gladiator‚Äôs Take

The most valuable real estate in the AI race isn‚Äôt in the cloud ‚Äî it‚Äôs in the physical world.
Tesla already owns the best training data for movement, interaction and perception.
Whatever launches today ‚Äî a new EV, a drone, or just more smoke and mirrors ‚Äî will be another breadcrumb on Tesla‚Äôs path from mobility company to AI-powered infrastructure giant.

And if it is ‚ÄúTesla Aviation‚Äù?
Well‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs when the Musk mythology goes from moonshot to full-blown Top Gun.

[08/10/2025, 06:49:35] ~‚ÄØAndrew Cawker: Listened to an Oddlots podcast yesterday that talked about closed loop cooling systems dramatically improving water consumption in Data centres. 

Worth being aware of going forward. This from perplexity:- 

Closed loop cooling systems are dramatically reducing water demand in AI data centres by recirculating a fixed volume of coolant, rather than relying on constant external water supply and evaporation as seen in older systems. Once filled, these systems use engineered fluids or water repeatedly within a sealed network, which nearly eliminates ongoing water consumption even when cooling high-performance AI workloads. For example, Microsoft‚Äôs latest chip-level closed-loop liquid cooling system‚Äîdeployed globally since August 2024‚Äîhas reduced annual water use by more than 125 million litres per facility, achieving an 80% improvement in Water Usage Effectiveness (WUE) versus legacy designs

[08/10/2025, 12:37:10] ~‚ÄØAndrew Draycott: Diageo PLC (LSE:DGE) could unlock between $5 billion and $8 billion from asset sales as part of plans to streamline its
portfolio and accelerate deleveraging, according to UBS. The Swiss bank, which maintained a 'buy' rating and 2,450p price target on the shares, believes proceeds from potential
disposals could strengthen the Smirnoff and Guinness maker's balance sheet and fund new share buybacks. Analysts identified five possible divestment targets: East African beer operations, the Chinese Baijiu business, the RCB
Indian cricket franchise, local Turkish spirits brands, and US value labels such as Captain Morgan and Seagram's 7.
Together, these represent about 11% of group sales and 12% of EBIT. UBS estimates that mid-range disposal proceeds of $6.4 billion could reduce Diageo's net debt-to-EBITDA ratio to 2.2x
by the 2027 and 1.9x by 2028 financial year, below the group's 2.5-3x target. The move would be likely to dilute earnings by about 5%, but the analysts reckon this could be partially offset by up to
$4.5 billion of share buybacks by FY28.
UBS said the resulting improvement in leverage and capital efficiency "should help drive a re-rating" in Diageo's shares.

[09/10/2025, 09:02:44] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Ben. Have done a Nutstuff dive on eare earths as long time holder still of MP US.
Will dial into call and then happy to share.

A few bits‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶.the West has finally woken up to the strategic insanity of depending on China for 90% of the inputs that power AI, EVs, missiles, drones, and even MRI machines. What‚Äôs driving this is industrial policy meets resource nationalism: Washington‚Äôs $3bn+ DoD funding for critical minerals, IRA tax credits, and private capital rotations out of tech hype into the things that make tech possible. The irony? The winners are still tiny‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶The next decade‚Äôs AI powerhouses won‚Äôt be digital first, they‚Äôll be physical and dirty: rare earths are like the new silicon.‚Ä¶.
‚Ä¶Put Ocean Walls USA Rare Earths (private) into my peer Nutstuff peer group chart mentally and you see the missing piece. It‚Äôs not yet listed, but it‚Äôs the pre-IPO analogue to MP Materials circa 2019: a vertically-integrated bet on sovereign magnet independence. Round Top in Texas gives them light + heavy rare earths (Nd, Pr, Dy, Tb) plus lithium and scandium. Stillwater, Oklahoma is the magnet factory, already producing pilot batches of sintered NdFeB magnets, the exact component every EV motor, wind turbine, and missile guidance system needs. If it executes, USA Rare Earths becomes the first American producer of both heavy and light REE magnets entirely onshore with no Chinese chemistry, no Asian feedstock & no dependency loop.  
‚Ä¶.

[09/10/2025, 12:52:18] ~‚ÄØLuke Dyas: The cautionary parallel on valuation exuberance is fair, but I don‚Äôt think Sun Micro in 2000 is a good comparison with Shopify or the high-multiple B2C AI commerce plays today. Back then, Sun‚Äôs valuation was pricing in an internet economy that still needed fibre rollout, data centres, broadband and enterprise digital transformation, all of which took another 10 to 15 years. Shopify (and AI in general) is monetising mature infrastructure today, with very sticky recurring revenues through strong API lock-in that creates Salesforce-style switching friction, and incremental margins of around 70%, much higher than Sun ever achieved. If Shopify keeps growing at 20‚Äì30%, it can grow into its earnings multiples quickly, and the stickiness of its recurring revenues is giving investors confidence that it will and hence the willingness to look further out.

There are a number of other non core assets that could also be on the block, the water division being an example. It‚Äôs not sexy but it‚Äôs cheap, has good turnaround potential and gives you a 5% yield in CHF while you wait.

[11/10/2025, 10:19:55] Nick finegold: Trumps post is worth a read read . 

Donald J. Trump
@realDonaldTrump
Some very strange things are happening in China! They are becoming very hostile, and sending letters to Countries throughout the World, that they want to impose Export Controls on each and every element of production having to do with Rare Earths, and virtually anything else they can think of, even if it‚Äôs not manufactured in China. Nobody has ever seen anything like this but, essentially, it would ‚Äúclog‚Äù the Markets, and make life difficult for virtually every Country in the World, especially for China. We have been contacted by other Countries who are extremely angry at this great Trade hostility, which came out of nowhere. Our relationship with China over the past six months has been a very good one, thereby making this move on Trade an even more surprising one. I have always felt that they‚Äôve been lying in wait, and now, as usual, I have been proven right! There is no way that China should be allowed to hold the World ‚Äúcaptive,‚Äù but that seems to have been their plan for quite some time, starting with the ‚ÄúMagnets‚Äù and, other Elements that they have quietly amassed into somewhat of a Monopoly position, a rather sinister and hostile move, to say the least. But the U.S. has Monopoly positions also, much stronger and more far reaching than China‚Äôs. I have just not chosen to use them, there was never a reason for me to do so ‚Äî UNTIL NOW! The letter they sent is many pages long, and details, with great specificity, each and every Element that they want to withhold from other Nations. Things that were routine are no longer routine at all. I have not spoken to President Xi because there was no reason to do so. This was a real surprise, not only to me, but to all the Leaders of the Free World. I was to meet President Xi in two weeks, at APEC, in South Korea, but now there seems to be no reason to do so. The Chinese letters were especially inappropriate in that this was the Day that, after three thousand years of bedlam and fighting, there is PEACE IN THE MIDDLE EAST. I wonder if that timing was coincidental? Dependent on what China says about the hostile ‚Äúorder‚Äù that they have just put out, I will be forced, as President of the United States of America, to financially counter their move. For every Element that they have been able to monopolize, we have two. I never thought it would come to this but perhaps, as with all things, the time has come. Ultimately, though potentially painful, it will be a very good thing, in the end, for the U.S.A. One of the Policies that we are calculating at this moment is a massive increase of Tariffs on Chinese products coming into the United States of America. There are many other countermeasures that are, likewise, under serious consideration. Thank you for your attention to this matter!

 

DONALD J. TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

[12/10/2025, 07:27:41] Nick finegold: The  Chinese trade war and the investigation into Qualcomm may give us no better example of how things play out . 

Xiaomi uses Qualcomm chips in all its mobile phones . So these Chinese measures hurt some Chinese companies every bit as badly as they hurt American ones. 

Xiaomi also exports a vast amount of its product suite outside China .

It‚Äôs definitely a negotiating tactic in the trade war although it‚Äôs impossible to ignore that long term the relationship will not sit easy with investors as both countries seek to lessen dependence on each other. 

We moved Qualcomm from the top 10 to the 30 for this reason. 

Companies simply cannot react at the same pace as the changing narratives between these two Governments which is why the most probable outcome is a short settlement  but a long term deteriorating in trade. 

In this mornings newsletter I talk about us owning mistakes, Qualcomm is super cheap but for a reason and maybe one of them . We shall see .

[13/10/2025, 09:34:08] Adam Clib: Deutsche Numis banging the drum on Molten.
 
*Molten Ventures (Buy, TP 671p) ‚Äì15 page note out. Ahead of trading update on Oct 23, we thought it would be useful to revisit the investment case. Whilst Molten Ventures' shares have risen c.20% in the last 3 months, it continues to trade at c.40% discount to the last published NAV per share of 671p/share (31/03/2025 NAV). Put another way, at the current share price, investors are getting the core portfolio (17 companies accounting for c.60% of the total gross portfolio value) for a c.5-10% discount to NAV and the rest of the emerging portfolio (c.90 companies, 40% of gross portfolio value) for free. We believe there is upside to this NAV given recent news on some of the core portfolio assets and that the discount should narrow still as the group: 1) continues to realise investments at or above carrying values, building confidence in its NAV, and 2) balances the pipeline of investment opportunities with the ability to drive returns to shareholders through its ongoing share buyback programme, while maintaining sufficient reserves. In this note, we take a closer look at some of its holdings including Revolut, ICEYE, Ledger, Thought Machine, Riverlane and BeZero.  Molten Ventures PLC: 40% discount to NAV attractive as core assets progress

[15/10/2025, 01:41:04] Nick finegold: Everyone‚Äôs staring at the spot price pretending silver‚Äôs $50 an ounce.

But step into the real world. China‚Äôs top bullion marketplace is now posting $128/oz for physical silver.

That‚Äôs not a typo. That‚Äôs four times the 2020 price and double today‚Äôs ‚Äúofficial‚Äù rate.

The global silver shortage isn‚Äôt coming. It‚Äôs already here.

Perth Mint has halted all silver product sales.
India‚Äôs dealers have vanished or defaulted on shipments.
Amazon sellers are taking money and not delivering metal.
Even the Royal Canadian Mint and TD Bank show ‚Äúout of stock‚Äù on nearly every bar.

This isn‚Äôt a paper disconnect. It‚Äôs a total breakdown in physical supply.

In Japan, Asahi Fine, a world-class refiner, is out of ingots.
In London, lease rates have exploded to 39 percent, panic levels not seen in decades.
Banks can‚Äôt locate metal and are being forced to cover or buy back futures just to stay solvent.

It‚Äôs chaos.

And through all of this, China quietly sets the new world price.
Their retail bars are fetching between $108 and $128 an ounce, and that‚Äôs for the small bars retail investors can actually hold.

Sellers always move to where they‚Äôre treated best.
If a refiner or trader can earn twice as much shipping to China, why would they sell into New York or London at half the rate?

The result: China‚Äôs premiums become the new global standard.

Silver goes where it‚Äôs valued highest, and right now the East is valuing it like gold.

Meanwhile, the West is still obsessed with ‚Äúspot‚Äù prices that no longer mean anything. Futures, ETFs, and ‚Äúpaper silver‚Äù are detached from reality. IOUs trading in a system that can‚Äôt deliver.

For those holding physical, this is the moment the market has been building toward for years, when scarcity becomes undeniable and the paper fa√ßade cracks.

What happens next?
Expect those $128 Chinese premiums to ripple outward fast.
Dealers in the US and Canada will raise quotes just to restock.
Industrial users will panic-buy to secure supply.
And small investors who mocked silver stackers will suddenly realize the shelves are empty.

This is what a global repricing looks like.

The shortage is systemic, and silver is finally being priced like the strategic, irreplaceable metal it truly is.

The age of cheap silver is over.

[15/10/2025, 08:10:52] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: All so relevant to the bigger issue ..



NEEDS VS WANTS. 
If you simply flipped Maslow‚Äôs hierarchy into a market chart, you‚Äôd see the absurdity instantly. The entire edifice of global market cap is crammed into the tiny, glittering top tech, AI, luxury where valuations levitate on narratives about transcendence and machine consciousness. But as Jim M and me have joked for many years, so much of it is just ‚Äútime wasting‚Äù. 
Meanwhile, the bottom, where civilisation actually resides as does stuff that really matters: food ( yes soya beans!) energy, uranium, rare earths, defence & security; all remain neglected and thinly owned with minimal benchmark/ index relevance. The irony is brutal: investors have poured trillions into ‚Äúself-actualisation‚Äù stocks that depend entirely on the physical security layers they‚Äôve ignored. No uranium, no AI. No diesel, no delivery. No rare earths, no robots. The next decade won‚Äôt reward whoever codes the cloud it‚Äôll reward whoever owns the power plant that keeps it alive. In short, markets have built their pyramid upside-down, and smart small money has been been quietly buying the foundations not the towers.
