‚Äé[15/10/2025, 13:41:55] ~‚ÄØWilliam Johnston: ‚Äéimage omitted
[15/10/2025, 13:41:59] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: The Janus Program, launched by the US Army yesterday, focuses on deploying safe, mobile, and resilient microreactors (under 20 MW) to power military installations and operations globally by 2028, building on Project Pele and leveraging advanced nuclear technologies for energy security. This initiative creates opportunities for companies in the nuclear sector, particularly those involved in microreactor development, fuel enrichment, and component supply, as it accelerates commercialisation, addresses fuel needs like high-assay low-enriched uranium (HALEU), and uses milestone-based contracting similar to NASA's models.

Names to know...

ASP Isotopes: Specialising in laser-based isotope enrichment, ASP Isotopes is advancing HALEU production facilities in South Africa and partnering with US entities like Fermi America to host domestic enrichment sites. Though not yet Defencse Innovation Unit ("DIU") qualified - a requirement to be approved for use by DOD - its technology addresses Janus's fuel constraints by enabling scalable, efficient HALEU supply, supporting the program's goal of reducing reliance on foreign sources and enhancing national security through advanced reactor fuels. Wholly owned subsidiary Quantum Leap Energy ("QLE") which is solely focused on nuclear fuels should like in Q4 2026 as publicly disclosed.

BWXT (BWX Technologies): BWXT is the main supplier of nuclear related services to the US Government and plays a key role in nuclear components and fuel fabrication, including TRISO fuel for advanced reactors and core manufacturing for Project Pele, which Janus complements as a fixed-site counterpart. Its advanced technologies division is DIU-qualified for microreactor efforts, positioning it for contracts in enrichment equipment, centrifuge manufacturing, and system integration under Janus, with potential revenue from defense-backed offtake.

Centrus Energy (LEU): As the only US producer of HALEU at commercial scale (with 900 kg demonstrated at Piketon), Centrus is crucial for fueling Janus microreactors, especially given the executive order's directive for a DOE HALEU fuel bank of at least 20 metric tons. The program's emphasis on domestic fuel supply to de-risk early deployments benefits Centrus, which is expanding capacity and securing investments, leading to pre-market stock surges tied to Janus announcements.

Energy Fuels (UUUU): As the largest U.S. uranium producer, Energy Fuels plays a pivotal role in the domestic nuclear fuel supply chain by mining and processing uranium ore into concentrate (U3O8), with record production rates reaching about 96,000 pounds per month in 2025 and plans to ramp up further to meet growing demand. This directly supports the Janus Program's fuel requirements, which emphasise a secure, full uranium fuel cycle for microreactors needing HALEU. Recent $700 million funding for expanded production hubs further positions it to supply uranium for military applications, enhancing energy security and de-risking Janus deployments.

Oklo: As a developer of fast fission microreactors (e.g., Aurora model, 1.5-15 MW), Oklo is directly relevant, having been pre-qualified by the DIU for advanced nuclear power initiatives that Janus expands upon. The program validates Oklo's factory-built, refuel-rarely designs for remote or resilient power, with market reactions showing stock surges and analysts viewing it as a tailwind for deployment timelines. Oklo's ongoing Air Force base project at Eielson AFB further aligns with Janus's goals for military siting. We think this is fully valued but a name to watch.

[17/10/2025, 07:15:52] Nick finegold: To this day I have rarely heard the expression of what I believe to be the real gold story. 

Yes of course institutional investors are underweight , rates may drop and geopolitical risk is elevated . But the single most bearish point historically on gold is that outside of Jewelry it‚Äôs useless , expensive to store and insure. 

That all changes when you digitise it and back it with real gold on the block chain because you can start to borrow against it. Collateralise gold and  its use cases explode. 

Would you rather own a stable coin backed by an infinite supply of $‚Äôs or a stable coin backed by gold that remains in scarse supply ? 

The gold narrative historically has always been about wealth protection thus shutting the door on tens of millions of retail investors who have little wealth to protect , however , if gold gets sexy , not dull,  as I believe is happening, the doors opens to millions who might buy it to accumulate wealth not protect it and the leopard truly changes  the colour of its spots .

The team attended a WGC film premiere with Elton John in this week on gold !!!  They must have spent a fortune on it .

The WGC are taking gold to the parts on the market it historically never reached , backed by a $200m annual budget to promote it. 

Hardly anyone still understands this yet in my opinion , because they don‚Äôt understand the long term mission of the WGC 24/7 project . ‚Äé<This message was edited>
[17/10/2025, 07:22:29] Nick finegold: Read their copy - it‚Äôs compliant inside information !

Wholesale Digital Gold

‚ÄúThe potential of representing physical gold in a digitalised format will unlock new opportunities for the market, including increased liquidity and enabling the use of gold as collateral. In order to achieve this, the gold market needs structural reform to allow digital products to operate independently of specific custodians, while still offering ownership of underlying physical gold.

The Wholesale Digital Gold concept could enhance how gold is owned, traded, and utilised by bridging the gap between the two ways gold is currently settled in the wholesale market ‚Äì allocated and unallocated gold.‚Äù

[20/10/2025, 17:50:04] ~‚ÄØWilliam Nutting: Ok. Mystery over..
ALCOA/ AA US..
Have been watching this and suddenly it is stumbling back into relevance, a $9 billion aluminium producer that‚Äôs quietly sitting on the three most valuable assets of the AI century: Power, Permits and Processing. For years, it‚Äôs been the dullest of tickers, melting ore while the world chased software. But as compute becomes the new oil, Alcoa looks less like a metals relic and more like a stranded energy arbitrage. Making aluminium is essentially turning electricity into metal, and Alcoa has locked-in megawatts across 24 sites worldwide, that is power contracts, grid access, and the one thing no data-centre or rare-earth refinery can get quickly: permission to exist!  
It‚Äôs hosting its first analyst day in 4 years on 30 October, a timing too deliberate to be coincidence. I would expect little from earnings but everything from the subtext: how to monetise vast, permitted, powered footprints. One site in East Virginia is already leased to a Bitcoin miner, its renewal looming; another in Texas sits on the kind of capacity hyperscalers would sell their souls for. 
The CFO‚Äôs remarks at Morgan Stanley hinted at a capital-allocation rethink that to me is code for a coming ‚Äúre-rating‚Äù the old business as a new asset class. I am not suggesting Alcoa becomes an AI darling, it doesn‚Äôt need to. It just needs investors to realise it owns the infrastructure everyone else is begging for; electrons, land, and regulatory forgiveness. Hits my Key Nutstuff thematic; in a world short of watts and patience, AA is the unintentional DePIN of the industrial age ‚Äî power made tangible, scarcity wrapped in metal.

[21/10/2025, 18:17:16] ~‚ÄØDominic Vail: Thought this was interesting from Doomberg for those interested in European autos‚Ä¶.The possession of anything begins in the mind.‚Äù ‚Äì Bruce Lee

A day after the US Department of Commerce dramatically expanded export controls on Chinese companies by roping in their subsidiaries, a remarkable escalation in the trade war transpired. At the urging of the US government‚Äîand specifically because of the new export controls‚ÄîDutch authorities executed a shocking takeover of a vitally important subsidiary of a Chinese-owned company:

‚ÄúAt the height of the cold war, the Netherlands passed a law allowing the state to take over companies for security purposes. After gathering dust for 73 years, the law has at last been put to use. On September 30th the Ministry of Economic Affairs quietly took control of Nexperia, a semiconductor firm headquartered in Nijmegen that had been bought in 2019 by Zhang Xuezheng, a Chinese entrepreneur. A week later an Amsterdam business court suspended Mr Zhang (known by his nickname ‚ÄòWing‚Äô) as CEO, replacing him with a Dutch interim chief. The moves were made public by the Dutch press on October 12th. They are among the most aggressive steps yet by European governments to protect strategic industries from China.‚Äù

We suspect few of you had heard of Nexperia until last week, but the company plays a critical role in many supply chains, most notably automotive and consumer electronics. For all the attention high-end computer chip designers like Nvidia receive, the base of the semiconductor pyramid‚Äîcharacterized by older designs, huge volumes, and low prices‚Äîpermeates the modern economy. The post-Covid chip shortage of 2021 highlighted how important these commodities are, and scenes of vast parking lots stuffed with new cars unsellable without them serve as a stark reminder of the disruption their absence unleashes.


Dollars held up by pennies | The Detroit News
Nexperia is a major player in that end of the semiconductor industry. The company ships more than 110 billion discrete semiconductor devices annually, or roughly 10% of global market share. It is particularly essential to the automotive industry, where it supplies approximately 35‚Äì40% of diodes and discrete transistors, among other products‚Äîparts that cost as little as a few cents each but are indispensable for nearly every electronic function in a vehicle.

Amazingly, the brazen move by Dutch and US officials does not appear to have been fully thought through, as the obvious and economically devastating countermeasures China would almost certainly take seem to have been wildly underestimated. So shocking is the one-dimensional chess Western leaders are playing that it raises serious doubts about their appraisal of China‚Äôs economic, geopolitical, and military might. Let‚Äôs explore why.


There is one small problem with seizing control of Nexperia: it has a major factory in China, without which much of the company essentially cannot function. Although Nexperia produces wafers in its German and British facilities, the majority of that output is shipped for back-end manufacturing to Dongguan, China‚Äîincluding assembly, packaging, and electrical testing. The sprawling 860,000-square-foot plant is essential infrastructure for Nexperia‚Äôs entire supply network.

In a move that can hardly be considered surprising, China retaliated swiftly:

‚ÄúChina is blocking Nexperia from exporting products from the Asian nation after the Dutch government moved to seize control of the chipmaker.

China retaliated after the Dutch government invoked a Cold War‚Äìera law to take control of Nexperia, to ensure Europe retains access to its products. The company is a subsidiary of China‚Äôs Wingtech Technology and a key supplier of mature chips used by the automotive and consumer electronics industries.

The Chinese Ministry of Commerce issued an export control notice earlier this month, prohibiting Nexperia China and its subcontractors from exporting some components, the company said in a statement on Tuesday. Nexperia said it is trying to obtain an exemption.‚Äù


Whoops | Nexperia
Unless the standoff ends soon, the auto industry outside China will be thrown into a major crisis:

‚ÄúThe scale of the crisis cannot be overstated. Nexperia produces‚Ä¶ a sprawling portfolio of discrete semiconductors, diodes, transistors and MOSFETs (Metal Oxide Semiconductor Field-Effect Transistors, a type of semiconductor device used for switching and amplifying electronic signals) that perform unglamorous but absolutely vital functions in vehicles‚Ä¶

On 10 October, automakers and their tier 1 suppliers received notice from Nexperia that it could no longer guarantee delivery of its chips to the automotive supply chain. The implications for automotive production are baked-in. Following the communication, the European Automobile Manufacturers‚Äô Association (ACEA) reported that existing stocks would last only several weeks.‚Äù

According to a report by the South China Morning Post on Sunday, the Chinese have escalated the situation, taking first steps to fully seize the Dongguan facility:

‚ÄúNexperia China, the local unit of the Dutch chipmaker, has told its employees to follow orders from local management and ignore instructions from the Dutch head office, according to a letter issued to employees over the weekend.

In open revolt against the headquarters in Nijmegen, the Netherlands, Nexperia China said in a Chinese-language statement on its official social media channel on Saturday that it was an ‚Äòindependent‚Äô Chinese entity and that Nexperia employees in China ‚Äòshould continue to follow instructions from Nexperia China.‚Äô‚Äù


Nexperia‚Äôs Dutch headquarters | ANP
China‚Äôs domestic automotive industry will ride out the upcoming storm just fine, of course, with ready access to local supplies. As this excellent article by Michael Dunne on Substack points out, the country has the capacity to build more than 50 million cars per year but only produces about 60% of that number, and Dunne speculates that China‚Äôs recent actions might even be part of a broader plan to further dominate the industry.

The damage China is capable of spans far beyond the automotive sector. A scan of market-cap rankings in the S&P 500 reveals dozens of similar vulnerabilities: Apple, Qualcomm, Starbucks, Coca-Cola, Honeywell, Caterpillar, Walt Disney‚Äîthe tally of firms with high concentration risk in China is a long one. For all of US Treasury Secretary Scott Bissent‚Äôs media bluster, the US cannot decouple from China in the short- or even medium-term without collapsing its own economy and stock market.

As the Nexperia affair so vividly exposes, there‚Äôs a sequencing issue, and a fairly significant one at that.

However this will depend on super majority consensus. Achieving consensus can be very messy as we saw in 2017. But consensus was reached in the Fork Wars.  Worst case is consensus is not reached and Quantum computers hack the dormant addresses (3-4m).  The Segwit addresses on the Bitcoin protocol are already quantum resistant due to the way the addresses are hashed. Ethereum addresses are more vulnerable. [22/10/2025, 18:46:10] ~‚ÄØAndy Raikes: This caught my eye too as been discussing this topic recently. Rio is under pressure to resolve the issue of PLC UK line trading at big discount to Oz Ltd line (24% as of yesterday, whereas tax differences supposedly warrant c. 15%), including recent activism arguing for collapsing dual listing structure. Rio has defended the dual structure, but is keen to pull whatever levers it can to reduce the PLC discount. One way to do this would be to buy back shares in PLC, but currently it can‚Äôt as the Chinalco stake is very close to the 15% cap in the PLC line (and chinalco seemingly don‚Äôt want to participate in a buyback). Hence the strategic imperative for Rio to resolve this impasse caused by the chinalco stake. One potential way to resolve this is to do an asset swap, as per this press story - ie exchange some or all of the equity stake for a stake in an asset(s). But biggest potential barrier to this is that it would require government approval from the country where the asset is domiciled, which one could imagine may well not be forthcoming. So I think definitely a positive that they are trying to resolve it - but maybe easier said than done. Maybe hear more on this topic at Rio forthcoming CMD.

[22/10/2025, 21:44:17] ~‚ÄØBen Finegold: Centrus rely on Russia for about 90% of revenues. Think of them as a broker who sell Russian enriched uranium to U.S. utilities at a premium. 

They have a HALEU business that has produced less than 1 tonne and cost them several billion $ - it will not scale in our view which is why we need new enrichment tech such as ASPI / SILEX / General Matter 

U.S. has not been able to sanction Russian uranium since the war because they are utterly reliant on it. The U.S. is the largest consumer of nuclear fuel in the world and relies on imports for more than 95% of it‚Ä¶hence the massive run in U.S. uranium linked names eg UUUU / UEC 

Not sure what sanctions we will see tomorrow but would expect nuclear fuel to be involved which won‚Äôt hurt prices of physical uranium or the equities 

Still like UUUU as preferred US play and ASPI worth topping up at these levels ‚Äé<This message was edited>
